U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf with a crew of 28, operates stealthily beneath the waves, posing a formidable challenge to the surface ships and highlighting the difficulty of detecting modern submarines—often compared to finding a needle in a haystack.

The exercise underscores growing concerns about Russia's expanding and technologically advanced submarine fleet, now numbering around 60 vessels, including both nuclear-powered and diesel-electric submarines capable of operating in shallow waters. Russia has recently launched what it claims to be the "quietest submarine in the world," further intensifying NATO's focus on submarine detection capabilities. Experts like Peter Roberts from the Royal United Services Institute (RUSI) recognize that Russian submarines are among the most advanced and elusive globally, with highly skilled crews capable of remaining undetected for extended periods while gathering intelligence on other nations' naval activities.

"Dynamic Mongoose" also brings attention to the critical gaps in the United Kingdom's maritime defenses. Since the retirement of its Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft, the UK lacks dedicated long-range aircraft capable of anti-submarine surveillance, forcing reliance on NATO allies for aerial support when Russian submarines are suspected near British waters. This absence represents a key vulnerability, especially concerning the protection of the UK's nuclear deterrent as it departs from Faslane naval base in Scotland. The forthcoming government defense and security review is expected to address this shortfall. Overall, the exercise emphasizes the importance of international collaboration in enhancing anti-submarine warfare readiness, acknowledging that detecting modern Russian submarines is a complex challenge that demands advanced technology and coordinated efforts.

The United Nations warns that South Sudan faces the potential of genocide and ethnic cleansing amid escalating violence. Since July, when fighting erupted in the capital, Juba, and spread to the previously peaceful southern Equatoria states, around 340,000 South Sudanese have fled to neighboring Uganda—surpassing the number of refugees from any other country this year, including Syria. An average of 2,500 refugees cross into Uganda daily, recounting harrowing experiences of killings, sexual violence, and ethnically targeted attacks.

The conflict, initially a power struggle between President Salva Kiir of the Dinka ethnic group and former Vice-President Riek Machar of the Nuer group, has evolved into widespread ethnic violence. Equatorians, who were not primary targets earlier, have been increasingly attacked since July. Refugees like Nelson Ladu Thomas describe atrocities committed against civilians, including murder and assault, particularly against men and boys, while women and girls face rape and other abuses.

Uganda has responded by providing land and resources to the influx of refugees. Families receive plots of land and materials to build shelters and cultivate crops within 36 hours of arrival. The Bidi Bidi settlement, once a village, has become one of the world's largest refugee camps, housing over a quarter of a million people across 250 square kilometers. Despite Uganda's generous efforts, the sheer number of refugees—now nearing a million—strains resources, with challenges in providing essential services like water and education.

Humanitarian agencies emphasize the urgency of international intervention to halt the violence in South Sudan. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees highlights the dire situation, calling for global attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop what is described as a massacre of civilians on all sides. The refugees' stories underscore the severe humanitarian crisis and the deep trauma affecting countless individuals, especially children, who make up a significant portion of the displaced population.

McKenzie, 38, is scheduled to fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. Formerly associated with Norwich and Peterborough football clubs, he switched to professional boxing in 2013 after leaving football in 2011. McKenzie has a boxing record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a former three-time world champion.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is slated for redevelopment as part of the coalition government's £330 million investment in new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will cost £33 million, with funding contributions from NHS Somerset and the Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust covering the remaining balance not provided by the government. Planned features include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners.

The existing hospital, built in 1813, has become cramped and outdated. Matron Sue Taylor expressed that the building's poor conditions impact patient recovery, emphasizing the need for a modern facility. Over the past five years, three out of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and construction has begun on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton.

Dr. Donal Hynes, a Bridgwater GP and medical director at Somerset Primary Care Trust, highlighted that the new hospital will significantly enhance patient care by providing a comprehensive range of services in a "one-stop shop" setting. Somerset PCT intends to build the hospital on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with the goal of completing the project by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot near Sheffield's city centre on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe. He was either inside or close to a black Mercedes he had been driving when the incident occurred around 13:35 GMT. Officers found him with a gunshot wound to the chest; despite being taken to Northern General Hospital, he died from his injuries. Local residents noted that the man was part of a family living nearby and that relatives had gathered for a celebration when the attack happened. Many family members rushed out to assist after hearing the shot. This tragedy follows a series of shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, though previous incidents occurred in the northern parts of the city, not near Upperthorpe.

The passage highlights the significant role of hacker groups in the cyber warfare accompanying the Ukraine conflict. Key among these are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, the pro-Russian Cyber Berkut, and the Russian activist group Anonymous International.

**Ukrainian Cyber Troops**: Led by Kiev-based programmer Yevhen Dokukin, this pro-Ukrainian hacker group targets Russian interests. They claim to have hacked Russian interior ministry servers and police emails, allegedly uncovering evidence of Russian military involvement in Ukraine. Utilizing distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, they disable rebel websites and disrupt separatist funding by targeting electronic payment systems like PayPal and WebMoney. They also monitor troop movements by hacking into public CCTV systems in rebel-held eastern Ukraine and have hijacked network printers to disseminate pro-Ukrainian messages and messages insulting Russian President Vladimir Putin. Ukrainian officials deny using information from hackers for military operations.

**Cyber Berkut**: A pro-Russian group named after the former Ukrainian riot police, Cyber Berkut opposes Ukraine's government and Western influence. Their activities aim to thwart Ukrainian military plans, which they describe as "genocide" instigated by the West. During U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden's visit to Kiev, they hacked Ukrainian government websites, displaying messages accusing him of supporting fascists. They claim to have obtained confidential U.S. documents detailing military assistance to Ukraine by hacking a mobile device from Biden's team. Cyber Berkut has also hijacked electronic billboards in Kiev to display graphic anti-government content, disrupted electronic vote-counting systems before parliamentary elections, leaked alleged defense ministry data on losses and desertions, and claimed responsibility for blocking President Petro Poroshenko's website. They assert possession of hacked communications suggesting Ukrainian forces downed Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, though this remains unverified.

**Anonymous International (b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay)**: This Russian activist group is known for leaking Kremlin documents. It is unclear whether they obtain materials through hacking or from insiders. While focusing on Russia's domestic affairs, they have released content related to Ukraine, including a letter from a Russian fighter indicating a lack of local support for separatist forces and leaked emails involving Igor Girkin (also known as Strelkov), a former Russian FSB colonel and key rebel commander in eastern Ukraine. Their website is currently blocked in Russia.

The passage underscores the extent to which cyber warfare has become a tool for both sides in the Ukraine conflict, used to influence public opinion, gather intelligence, and disrupt adversary activities. These cyber activities are reported and analyzed by BBC Monitoring, which aggregates news from various global media sources.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran MSPs Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie delivered their farewell speeches ahead of the Scottish Parliament election on 5 May. Former First Minister Alex Salmond reiterated his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," highlighting a consensus on the need for the parliament to assume greater governance responsibilities. While welcoming new powers under the Scotland Bill, he argued that they did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. Salmond added humor by referencing the Chancellor's UK budget speech and the Cheltenham races, concluding with, "It's goodbye from me... for now." Marwick praised his service to the parliament and Scotland.

Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, serving since the parliament's establishment in 1999, moved Marwick to tears with his powerful speech. He urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster, particularly in enhancing accountability and scrutiny through its committee system, warning that failure to do so would have consequences. Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bade farewell, joking she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney's "huge outbursts of faux indignation."

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care provided to older people in residential care homes across Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their families, and friends to share their experiences, with the aim of using this evidence to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, highlighting both good practices and the impact of poor care.

While Rochira has observed positive effects of high-quality care during her visits across Wales, she also notes unacceptable variations in care quality. Her team plans to engage not only with residents and their families but also with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the situation.

Mario Kreft, Chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the overall goals of the review but expresses disappointment that the advisory panel lacks representation from provider experts—individuals who have lived in, worked in, managed, or owned care homes. He believes that their absence is a missed opportunity for partnership and full engagement with the sector.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company specializing in manufacturing and supplying animal feeds for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors, reported an increase in pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million. The company experienced growth in international sales in Europe and new markets further afield. Harbro also operates 19 Country Store branded shops across Scotland, catering to farming and rural communities with products like fireside supplies, country clothing, and footwear. In accounts filed with Companies House, Harbro noted the unpredictability of the agricultural outlook and acknowledged challenging times over the past 12–18 months but expressed confidence in the robustness of the industry and its preparedness for potential business challenges arising from Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. Another man in his 80s was taken to the hospital, according to a police spokeswoman. Detectives are treating the death as a murder and are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker. The public is warned not to approach him. Detective Chief Inspector Martin Brunning from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, and Hertfordshire major crime unit stated that the investigation is in its early stages but emphasized the urgency in locating McLoughlin. McLoughlin is described as a white male, approximately 6 feet (1.8 meters) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and an average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter-length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Authorities urge anyone with information to contact the police or Crimestoppers. Additional police patrols are being conducted in the area to reassure residents.

David Lipton, the second-in-command at the IMF, warned of a weakening global economic outlook during a speech to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington. Citing the IMF's latest readings, he stated that the global economy shows a "weakening baseline" and is "clearly at a delicate juncture." His remarks followed disappointing trade figures from China, where exports plunged by 25% compared to the previous year. As a result, the IMF is likely to downgrade its current global growth forecast of 3.4% in its upcoming April predictions. This grim scenario has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that have relied on China's growth.

The council is offering free crossings at Cowes until 2 July due to multiple problems with a new chain ferry launched on 14 May. Issues include breakdowns, running aground, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency for "training issues," and cars being damaged while boarding. Council leader Dave Stewart described the ferry's start as "frustrating and disappointing" and has ordered an audit review of the project. Local business owners, such as shopkeeper Angie Booth of Valu-4-U, are experiencing financial losses and are seeking compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that compensation is under discussion and that problems are being addressed, including rectifying electrical issues, manufacturing ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage, and resolving seamanship issues that caused groundings.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred around 07:30 GMT on Thursday on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. Police arrested a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road between Thursley and Liphook was closed until early evening for investigations.

Matching Models, a London-based agency billing itself as "an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people," faced criticism for advertising a personal assistant position specifying physical attributes such as "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned the advert as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and is seeking clarification on the company's hiring practices. Women's equality advocates, including Sam Smethers of the Fawcett Society, noted that these ads likely violate equality legislation and reflect outdated sexist attitudes. Employment lawyer James Lynas described the advert as "clearly unlawful," warning that it could lead to legal action under the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on characteristics like age, sex, and appearance unless essential to the job. Despite the backlash, agency founder Nathalie Jansen defended the practice, stating that "looks are important" to their clients and citing examples of clients requesting specific appearances, such as a "Jackie O" look or blonde, blue-eyed Greek women. Matching Models claims prestigious clients like MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods, and reports having hired 5,000 people worldwide.

A shooting took place at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, allegedly entered the room of 18-year-old student Gautami on Tuesday evening and shot her in the head, resulting in her death. He then shot another student, Sirisha, who sustained severe injuries but is believed to be out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. The motive for the shooting is unclear. Such incidents are very rare in India due to strict gun control laws, though firearms are sometimes used to settle feuds. In 2007, a similar incident occurred when a 14-year-old schoolboy was shot dead by two fellow students near Delhi.

The advocacy group GLAAD analyzed TV shows aired or to be aired between June 2016 and May 2017 and counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16 this year. However, GLAAD pointed out that more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington from "Orange is the New Black" and Bea Smith from "Wentworth". The report also found a record high percentage of Black characters on broadcast television, thanks largely to shows like "Empire," "Luke Cage," and "How to Get Away with Murder." GLAAD's "Where We Are on TV" study based its findings on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already being shown or for which casting had been confirmed. GLAAD's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, said it was heartening to see progress being made but noted that numbers were "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election, ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to face opposition. This decision follows reports that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town Football Club during his tenure as leader of the borough council have vanished. The £10.25 million loan, intended to rebuild Sixfields Stadium and develop nearby land, is missing and is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. Despite denying any wrongdoing, Mr. Mackintosh faced criticism and a potential vote to deselect him by a majority of his party's local executive council. Previously stating his intention to stand for re-election, he now believes it is time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, has been charged with the murder of 15-year-old Jordan Edwards after firing a rifle into a car that was driving away from a party in Balch Springs, a suburb of Dallas. The incident occurred in April when officers responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party. While officers were inside the home attempting to locate the owner, they heard what they believed to be gunshots outside. As a car full of teenagers, including Edwards and two of his brothers, was leaving the party, Oliver fired into the vehicle. Police initially claimed the car reversed aggressively toward the officer, but video footage later discredited this, showing the car was moving forward, away from him.

Oliver was fired a few days later for policy violations. In addition to the murder charge, he faces four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official related to the other teenagers in the car. No trial date has been set, and he is currently free on bail. If convicted, Oliver faces five to 99 years in prison and would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

Dallas County District Attorney Faith Johnson stated that justice is proceeding effectively and thoroughly. Lee Merritt, the attorney for the Edwards family, expressed cautious optimism, noting it has been over 40 years since a police officer was convicted in Texas. Jordan Edwards was remembered by his coach as "a checklist of everything you would want in a player, a son, a teammate, a friend."

Melania Trump has decided to delay moving to the White House until her 10-year-old son, Barron, finishes his current school year in New York. This decision has sparked both criticism and support on social media. Critics argue that the First Family traditionally resides in the White House as a symbol to the nation and the world, while supporters commend her commitment to her son's education.

Historically, only two First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not reside in the White House during their husbands' presidencies, due to circumstances like the White House not yet being built or the president's untimely death. Historian William Seale notes that it's not uncommon for presidential families to delay moving to accommodate their children's schooling.

Previous First Families with school-age children, such as the Clintons and the Obamas, chose to move to Washington, D.C., before the inauguration so their children could start school on time. Melania Trump's focus on her son suggests she may not fully assume the traditional duties of the First Lady, a role that has evolved to include championing various social causes.

Speculation has arisen that Ivanka Trump might take on some First Lady responsibilities, a role occasionally filled by daughters or other relatives in history when a president's wife was unable to serve. The passage highlights how past presidential families balanced public duties with private family life, emphasizing the importance they placed on family time despite the demands of the presidency.

On 27 October this year, a 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness. Prior to his death, he had made a call to the police. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has instructed the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), led by Kate Frame, to investigate the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland stated it is fully engaging with the investigation and is awaiting its findings. A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning has been issued, predicting gusts of up to 75 mph (120 km/h) locally, particularly to the west of the mountains. The unusual easterly winds could intensify the impact, and forecasters anticipate disruptions to travel on roads and at sea. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts brought down a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route into the town. The council expects Telford Road to remain closed for most of Monday to allow clean-up work.

The Belfast Giants edged out the Nottingham Panthers 4-3 in a closely contested match. Player-coach Derrick Walser opened the scoring with a shorthanded goal for the Giants, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney's powerplay breakaway restored the Giants' lead, only for Andy Bohmback to level the score again at 2-2. The Giants pulled ahead with goals from Mike Radja and James Desmarais, making it 4-2. Nottingham's David Ling scored to narrow the gap to 4-3. The teams are set to face each other again on Saturday night in the second game of their double-header. In the league standings, Nottingham leads with 28 points, followed by the Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Nico Rosberg secured victory, extending his championship lead, while teammate Lewis Hamilton faced significant challenges. Hamilton started from the back of the grid, suffered a broken front wing on the first lap, and made five pit stops due to damage and strategy adjustments. He struggled with a damaged car throughout the race and was unable to advance significantly, finishing behind the Williams of Felipe Massa.

Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished second despite colliding with his teammate Kimi Raikkonen at the start, which damaged both cars. Raikkonen recovered impressively to finish fifth, overtaking Hamilton late in the race thanks to a strategic advantage with softer tires. The Red Bull drivers, Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo, finished third and fourth respectively. Ricciardo had initially taken the lead at the start but suffered a puncture on lap three.

The race was marked by multiple first-lap incidents, leading to the deployment of the safety car by lap four. Post-race, Vettel confronted Kvyat about his aggressive driving at the start, leading to a heated exchange. The results have strengthened Rosberg's position in the championship, with historical trends favoring drivers who win the first three races of a season.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer and former international player, publicly announced his homosexuality in an interview with the newspaper Die Zeit. He stated that he came out to advance discussions on a topic that is "simply ignored" in German football. His announcement marked him as the most prominent footballer in Germany to reveal his homosexuality, and it was met with widespread support from teammates, officials, and public figures.

Former teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich praised his courage on social media, while football administrators such as Theo Zwanziger, the former president of the German Football Association, and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball commended his decision as a significant step in combating homophobia in the sport. International figures, including Gary Lineker and Joey Barton, also expressed their support.

The announcement is considered a watershed moment in Germany, highlighting ongoing challenges with homophobia in football. References were made to past hesitations within the sport, such as Philipp Lahm's controversial advice in 2011 for gay footballers to remain private due to fear of negative repercussions. Government representatives, including Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert, lauded Hitzlsperger's decision, emphasizing that no one should worry about intolerance due to their sexuality. Openly gay politician Volker Beck expressed hope that this move would encourage other players to come forward.

Hitzlsperger's revelation has sparked optimism among football officials like Zwanziger, who believe it could lead to greater openness and acceptance regarding sexual orientation within the sport.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, contributing to Brighton & Hove Albion's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at the end of the campaign, Sidwell hopes to sign a new deal, expressing his desire to remain with the team and confidence in their ability to stay in the top flight. Having previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, he believes he deserves the opportunity to compete at the highest level again. Sidwell feels he has exceeded expectations this season and is eager to finalize a new contract so he can enjoy the summer ahead.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw. Blackpool opened the scoring after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso evaded a defender and chipped the ball into the area, allowing Jamille Matt to score from close range. Colchester equalized five minutes later through Kurtis Guthrie, who prodded the ball in after a goalmouth scramble following a corner. Both teams had opportunities to take the lead: Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made impressive saves, denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Guthrie hit the crossbar from two yards out just before halftime. In the second half, Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a clear chance, heading wide from eight yards. The match concluded with Colchester reduced to ten men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

Reid, a 29-year-old footballer who made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season before their relegation from League One, could make his debut for Colchester United (the U's) in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round match against Championship side Aston Villa. Previously having played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, Reid joins a Colchester team that began the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer during an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March has intensified efforts to establish a permanent memorial for police officers who have died in the line of duty. The UK Police Memorial Trust has appealed for £1.5 million towards constructing the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The memorial will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the trust, emphasized the need for a place where the nation can honor the police service and where families and colleagues can perform personal acts of remembrance. The design includes a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to the families as personal memorials. Home Secretary Amber Rudd announced that the government has committed £1 million towards the £4 million cost of the project, stating that it is fitting to remember those who have given their lives in the line of duty with a lasting tribute. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United achieved a 1-0 win over Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the Premier League with eight games remaining. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson highlighted the team's impressive record of 25 victories in their first 30 matches and emphasized their focus on future games, notably the upcoming derby against Manchester City. Ferguson mentioned that injuries to players Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea—who suffered a knock after colliding with teammate Nemanja Vidic—would prompt changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea. He noted that key players like Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, Tom Cleverley, Rio Ferdinand, Ryan Giggs, and Javier Hernandez would be considered for the match. Ferguson praised his team's performance against Sunderland, acknowledging their strong first half and resilient defending in the second half, while also crediting Sunderland for their challenging play.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt defended the company's UK tax practices, stating that Google pays the legally required amount of taxes. Between 2006 and 2011, Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes. Schmidt emphasized that if the UK government wants companies to pay more taxes, it should change its tax laws, and Google would comply accordingly. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed the creation of a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, potentially allowing evidence to be heard in secret to prevent companies from hiding behind confidentiality rules. Google has been criticized for minimizing its UK tax payments by routing most of its UK sales through Ireland. European Union leaders recently agreed to combat tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt has argued that corporate taxes should be levied where companies conduct economic activity and take risks, rather than where products are consumed, and has called for a debate on international tax reform. He believes that politicians should set clear tax rules, enabling companies that abide by the law to operate without confusion.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce the NHS's expenditure on agency staff by £1 billion by the end of the financial year, down from the £3.6 billion spent last year. A cap introduced in October, which limits payments to no more than 55% above normal shift rates for most staff, has saved £600 million so far. This cap applies to all staff—including doctors, nurses, and administrative personnel—except senior managers. Despite this progress, the NHS is behind schedule, with trusts 10% short of their financial targets. There are concerns that while agency spending is decreasing, costs may be shifting to other areas such as NHS "bank" staff and overtime for employed staff, which are not included in the reported figures. NHS Improvement plans to publish "league tables" of trusts based on their agency spending and collect data on the top 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust due to suspicions of excessive earnings. Instances were found where hospitals were quoted rates nearly double the capped amounts for medical staff. NHS Improvement's Chief Executive, Jim Mackey, emphasized the urgency of reducing reliance on costly agency staff, stating, "The NHS simply doesn't have the money to keep forking out for hugely expensive agency staff. There's much more to be done."

The Longford Town Centre in Ireland, once intended as a vibrant commercial hub, now stands empty, symbolizing the end of the Celtic Tiger era and the country's economic downturn. Local traders like Matt O'Brien, who runs a family-owned men's clothing shop, have faced significant challenges, with business declining by 30% during the recession and staff layoffs. However, signs of recovery are emerging as businesses adapt by diversifying their offerings; O'Brien's shop has expanded into childrenswear and dress-hire services to boost sales.

Fianna Fáil, the main opposition party, criticizes the Fine Gael-Labour coalition government for its handling of economic development in the midlands. Local TD Robert Troy argues that the €500 million investment in water meters—set to become operational in several years—would be better spent on improving broadband infrastructure. He also highlights the lack of attention from the Industrial Development Authority (IDA), noting that no potential foreign investors have been brought to Longford in over four years.

In response, the government points to the proposed Center Parcs holiday resort in Ballymahon, County Longford, which is expected to create about 1,000 jobs upon its planned opening in 2019, pending planning permission. Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon is optimistic about the project's success, emphasizing the region's attractive scenery and recreational opportunities, such as the Shannon and Inny rivers and the Royal Canal.

Despite these developments, local traders believe more can be done to stimulate the economy. Concerns include issues like paid street parking, which neighboring towns do not have, potentially deterring shoppers. The overarching sentiment in the midlands is that while economic recovery is beginning to take hold, additional measures are needed to support local businesses and fully revitalize the area.

The competition concludes on 29 May at the same stadium where it began. Eight teams are participating, each facing the others twice, with the top four teams advancing to the playoffs. Leading run-scorers so far are Warner (294 runs), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249). Warner and De Villiers have hit the most sixes with 12 each, followed by Kohli with 8. The highest individual scores in an innings are by De Kock (108 runs), Warner (90*), and Gambhir (90*). The top wicket-takers are McClenaghan (9 wickets), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7).

Four current or former England players are involved in the tournament: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants).

Fixtures are scheduled from 25 April to 22 May, with playoffs taking place from 24 to 29 May. Matches are held mostly at 15:30 BST, with some at 10:30 BST. Key upcoming fixtures include Kings XI Punjab vs Mumbai Indians on 25 April and the final slated for 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in the number of plastic carrier bags since 2013. Many of these non-recyclable bags are discarded after a single use, ending up in landfills and rivers, which poses significant environmental problems. Starting in October, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags to encourage people to reuse bags they already have. In Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where such charges are already in place, supermarkets have seen a decrease in the number of bags used. Campaigners hope that the charge in England will similarly reduce the number of discarded bags and benefit the environment.

Severe winds across Wales caused significant disruption and damage. Part of a school roof was ripped off in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, and hundreds of homes experienced power cuts. Train services faced delays and speed restrictions, especially between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead. Major bridges like the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge initially had speed and lane restrictions, which were later lifted as winds eased Friday evening. The high winds led to the cancellation of six Irish Ferries fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, with passengers transferred to cruise ferry services. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the weather. Friday was one of the busiest travel days of the festive season, coinciding with the Christmas getaway and the end of the workweek. Due to the blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend, events like Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in Denbighshire were postponed by 24 hours to Tuesday, 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan told The Hollywood Reporter he is "super excited" about an upcoming film and wants "to put a different spin on it," although he didn't reveal his role. The film will see him reunite with his "Creed" director, Ryan Coogler. Jordan said, "I'm looking forward to working with Ryan once again. It's gonna be a good time." He also expressed eagerness to work with Lupita Nyong'o, who won a Best Supporting Actress Oscar for "12 Years a Slave" in 2014, and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently portraying Black Panther in "Captain America: Civil War." Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the 2015 "Fantastic Four" reboot. Nyong'o also appeared as Maz Kanata in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." "Black Panther" will be released in February 2018.

The theatre at Alexandra Palace, founded in 1875 and unused for decades, is planned to be restored for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. Retaining much of its original decor and stage machinery, it is hoped the theatre will reopen in 2018 if fundraising is successful. Alongside the refurbishment of the BBC studios at the eastern end of the Palace, the theatre is part of a £26.6 million east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. Funding includes £18.8 million from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8 million from Haringey Council, and a commitment from the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust to raise the final £1 million by summer 2017. The glazed east court will also be renovated into a public space for exhibitions.

James Milner, 30, has earned 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009 and was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46 appearances starting in 2004. Milner scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. Commenting on his decision, Milner said, "The decision we've reached is about common sense. I wish Sam [Allardyce], the players, staff and supporters success in the future."

Marcy Smith and her family from Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, escaped a devastating house fire thanks to her young son, David. While on FaceTime with his father, David noticed flames out of the corner of his eye and promptly woke his mother and sister. The family fled their home with only their pyjamas, just moments before the entire kitchen was engulfed in flames. Sadly, their house was destroyed, and their dog and cats did not survive. The fire was caused by rubbish Mrs. Smith had burned in the wood stove, a routine she'd performed many times before; however, the fire alarm did not activate. Despite the loss, the community rallied around the family, providing clothes, shoes, and even a bike for David. Mrs. Smith expressed immense pride in her son, acknowledging that without his quick actions, she and her daughter might not have survived.

Reports have emerged that the energy drinks giant is considering a £200 million offer for the Premier League club. Sullivan and Gold, who purchased a majority stake in West Ham United in 2010 in a deal valuing the club at £105 million, now collectively own over 85% of it. Following West Ham's move to London Stadium in August, the club has also been linked to potential takeovers by Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan indicated that while selling a minority shareholding to clear debts was possible, he and Gold intended to pass ownership of the club to their children.

At the MTV Movie Awards in Los Angeles, "The Fault in Our Stars" emerged as the big winner, securing Best Movie. Its star, Shailene Woodley, received multiple honors including Best Female Performance, the Trailblazer Award, and Best Kiss alongside Ansel Elgort. Woodley delivered an emotional speech dedicating her accolades to John Green, the author of the novel on which the film is based. Bradley Cooper won Best Male Performance for portraying Chris Kyle in "American Sniper," dedicating his award to the late Navy SEAL. Other notable winners included Channing Tatum for Best Comedic Performance in "22 Jump Street," Meryl Streep as Best Villain for "Into the Woods," and Zac Efron for Best Shirtless Performance. Kevin Hart accepted the Comedic Genius Award with his children by his side, expressing his desire to leave a lasting legacy. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, joined on stage by his fellow "Avengers" co-stars who knelt in his honor. The event also served as a promotional platform, showcasing exclusive clips from upcoming summer releases like "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and Marvel's "Avengers: Age of Ultron."

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old forward, was loaned by Aberdeen (the Dons) to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. Having debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and netted four times in 89 appearances for them, Smith has now been acquired by St Mirren. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, expressed his enthusiasm for the signing, calling Smith a "brilliant acquisition" and noting his surprise at being able to secure him from Dundee United. Ross praised Smith as a mature player who will enhance their attacking options. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, are set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that the warmer weather allows their Jetpatcher machines to begin repairing potholes. They aim to fill in 145 potholes each day over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December, six Wood Group contractors on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing a piece of pipework during planned shutdown activities. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes claimed that the workers were not provided with proper personal protective equipment and were unaware of the radiation risk until two-thirds through their trip. He expressed concerns about potential long-term health effects and criticized EnQuest for failing in its duty of care.

EnQuest stated that the exposure was less than 1% of the level reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) but had advised the HSE at the time. The company conducted an investigation and implemented additional precautionary measures to prevent future exposure. Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety, downmanned the affected employees for medical assessments, and supported EnQuest in the investigation.

The Unite union condemned the treatment of the workers, stressing the importance of transparency in safety incidents to improve offshore working conditions. The HSE acknowledged awareness of the incident but noted it was not reportable under current regulations and no investigation was conducted.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) is returning a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India after discovering it was likely stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu. The ACM purchased the artwork for $650,000 (£420,000) from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer's manager, Aaron Freedman, later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the sculpture being returned, during a 2012 court case on trafficking antiquities. Although there's no conclusive proof the sculpture was stolen, the museum noted Freedman's confession and decided to act. Following discussions with the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which submitted an official request for the sculpture's return, the ACM agreed to repatriate it. The museum, which bought 30 objects from the dealer—with none of the others thought to be stolen—allowed the ASI to examine them. The ACM plans to take legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35 km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5 km, with the epicenter in Garfagnana, according to officials and the National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV). Occurring at 15:48 local time (14:48 GMT), the tremor was felt as far away as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but phone lines were down and power was cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution and were to be inspected for damage. Several lower-magnitude aftershocks were felt across a large area. Alessandro Amato of INGV described the quake as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow," noting it "came out of nowhere." Italy, prone to earthquakes, is still recovering from past quakes, including one in L'Aquila in 2009 that killed nearly 300 people and two in the same area last May that left over 20 dead. In October 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing misleading information prior to the L'Aquila quake, which led many to stay indoors on the night of the disaster.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, expressed his joy upon seeing fruit still attached to his plant, though it was not yet ripe enough to eat. Despite his doubts about South Yorkshire's climate suitability for growing such fruit, he finally saw positive results, stating, "I was literally jumping for joy."

Rockstar has announced that the PC release of **Grand Theft Auto V** has been delayed from 27 January to **24 March** to allow for additional testing and polishing. In their statement, Rockstar emphasized that postponing a release is not taken lightly but is done in the best interests of the game and its fans, assuring that the extra time will be worthwhile. Despite the delay, the company revealed that eagerly awaited **online heists** are coming to consoles before the PC release date.

New screenshots of the PC version have been released, showcasing greater levels of detail. The game will support **1080p at 60fps**, up to **4K resolution**, and **triple monitor configurations**. Minimum system requirements have also been published for players to ensure their PCs are ready.

Originally released on 17 September 2013, **Grand Theft Auto V** became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating **$1 billion (£620 million)** in revenue within three days.

Simpson, a 76-year-old artist, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his painting *Squint (19)* at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. Previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted on three other occasions, he expressed that finally winning was "very nice indeed". The painting depicts a leper squint—holes in the sides of medieval churches that allowed undesirables to look through and participate in services. Judge Ansel Krut praised *Squint (19)* as "quite extraordinary" despite being "difficult to look at", noting its subtle technique and minimal language that evoke great sympathy. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art materials, saying it will go to a good cause. Established in 1957, the biennial John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, now the prize's patron, won the junior title in 1961.

Early on Thursday, the offices of pro-government Turkish newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked almost simultaneously. Four masked assailants targeted the Yeni Safak building, starting a blaze that firefighters quickly extinguished; gunfire shattered windows in both buildings. Police have cordoned off the areas, discovered numerous spent bullet casings, and are hunting for the attackers. No casualties were reported, and no group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. Both newspapers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

A 24-year-old ex-Burton player, previously under contract with the Stags, will officially join Marcus Bignot's Mariners on 1 January after an agreement was reached for a free transfer. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, and becomes Bignot's first signing for the club.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger, whose contract runs until the summer, has been linked with the England national team manager's job. Current interim manager Gareth Southgate, 46, succeeded Sam Allardyce in September and has overseen a 2-0 win against Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate, saying he "has accumulated experiences and is a good observer of what's going on in the national team." When asked about his own links to the role, the 66-year-old Frenchman stated, "I focus on my job, that's what it is about."

Southgate faces upcoming matches against Scotland on 11 November and Spain four days later, which are opportunities to convince the Football Association to appoint him on a permanent basis. Wenger expressed support for Southgate, emphasizing the importance of competency over big names and acknowledging that Southgate has a good opportunity to demonstrate his quality.

Additionally, Wenger mentioned that Arsenal plans to offer a new contract to 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin amid interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. Wenger was surprised by the transfer speculation and affirmed his desire to keep Bellerin at the club, saying, "For me, his long-term future is here." He also provided an injury update on midfielder Aaron Ramsey, 25, who will miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the inquiry.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a longstanding dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving Scotland's Northern Isles. The RMT union had claimed that some workers on the freight boats Hellier and Hildasay were being paid less than £4 an hour. These vessels, operated by Seatruck under contract from Serco Northlink, employed many non-UK residents, and Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to them. Serco Northlink, which holds a six-year £243 million contract awarded in 2012 to operate ferries and cargo boats on routes heavily subsidized by the Scottish government, had offered to cover the pay gap and backdate wages, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangement will bring the services directly under Serco Northlink's operation from next month, ensuring all crew members are paid at least the national minimum wage after finalizing some financial and regulatory details.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole involving Jamie Mitchell, 35. Mr. Mitchell had intervened in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, with whom Mr. Dickie had been in a relationship for several years. On 7 May, after spending the evening at the holiday park bar where he became intoxicated, Mr. Mitchell confronted Mr. Dickie outside, leading to a fight that was broken up by bystanders.

Mr. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault related to the altercation and, along with his mother, admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially providing false accounts to the police. They had first claimed that Mr. Dickie pushed Mrs. Mitchell and that she pushed him back. Later, Mr. Mitchell admitted he had tried to intervene, resulting in what he described as a "tragic accident." He was acquitted of manslaughter, and both he and his mother are scheduled to be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter renowned for his contributions to Michael Jackson's music, died in London at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer, as announced by Jon Platt of Warner/Chappell music publishing. Nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile, Temperton penned some of Jackson's most iconic songs, including "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," "Burn This Disco Out," "Thriller," "Baby Be Mine," and "The Lady in My Life." These tracks were integral to the success of Jackson's albums *Off The Wall* and *Thriller*, the latter becoming the best-selling album of all time in the U.S. with 32 million copies sold.

Born in Cleethorpes, North East Lincolnshire, Temperton attributed his musical passion to his father, who placed a transistor radio in his crib, allowing him to fall asleep listening to Radio Luxembourg. After working in a frozen food factory in Grimsby, he answered an advertisement for a keyboardist in *Melody Maker* magazine and joined the disco group Heatwave. With Heatwave, he wrote hits like "Boogie Nights," "Always & Forever," and "Groove Line," which became significant successes in the 1970s.

Temperton's songwriting talents caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, leading to their collaboration on Michael Jackson's albums. Beyond Jackson, his songs were recorded by artists such as Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. In 1990, he won a Grammy Award for his work on "Birdland" from Quincy Jones's album *Back on the Block*, and in 1986, he received two Oscar nominations for his contributions to the soundtrack of *The Color Purple*.

Following his passing, numerous artists paid tribute to Temperton. Nile Rodgers praised him for making "a funkier world," LaToya Jackson and Mark Ronson expressed their admiration on social media, and Chaka Khan thanked him for his "superlative songwriting." BBC radio presenter Gilles Peterson remarked, "Apart from Lennon and McCartney, no one from the UK has written more gold-plated songs than Sir Rod Temperton."

Temperton once summarized his approach to songwriting: "The first criteria is write something you love first, and once you feel those hairs standing up on the back of your hand, you can go to the world." His funeral was private, and his family requested privacy during their time of grief.

Researchers, including Swansea University's Dr. Neil Loader and Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott, have discovered over 450 ancient geometrical earthworks called geoglyphs in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. These structures, possibly 2,000 years old, were concealed beneath bamboo-dominated rainforest and were revealed due to modern deforestation. The function of these geoglyphs remains uncertain; they are unlikely to be villages or defensive sites due to few artefacts found and their non-defensive layouts. Instead, they may have served as ritual gathering places, similar to Central America's Maya pyramids or Britain's Stonehenge. However, unlike those monuments, these geoglyphs were constructed among tall vegetation and were likely not visible above the forest canopy, raising questions about their purpose.

Dr. Loader analyzed soil samples from the geoglyphs, studying phytoliths to reconstruct ancient vegetation, charcoal quantities to assess forest burning, and carbon stable isotopes to determine past vegetation types. The research suggests that ancient peoples transformed their environment not by large-scale burning but by cultivating economically valuable trees like palms, indicating early agroforestry practices. This challenges previous assumptions that Amazonian forests were pristine ecosystems untouched by humans before European arrival in the 16th century. The team likens this to a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products and suggests that the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests today may still reflect these ancient practices.

Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career-high 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes at the Shanghai Masters to advance to the second round. Despite his recent victory at the Japan Open and closing in on a top 10 ranking, Kyrgios expressed feeling tired and "a bit bored at times" during the match, which affected his usual vocal demeanor on the court. He attributed his fatigue to travel demands, including a lack of sleep, late arrival, and the lengthy commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium, located an hour from Shanghai's city center. Notably, at the same tournament the previous year, Kyrgios was fined for a foul-mouthed outburst in which he referred to the event as a "circus".

Scientists and charities in Wales are urging the Welsh government to expand the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination program to include boys, arguing that it will protect them from head and neck cancers, which are on the rise and predominantly affect men. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to protect against cervical cancer, with 85% vaccination coverage in Wales since the program's rollout in 2008. Organizations such as Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are delivering a letter requesting immediate action. They emphasize that HPV causes 5% of the global cancer burden and that vaccinating boys would be a progressive step in public health. The Welsh government is awaiting recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering changes to the HPV vaccination program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student from West Calder High School, was battling a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Despite his illness, he maintained a positive attitude and documented his journey on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," assisted by his mother Allison, sister Aimie, and girlfriend Hannah Boyd. His story touched many hearts, gathering over 28,000 followers. Jak was passionate about football and had interactions with Rangers FC players, including Neil Alexander, Nacho Novo, Cammy Bell, and Barry Ferguson.

On Saturday, Jak attended a school prom held in his honor but had to leave after 10 minutes due to feeling unwell. At the event, his family accepted his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. Earlier, doctors informed Jak and his family that his cancer had spread and further treatment was not pursued. He expressed gratitude to the medical staff and remained determined to make the most of his remaining time.

Jak spent his final days creating cherished memories, such as visiting the Kelpies, enjoying a romantic meal with his girlfriend, attending a party in his honor, and experiencing rides in a supercar and on a quad bike. His mother announced his passing on Facebook, expressing her devastation and pride in her son. In his memory, his family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and a charity football match was planned at the Energy Assets Arena to raise additional funds.

Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda in a Group D match of the Africa Cup of Nations, with Abdallah El Said scoring the decisive goal in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. The match had few chances for either side on a deteriorating pitch in Port-Gentil. Uganda had a goal correctly disallowed for offside when Joseph Ochaya turned in Faruku Miya's through ball. The win means Egypt will face Ghana on Wednesday with the top spot in the group still at stake, while Uganda is eliminated from their first tournament since 1978. Earlier that day, Ghana confirmed their place in the quarter-finals with a 1-0 victory over Mali. Despite Uganda's resilient defense and a lifeless first half, Egypt's persistence paid off late in the game, keeping their tournament hopes alive.

Lancashire County Council plans to build a new railway station in Skelmersdale on land previously occupied by Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus, both currently unused. The sites were selected over another near the Concourse shopping centre following a comparative study by Network Rail. Skelmersdale's original station closed to passengers in 1956, and the town is one of the largest in north-west England without its own railway station. The proposed plans, developed in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, envision two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County Councillor John Fillis, cabinet member for highways and transport, called the initiative an "exciting step forward," highlighting the site's potential for future expansion and its good connectivity. The council will now commence the process of acquiring the necessary land.
Police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, later turned himself in to the authorities and is now in custody. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, according to a spokesman for Hannover prosecutors. Police have secured the area and are calling for witnesses to come forward.

A study conducted by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin analyzed data from 4,600 workers and found that women are as likely as men to ask for pay raises but are less likely to receive them. By comparing full-time males with full-time females and part-time males with part-time females, the researchers eliminated the impact of part-time status on earnings. The study found no evidence supporting the "reticent female" theory, which suggests that women avoid requesting higher pay due to reluctance or fear of upsetting their employer. When comparing similar male and female workers, men were 25% more likely to receive a pay increase when they asked. The researchers accounted for factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications.

The data was sourced from the 2013-14 Australian Workplace Relations Survey, noted for systematically recording whether employees had asked for a pay rise and their reasons. Professor Andrew Oswald expressed surprise at the findings and suggested that the results might indicate an element of discrimination against women. The study also observed that among workers under 40, both women and men asked for and received pay raises at similar rates, suggesting a shift in negotiating behaviors. Dr. Amanda Goodall commented that young women are negotiating their pay and conditions more successfully than older generations, which may continue as they advance in their careers.

Oxford City Council has been searching for new burial sites for many years but has not found any suitable land due to issues like site size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. The two remaining cemeteries with space—Wolvercote and Botley—are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After these are full, only limited options such as reopening family plots, using a few reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), scheduled from 19 to 22 July in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, is introducing an app that allows visitors to access online information by interacting with signs and posters at the event site. Through this app, users can view videos, band interviews, and receive updated messages leading up to and during the festival. This year's lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan stated that the augmented reality experience is designed to enhance visitors' enjoyment and enable people worldwide to engage with the festival, access information, purchase tickets, and experience its unique atmosphere remotely.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite immediate treatment from veterinary staff, he was pronounced dead on the scene. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed that Many Clouds suffered a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, stated that such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. He emphasized the sport's determination to understand the causes of these incidents and to explore preventive measures.

During the race, Many Clouds, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, was challenged by King George winner Thistlecrack but fought back to secure the win. Although Many Clouds had previously exhibited symptoms of post-race ataxia—overheating and wobbling—he had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on that day. His trainer, Oliver Sherwood, described him as the "horse of a lifetime." BBC horse racing correspondent Cornelius Lysaght noted that while Many Clouds had a history of overheating, leading to close monitoring by authorities, the report concluded that his death was due to a rare pulmonary haemorrhage not linked to previous health issues.

Many Clouds had an illustrious career, including victories in the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. His sudden death has raised questions about the potential links between his past health concerns and the fatal incident, but officials have indicated that such a connection is unlikely.

In the autumn of 2004, a 15-year-old girl met an individual named David Ayrton in a garage in Portsmouth. Ayrton, who later changed her name to Davina in 2012, is now 34 years old and has denied the charges brought against her. She is scheduled to be sentenced on March 4th. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, expressing concerns about her well-being and the possibility that she might not attend future court proceedings if released on bail. He indicated that she would likely be held in a male prison in Winchester, pending arrangements by the prison service.

During the trial at Portsmouth Crown Court, Ayrton discussed her sexuality and mentioned that she had not undergone any physical changes or taken medication related to gender transition. The court was informed that Ayrton has learning difficulties and had attempted to commit suicide the previous summer. Protocols have been established for her detention at the prison to address these concerns.

The court heard allegations that Ayrton assaulted the teenager in the garage while two others were asleep nearby. The victim reported that she tried to stop the attack but was unable to wake her friends. In 2014, Ayrton disclosed information about the incident to a worker at the care home where she was residing in Fordingbridge, Hampshire. Judge Pearson acknowledged the complexity of the case, describing it as "slightly unusual" and "not an easy case."

World number one tennis player Novak Djokovic, a 12-time Grand Slam winner, faced multiple defeats leading up to and during the Rio Olympics. After a surprise third-round exit at Wimbledon to American Sam Querrey in July, Djokovic was knocked out of the Olympic singles competition by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Subsequently, the Serbian doubles team lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. Prior to the Olympics, Djokovic had claimed his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

Over 20 competitors will participate in a chainsaw carving event on Saturday in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms. Carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US regularly enter this competition, where only chainsaws are permitted—any other carving tools are banned—to create sculptures of animals and people from logs. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and attempt to retain the first-place prize, the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, has been sidelined since suffering a serious foot injury during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy in September. He reports that he is now close to returning to play, aiming to regain fitness before the Six Nations tournament begins in February. Currently back to running and undergoing pre-season training, Webb is hopeful of returning earlier than initially expected, possibly a couple of weeks before early February. He has renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region—where he debuted in 2007—despite offers from elsewhere. Committed to playing for Wales, Webb is determined to position himself for selection in the upcoming Six Nations campaign, which starts with an away match against Ireland in Dublin on 7 February.

On Tuesday near Sumas, Washington, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks who were attempting to smuggle MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. When ordered to halt, one man, Nathan Hall, fired a weapon at the agents and fled but was arrested in British Columbia the next day. The other man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody immediately. Their backpacks contained a total of 58 pounds (26 kg) of ecstasy. Investigators also arrested two accomplices: Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the men at the border, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who allegedly was to be paid $11,000 to transport the drugs to San Francisco. The three individuals in U.S. custody face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area east of Sumas is known as a common smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported counseling over 4,500 children in the past year regarding online abuse, nearly doubling from about 2,400 cases in 2011-12. The actual number of affected children is believed to be significantly higher. Children as young as seven have described being tormented and abused, leading to fear of attending school. The charity emphasized that online trolls are causing widespread misery and humiliation among youth.

Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, highlighted these figures as a wake-up call. She stressed that bullying can devastate young people's lives, especially with cyberbullying extending beyond school and into their homes, becoming inescapable. Rantzen urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene proactively, noting that bullying typically worsens if left unaddressed. She called on schools to take the problem seriously and encouraged children to seek help.

The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with parents, schools, and organizations to combat bullying. A young person shared their experience of online bullying, expressing deep hurt after being told to harm themselves by peers during online gaming. Despite their parents' advice to stand up for themselves or stop playing, they felt misunderstood and continued to suffer emotionally.

Advice provided by young people on handling bullying situations was also included in the report.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office requested the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee to postpone a vote on authorizing 492 new settlement homes in East Jerusalem. This move aimed to avoid further straining relations with the United States ahead of a speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry. The postponement follows the U.S. decision to abstain from vetoing a United Nations Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction, allowing it to pass. Netanyahu was infuriated by the abstention, accusing the Obama administration of orchestrating the resolution—an allegation the U.S. State Department denied. In response to the resolution, Israel took diplomatic actions such as summoning U.S. and other ambassadors, recalling its envoys to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The settlements are considered illegal under international law, though Israel disputes this. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, expressing hope that it would pave the way for the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France on January 15.

On the eve of Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, Prince William paid tribute to her in a BBC interview, calling her a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. A new stamp featuring four generations of the Royal Family—the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George—was released to mark the occasion. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office to celebrate the 500th anniversary of the postal service and later opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens, where schoolchildren sang "Happy Birthday" to her.

Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their well-wishes during Prime Minister's Questions, with Cameron noting the Queen had served the nation with "dignity." In his interview, Prince William addressed criticisms of being "work-shy," emphasizing his commitment to duty and the importance of finding his own way. He stated that both his father and grandmother support his approach and that he will accept more responsibility when the time comes.

Celebrations for the Queen's birthday included plans for her to walk around Windsor, unveil a plaque for The Queen's Walkway—a 6.3 km trail connecting 63 significant points—and light a beacon to initiate over 900 beacons across the UK and the world. On Friday, U.S. President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama were scheduled to join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle. The Queen, Britain's longest-serving monarch, celebrates two birthdays each year: her actual birthday on April 21 and her official birthday in June. The republican group Republic criticized the extensive media coverage, accusing the BBC of failing to report the birthday in a fair, balanced, and proportionate manner.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match. After a strong start from the League Two side, West Ham gained control before halftime with two quick goals. Diafra Sakho opened the scoring by slotting in his first goal since November from Sam Byram's pass. Moments later, Andre Ayew doubled the lead by finding the same bottom corner of the net. 

Cheltenham had opportunities to respond, notably through Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but they couldn't capitalize. West Ham could have extended their lead further, with chances missed by James Collins and Byram. The Premier League side made seven changes following recent top-flight losses, while Cheltenham remained unchanged from their previous league defeat. Despite a respectful performance, Cheltenham did not sufficiently test West Ham's goalkeeper, and their exit from the competition ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw. The match concluded with a final score of Cheltenham Town 0, West Ham United 2.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to spot McNicholl on his motorcycle as he turned his VW Transporter right, causing the fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. Prosecutor Sarah Marsh noted that the victim's family saw no value in Werner being jailed, accepting it was a momentary lapse. Werner's defense stated he was remorseful and could offer no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, left the UK to fight in Syria under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani. As a prominent, masked figure online, he was a member of Rayat al Tawheed ("Flag of Unity"), a group affiliated with Islamic State comprised of many British fighters. The group produced slick propaganda videos and images to recruit young British Muslims, portraying jihad as glamorous and noble. However, their activities were gruesome; one image showed Khawaja holding a bag containing a severed head of a supposed Syrian army soldier.

After spending time in Syria, Khawaja decided to return to the UK. To conceal his movements, he faked his own death through an online obituary. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, assisted by driving to Bulgaria to pick him up. Upon their arrival at Dover, both were arrested by authorities who had been monitoring Khawaja. He has admitted to four offences and faces a possible life sentence, while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Considered extremely dangerous, Khawaja was held in the high-risk terrorism unit at Belmarsh prison. Authorities emphasize that he deliberately chose the path of terrorism, engaged in training and combat in Syria, and attempted to re-enter the UK covertly after faking his death.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old footballer who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, has signed with Barnsley as their third addition for the upcoming season.
