President Barack Obama stated that achieving 100% security while maintaining 100% privacy and zero inconvenience is impossible. Some experts question the capabilities of Prism, suggesting access may be limited and regulated through legal orders.

Data-protection laws vary by country and typically regulate company use of customer data rather than government access. User data is often stored in the U.S., subjecting it to laws like the Patriot Act and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA), which allow U.S. authorities access with limited transparency, even for non-Americans abroad. European Union officials expressed concern and sought more details from U.S. authorities.

Privacy advocates, such as Privacy International, argue that Prism validates fears of widespread privacy violations, as anyone using popular services could be affected. Snowden stated he acted because he found the extent of surveillance "horrifying" and did not want to live in a world where everything is recorded.

OpenAI is a venture backed by prominent figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Aiming to advance digital intelligence for the collective benefit of humanity, it operates without the constraints of financial obligations. The organization focuses on research with a positive human impact, acknowledging the vast potential benefits of human-level AI as well as the significant risks if it is developed or used improperly. Notably, Elon Musk has described AI as humanity's "biggest existential threat," and Stephen Hawking has warned it could surpass humans by outpacing biological evolution. While some experts consider these risks to be remote, OpenAI emphasizes that AI should be an extension of individual human wills and be broadly and safely distributed. Only a small fraction of the $1 billion pledged will be spent in the next few years.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, has received thousands of Facebook friend requests after carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June. Due to Facebook's limit of 5,000 friends per personal page, he cannot accept all the requests. Accompanied by hundreds of supporters, he walked for nearly half an hour with the torch, assisted by someone supporting his arm. His nomination highlighted that while a brain injury initially took his speech, his personality and sense of humor remained intact, and he now speaks unaided. Ben spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehabilitation, walks with crutches, and dedicates the rest of his time to raising money for military charities, serving as a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, described the public response as phenomenal, noting increased online engagement and support, including over 5,000 friend requests, thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits website, and a surge in email and mail. Facebook suggested that Ben consider creating a public figure page or using the subscribe feature to accommodate the overwhelming interest. The Olympic torch relay involves 8,000 people carrying the flame over an 8,000-mile, 70-day journey to the opening ceremony of the London 2012 Olympic Games on 27 July.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate held steady at 15%, leaving 46.2 million Americans in poverty after three consecutive years of increases. The real median household income declined by 1.5%, and income inequality grew by 1.6% as measured by the Gini index—the first annual rise since 1993. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. Notably, poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who moved from Somerset to Lancashire in 2013, has extended his contract with the club until 2019. A specialist in short-format cricket, Buttler holds England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan last year. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised him as "one of the most talented cricketers in the game" and highlighted his key role in Lancashire's T20 Blast victory at Edgbaston. Buttler has been playing in the Indian Premier League with the Mumbai Indians and will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour and are up for sale. Interested bidders had until 23 January to register, with viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a final decision expected in the spring. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. The government's Disposal Services Authority, managing the sale, intends to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. 

Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, emphasizes the importance of supporting UK recyclers but also advocates for saving at least one ship from the scrapyard. She suggests converting a frigate into a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income, balancing best value for the budget with economic benefits. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers but has not disclosed bid details due to commercial sensitivity.

The Type 22 frigates, initially designed for anti-submarine warfare, evolved into powerful surface combatants with substantial weapon systems and excellent command, control, and communication facilities, making them ideal flagships with a crew of about 280. Previously, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3 million.

Since 1987, Fiji has faced significant racial and political tensions that have led to instability and international isolation. A coup by indigenous Fijians in 1987 overthrew an elected, Indian-dominated coalition government, triggering adverse events such as the introduction—and subsequent withdrawal—of a constitution promoting indigenous Fijian political supremacy. In 2000, a coup led by businessman George Speight resulted in the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister, his cabinet, and several MPs being held hostage for several weeks. These events severely harmed Fiji's economy, particularly the tourism industry, and tarnished its international reputation.

Persistent disputes over granting amnesty to those behind the 2000 coup fueled ongoing tensions, culminating in a bloodless military takeover in 2006—the fourth coup in 20 years. In September 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth due to a lack of progress toward democracy, marking only the second full suspension in the organization's history. The government agreed in 2012 to hold free elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and Fiji's reinstatement in the Commonwealth after the elections.

Fiji's population is primarily based on the two main islands, Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, and is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians—the descendants of indentured laborers from India. Until the mid-2000s, the two groups were roughly equal in number, but political unrest and coups prompted thousands of Indo-Fijians to flee, making indigenous Fijians a slight majority. Interaction between the two groups is minimal, with deep-rooted informal segregation throughout society. Small minority communities, such as Chinese and Rotumans, also reside in Fiji.

Economically, Fiji relies heavily on the sugar and tourism industries for foreign exchange but boasts a diverse economy that includes mining of gold, silver, and limestone, a strong services sector, and light manufacturing. Despite this diversity, persistent trade and budget deficits have hampered economic progress, making Fiji one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is committed to complying with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. He attributed the delays to attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups" as they were transported from Damascus to the port of Latakia. Mr. Mekdad criticized U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the government's alleged use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, denying that the military targeted civilian areas and accusing the U.S. of supporting terrorist elements. Activist groups and the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that barrel bomb attacks by military helicopters had killed numerous civilians in Aleppo, including children. There were also conflicting reports about rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison; while activist groups claimed rebels had taken control and freed detainees, the Syrian government denied these reports, stating that an attack was thwarted. Internationally, the U.S. expressed concern over delays in the chemical weapons elimination plan, with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel emphasizing Syria's responsibility to fulfill its commitments. Russia urged Syria to complete the transfer of chemical weapons by March 1. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons acknowledged security concerns slowing the process, but Mr. Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to meeting its obligations on time.

The 46th Booker Prize shortlist has been announced, featuring six authors as the prize opens up to all English-language writers regardless of nationality for the first time. The shortlisted authors are:

- **Neel Mukherjee (UK)** for *The Lives of Others*, a novel set in 1960s Calcutta focusing on family secrets and political activism. Bookmakers William Hill have it as the favourite at 5/2 odds.
- **Howard Jacobson (UK)** for *J*, a futuristic love story in a society where the past is suppressed. Jacobson previously won the Booker in 2010 for *The Finkler Question*.
- **Ali Smith (UK)** for *How To Be Both*, which interweaves two stories—one of a Renaissance artist in 15th-century Italy and one of a 1960s child—allowing readers to choose the order in which they read them.
- **Joshua Ferris (USA)** for *To Rise Again at a Decent Hour*, exploring atheism through a New York dentist who discovers someone impersonating him online.
- **Karen Joy Fowler (USA)** for *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves*, narrated by college student Rosemary as she unveils her unique family story. It is the bestseller among the nominees, with over 55,000 copies sold since March.
- **Richard Flanagan (Australia)** for *The Narrow Road to the Deep North*, a love story set against the backdrop of the Thailand-Burma Death Railway's construction during World War II. He stands at 3/1 odds with bookmakers.

The announcement has sparked discussions, with some critics like Professor David Brauner describing the list as "weak" and expressing concerns over potential biases in awarding repeat winners like Jacobson, especially after Hilary Mantel's recent double win. The mention of Jacobson's *J* in John Sutherland's "Top 10 Unfinishable Novels" might also affect its chances.

The winner will be revealed at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night, with coverage on the BBC News Channel from 21:30 BST and on BBC Arts. The judging panel is chaired by A.C. Grayling and includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, and Erica Wagner. Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. Last year's prize was won by New Zealander Eleanor Catton for *The Luminaries*, making her the youngest-ever winner at 28.

A celebrity referred to as PJS is appealing a Court of Appeal decision that lifted a ban on naming him in media publications in England and Wales. The UK Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments on whether to grant his appeal and will decide if it should be allowed or dismissed, maintaining an interim injunction preventing his identification until the hearing concludes. PJS, who has young children and a spouse also in the public eye, seeks to prevent the **Sun on Sunday** from publishing allegations about his extra-marital activities, including a "three-way" sexual encounter with two individuals known as AB and CD.

Initially, a High Court judge refused to impose an injunction barring the publication of the story. PJS appealed this decision, and two Court of Appeal judges ruled in his favor, preventing his identification in England and Wales. However, the publishers argued for lifting the ban, citing that the story had already been published in the US, Scotland, and online, where the injunction does not apply. On Monday, the Court of Appeal judges ruled that confidentiality had likely been lost due to the widespread dissemination of the details, making a permanent injunction unlikely. They described further attempts to prevent disclosure as a "hopeless task," despite PJS's legal team's efforts to remove online breaches of the injunction.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was purchased in August for £345.5 million. The new owners are planning to improve parking, address traffic congestion, and enhance the appearance of the units. They have met with Blaby District Council to resolve potential planning questions. Council leader Ernie White noted that Fosse Park serves as the gateway from Blaby into the city and believes it could offer a better view than the current "backs of sheds." Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, stated that they aim to improve parking and congestion issues, upgrade the quality of common areas where people walk and park, and enhance facilities to make Fosse Park as good as it can be.

Disney's live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" has been delayed in Malaysia due to a scene featuring a "gay moment." Although the film was initially set for release, Disney postponed it for a content review. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) stated it approved the screening with a minor edit concerning the scene. Despite homosexual activity being illegal in Malaysia, the country's tourism minister criticized the idea of banning the film as "ridiculous." A new release date has not been announced. The film received a "P13" parental guidance classification, and local cinemas are offering refunds to customers who purchased tickets in advance. Director Bill Condon highlighted the scene involving LeFou, who explores feelings for the main antagonist Gaston, as an "exclusively gay moment." The decision to review the film has faced public criticism on social media, with many calling it unwarranted.

In Southampton, landlords renting properties to more than three unrelated people are required to obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which costs £1,000. Despite facing fines of up to £20,000 for non-compliance, many landlords are deterred by the licensing fee, leading to an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. According to Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan, tenants frequently express concerns about fear of eviction and poor property maintenance due to unregulated rentals, a situation intensified by a shortage of affordable homes. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated individuals. In Southampton, specific areas were designated in 2013 and 2015 requiring licences. While most landlords have cooperated with the licensing regulations, a minority have resisted, resulting in prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Following an election in Ireland nearly two months ago, no party secured a majority: Fine Gael won 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7. Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are working to avoid a second election. Micheál Martin has indicated that Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but will not support a government program. A key obstacle in their negotiations is disagreement over water charges—Fianna Fáil seeks their immediate removal, while Fine Gael supports retaining them. A proposal to establish a commission to examine the future of the national water utility, Irish Water, is under consideration. So far, TDs (members of the Irish parliament) have been unable to elect a Taoiseach.

A fire broke out on the ferry **Sorrento** while it was traveling from Mallorca to Valencia, quickly getting out of control after starting on one of the car decks. Passengers and crew were evacuated onto lifeboats and rescued by another ferry, the **Puglia**. At least three people were injured—one seriously—and were taken to the hospital by helicopter. The incident occurred about 27 km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon, and the cause of the fire is unclear. The **Sorrento**, owned by Italian company **Atlantica di Navigazione**, may sink due to the damage, according to the Balearic Islands port authority. Rescued passengers are returning to Palma de Mallorca and are expected to arrive in a few hours, where psychologists will be available to provide counseling. Initially, the captain did not think evacuation was necessary, but the intensity of the fire prompted a full evacuation.

The Electoral Commission raised concerns about individuals, including students, potentially voting twice in the UK general election—a criminal offence punishable by an unlimited fine. This issue stems from the lack of integration between local electoral registers and the online registration system, which use different databases and cannot communicate directly. As a result, there were significant numbers of duplicate registrations; between December 2016 and May 2017, 4.9 million applications were submitted, but the net increase in registered voters was only 1.4 million, indicating many were duplicates. This caused administrative and financial burdens for electoral officials.

The Commission recommends better coordination between electoral registers to identify duplicate entries and suggests introducing verification functions on registration sites, similar to systems in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland. They also propose that individuals registered in multiple constituencies should choose in advance where they will vote in future elections to reduce the risk of double voting.

Labour warned against reacting hastily and stressed that measures to prevent double voting should not make it harder for young people and students to register. They cautioned that a blanket ban on being registered at two addresses could disenfranchise those who need to be registered in multiple locations for work or study. Labour emphasized that efforts to address double voting must not inadvertently suppress voter turnout among younger demographics.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, a former star football player at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s, was found dead in his cell on Wednesday, with officials believing he took his own life. A highly sought-after rookie in the NFL, he played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999 but faced numerous troubles on and off the field. After his NFL career, Phillips encountered legal issues, including convictions for assaulting a former girlfriend and for driving his car into a group of teenagers, leading to a prison sentence of over 30 years. While incarcerated, he was accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward, 37, and a judge recently determined there was sufficient evidence to try him for that death. Tom Osborne, his coach at Nebraska, commented that Phillips was intelligent and had good qualities but struggled with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially enlisted as a soldier in the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams during an event in Chester celebrating the regiment's eighth anniversary. He received this honor for "good behaviour." As the 30th mascot in a lineage dating back to the Indian Mutiny War of the mid-19th century, Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014. He has his own army number, is paid for his rations, and takes holidays during the mating season at the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Throughout his service, Lance Corporal Derby XXX has participated in notable events, including helping to switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial commemorating the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool staged a remarkable comeback to defeat Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a Europa League quarter-final at Anfield. Trailing 2-0 after just nine minutes due to goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, Liverpool faced a daunting task. Manager Jürgen Klopp invoked the spirit of the 2005 Istanbul comeback, urging his team and the fans to believe. Divock Origi scored early in the second half, but a goal from Marco Reus left Liverpool needing three goals in the final 33 minutes. Embracing Klopp's mantra of turning "doubters into believers," Liverpool rallied with goals from Philippe Coutinho and Mamadou Sakho. In injury time, Dejan Lovren headed in the dramatic winner, sealing a victory that ranks among Anfield's greatest nights. The match highlighted both the team's strengths—such as the promising performances of Origi, Emre Can, and Coutinho—and areas for improvement in defense. Klopp's influence was evident as he motivated the players and energized the crowd, reinforcing his impact since joining the club. The win brings Liverpool closer to securing a place in the Champions League through the Europa League and underscores Klopp's commitment to writing new chapters in the club's storied history. As an incentive, Klopp has prohibited players from touching the iconic "This Is Anfield" sign until they have won a trophy.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Minister Mr. Davis announced plans to keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations. He proposed monthly meetings to share analysis and establish a "two-way information flow," aiming to collaboratively secure the best deal for the whole UK. Mr. Davis described the initial meeting as constructive and amicable.

However, Scottish Minister Mr. Russell welcomed the engagement but criticized the UK government for lacking clarity and transparency in its strategic intentions, especially concerning membership of the single market and customs union. He emphasized that remaining in the single market is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity.

In parallel, while the UK government hopes to overturn a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 in an upcoming Supreme Court appeal, the Scottish government plans to oppose this move. Scotland's Lord Advocate, James Wolffe, intends to apply to be heard in the case.

The passage describes a study at the University of Nottingham involving 13 cloned sheep, including four—Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane—that are clones of the same ewe as Dolly, the first mammal cloned in 1996. Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr is conducting thorough physical examinations on these sheep to check for signs of diseases like osteoarthritis. Led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, the research aims to determine whether cloned animals age normally or if the cloning process leads to premature aging and associated health issues. This concern arose after Dolly developed osteoarthritis and died at six and a half years old. The sheep are undergoing extensive tests, including joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on aging-related conditions such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Preliminary observations indicate that the cloned sheep, now approaching nine and ten years old, are in good health. The results of the study, which could significantly impact the future of cloning, are to be published soon.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten favorite, Shutter Speed, won the Musidora Stakes at York, defeating runner-up Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters despite soft ground conditions. Jockey Frankie Dettori noted that she would perform even better on firmer ground. Shutter Speed will bypass the Epsom Oaks and instead race in the French Oaks at Chantilly, while Gosden's other horses, Enable and Coronet, will contend at Epsom. In the Duke of York Stakes, Tasleet, trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, won comfortably over Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden is uncertain about running his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes due to ground conditions and the short 16-day gap before the Derby. BBC correspondent Cornelius Lysaght highlighted Shutter Speed's impressive performance in tough conditions and Gosden's focus on preparing her for Chantilly.

The passage discusses significant fluctuations in the British pound and global financial markets amid growing uncertainty over the upcoming Brexit referendum. The pound initially fell against the dollar and euro, recovered slightly in mid-afternoon trading, but fell again. The volatility index, a measure of investor uncertainty, reached levels unseen since the 2008 financial crisis.

Investors are concerned due to data suggesting a decreased likelihood of a Remain vote. Two recent polls showed the Leave campaign ahead, and betting firm Betfair reported the implied probability of a Remain outcome dropping to 68.5% from nearly 80% the previous week. Analysts like Charalambos Pissouros anticipate that incoming polls will cause more pronounced movements in the pound's value as the referendum approaches.

Hedge funds have been betting on further declines in sterling, with BBC economics editor Kamal Ahmed noting increased short-selling activities. Joe Rundle of ETX Capital stated that markets are on full Brexit alert, observing that sterling has shed more than 2% over two sessions.

Global markets have also been affected. Asian stock markets saw significant drops due to concerns about the economic impact of a potential Brexit, with Japan's Nikkei index closing down 3.5% and Hong Kong's main index falling by 2.5%. In the UK, the FTSE 100 index ended the day down 1.1%, with financial institutions like Lloyds Banking Group experiencing notable declines.

Nigel Farage, a Leave campaigner, argued that despite recent volatility, sterling is stronger since March and that the FTSE 100 remains at similar levels. He also highlighted that a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters. Supporting this point, recent official figures indicated that the UK's trade deficit narrowed in April due to a surge in exports.

In summary, the passage highlights the heightened market volatility and investor anxiety caused by the approaching Brexit referendum, reflected in currency fluctuations, stock market declines, and shifting polling data influencing market expectations.

Braintree Town FC, known as the Iron, are currently sixth in the National League, just one point and one place shy of the playoff positions. After a tough 1-0 defeat to Barrow—extending Barrow's unbeaten run to nine games and marking Braintree's third consecutive loss—manager Danny Cowley remained optimistic. Despite the challenges of a long journey and an early goal conceded, Cowley praised his part-time team's remarkable achievements to date. He acknowledged the difficulty of their task but emphasized their determination to embrace the challenge and see where it takes them.

Starting in April 2015, planning decision authority in Northern Ireland will shift from the centrally managed Planning Service to local councils, allowing elected politicians to accept or reject development applications in their areas. Michael Corr, creative director of PLACE, views this as a positive move that offers councils the opportunity to develop their own community and development plans. However, concerns are raised by groups like Friends of the Earth, whose Northern Ireland director, James Orr, warns that without strict enforcement of codes of conduct, the change could lead to unfair practices reminiscent of the 1960s discrimination in public housing allocations. Orr highlights the risks of close relationships between developers and political parties, potentially resulting in favoritism in granting planning permissions. Friends of the Earth emphasizes the need for transparency, especially regarding political donations, to prevent corruption and ensure equitable planning decisions. While some politicians oppose revealing donor information due to security concerns and question the relevance of donation limits, the Northern Ireland Secretary holds the authority to decide when to increase transparency under a recently passed law.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun in Niddry View, Winchburgh, on Friday 14 March. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA, where vets amputated Teenie's severely damaged back left leg. Teenie is now learning to walk again. The incident has raised concerns about air gun misuse, with Scottish SPCA Chief Superintendent Mike Flynn urging the Scottish government to implement air gun licensing urgently. Despite a previous consultation where a majority opposed such licensing, the proposed scheme would require individuals to demonstrate a legitimate reason for owning an air gun. The Scottish SPCA is appealing for information to find the person responsible.

Liverpool Football Club has signed Belgian striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa on a long-term contract, making him their second most expensive signing. The Reds triggered a release clause in the 24-year-old's contract to secure their seventh summer acquisition, following the £49 million sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 appearances for Villa after joining from Genk for £7 million in 2012, expressed his desire to win trophies and be part of manager Brendan Rodgers' project at Liverpool.

The club struggled offensively in the previous season due to the departure of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, with replacements Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert contributing only three league goals. To bolster their attack, Liverpool has also signed forwards Danny Ings from Burnley, Roberto Firmino from Hoffenheim, and welcomed back Divock Origi from a loan spell at Lille.

Former Aston Villa manager Paul Lambert praised Benteke as a "brilliant number nine" who will thrive at Liverpool if provided with good service and can handle the heightened expectations. Former Liverpool striker John Aldridge echoed this optimism, highlighting Benteke's strength, speed, and aggression as valuable assets for the team. Aldridge believes Benteke's arrival marks a positive shift for Liverpool's forward line, which managed only eight striker goals in the previous season, and anticipates improved performances in the upcoming campaign.

A study commissioned by the education technology charity Tablets for Schools investigated the impact of tablet computers in 671 state and independent UK schools. While 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools reported using tablets, and their numbers are expected to rise from 430,000 in 2014 to nearly 900,000 by 2016, the study found no clear evidence that tablets improve academic results. Researchers, led by Barbie Clarke of the Family, Kids and Youth research group, noted that tablets help motivate disengaged students and increase family involvement when taken home, but could not definitively link their use to improved attainment.

The study highlighted that in 9% of schools, every pupil had an individual tablet, with the highest usage in academy schools. Despite the lack of evidence for academic improvement, head teachers reported positive impacts on student motivation. A separate report by the National Literacy Trust and Pearson suggested that touch-screen devices are particularly beneficial for helping boys and pupils from poorer backgrounds learn to read, with many preferring digital reading over printed books.

The research also pointed out the deep integration of technology in young people's lives, with many students taking devices to bed and a significant number describing themselves as internet "addicts". Head teacher Simon Mason from Honywood Community School supports tablet use, stating that it empowers students and aligns education with modern technological realities, even if the benefits are "difficult to put into league tables." He emphasizes that schools should reflect the technology-rich environment students experience at home and in the future workplace.

"Growing Up in the City" is an exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool featuring 25 evocative photographs that capture the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images provide a snapshot of childhood and offer a thought-provoking social history of the city through the decades. The oldest photograph, dating back to 1887, depicts Florence, George, and Gertie Rollo from Waterloo Park dressed for a fancy dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle. The exhibition also highlights the harsh realities of the past, such as child labor, exemplified by an image of a young maid from around 1900. Curated by Kay Jones, the Curator of Urban Community History at the museum, the exhibition was assembled after sifting through hundreds of photographs from the National Museums Liverpool's collections. Jones aimed to select images that stood out and portrayed both the positive and negative experiences of childhood. "Growing Up in the City" is open to the public at the Museum of Liverpool until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. The former Aldershot and Exeter player, who has also played in Italy, could face his old club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams and is set to join the club pending international clearance. Keating has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Nicholson expressed that Anderson, despite not having played many games for his age, possesses the leadership qualities he desires, while Keating is young and eager to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

Bolivia has enacted a law permitting 12-year-olds to work for others with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic realities where over 500,000 children already work to support their families. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera stated that the legislation balances Bolivia's needs with international law and aims to eradicate extreme poverty. The new law also imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. While the International Labour Organisation recommends a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, it is reviewing Bolivia's legislation for compliance with international child labor regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress and television personality, experienced a severe heart attack known as the "widow maker." After assisting a woman struggling to get out of her car at her home in Nyack Village near New York, she began to feel chest aches, sudden nausea, and feverishness. Instead of calling emergency services, she searched online for "women's heart attack symptoms," which included sudden nausea and aches, and took a few aspirin. The following day, she visited a cardiologist who discovered an artery that was 99% blocked and inserted a stent. O'Donnell shared her experience in a poem titled "my heart attack" on her blog, emphasizing the importance of recognizing symptoms and urging women to "listen to the voice inside" and call 911. Despite not calling emergency services herself, she warned others not to ignore warning signs. O'Donnell had recently hosted **The Rosie Show** on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was canceled in March due to low ratings, and has acted in several TV shows, including *Drop Dead Diva*, *Will and Grace*, and *Nip/Tuck*.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed around 00:30 GMT in an alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate in Kenton after attending a party on Saturday evening. Although he had been invited to the well-supervised event and was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group of youths denied entry, he was later targeted. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition at a north London hospital. Police have arrested a 21-year-old man on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16 who have been bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old boy held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon. Detective Chief Inspector Chris Jones is seeking witnesses who were near the alleyway at the time of the incident.

Denmark restructured its cancer diagnosis system to address poor survival rates stemming from long waiting times and challenges in identifying cancers with vague or non-specific symptoms. The new approach introduced a three-route model:

1. **Fast-Track Route**: Patients exhibiting clear "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers are given priority for rapid diagnosis and treatment with strict time targets.
2. **Diagnosis Centres**: Established within existing hospitals and clinics, these centres offer quick access to a range of tests and scans for patients whose symptoms cannot be readily diagnosed by general practitioners (GPs), facilitating prompt identification of underlying conditions.
3. **"Yes-No" Centres**: Designed for patients with minor symptoms unlikely to indicate cancer but warranting verification, these centres provide simple tests or scans to rule out serious diseases swiftly.

This reorganization improved patient diagnosis without overwhelming the healthcare system and led to enhanced cancer survival rates, bringing Denmark closer to its Scandinavian counterparts. A team of Welsh cancer specialists, GPs, NHS, and public health experts visited Aarhus to study this model. Inspired by Denmark's success, Welsh medical leaders, like Dr. Tom Crosby of the Wales Cancer Network, see potential in adopting similar strategies to foster better collaboration between GPs and specialists and improve cancer outcomes.

Following the UK government's decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), Powys County Council has been selected to assume its regulatory role over estate agents. Powys won a competitive bidding process and will receive £170,000 annually to issue warning and banning orders against estate agents acting dishonestly or breaching laws. While local authority trading standards departments will continue to handle complaints and prosecute offenders, they will refer cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys. James Munro from Powys Council will lead the new team and hopes this opportunity will enable Powys to secure more contracts and external work in the future. He discussed the new role and responsibilities with Peter Johnson on Radio Wales' "Good Morning Wales."

NHS Employers has approved a plan to expand the roles of non-doctor healthcare staff through additional training, as advisers have noted a range of extra tasks they could perform. A review by the Nuffield Trust found examples of nurses stepping in for hospital doctors and pharmacists substituting for general practitioners (GPs). The report suggests that this approach could help address doctor shortages and is suitable given the shift towards managing long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease. Since doctors comprise only about one-tenth of the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce, the report emphasizes the need for other health staff to take on more responsibilities, though it acknowledges that funding will be necessary to implement these changes.

While NHS Employers is considering the report's recommendations, unions and professional bodies have expressed caution. Dr. Mark Porter of the British Medical Association supports enhancing the skills of the workforce but warns against doing so at the expense of quality training for doctors. He emphasizes that there is no substitute for the expertise and experience that come from many years of medical training. Christina McAnea, Unison's head of health, points out that funding constraints often limit access to training courses and cautions against viewing workforce development as a quick and cheap fix for the chronic shortages of nurses and other health workers. Both stress the importance of proper support and investment to ensure the best possible care for patients.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot following a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure, which was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First announced that while parts of its services have resumed normal schedules, it will take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing Director James Freeman expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts in managing the situation.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that the proposed £1.3 billion Swansea tidal lagoon project could result in the annual deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout migrating to and from local rivers. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the company behind the project, disputed these figures, stating they lack a "clear scientific basis" and claiming that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own computer modelling suggested a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing 2% of all fish species. NRW defended its estimates, asserting they are based on the "best available evidence" and that they have shared extensive information and methodology with TLP. The Welsh Government expressed strong support for the project but seeks clarity from the UK Government, which is reviewing the scheme's viability. The Swansea tidal lagoon is intended as a test bed for larger, more cost-effective tidal projects around the Welsh coast, including in Cardiff, Newport, and Colwyn Bay.

Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister, Arlene Foster, announced that the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) will develop a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. This body, modeled after the successful Scotland Food and Drink, aims to provide strategic leadership and coordination for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The initiative seeks to benefit the entire agri-food sector, which is "hugely important" to Northern Ireland and employs almost 100,000 people across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution.

Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, emphasizing that agri-food is key to delivering export-led economic growth for the region. She noted industry representatives' calls for better coordination of marketing activities. However, O'Neill cautioned that the new body could have implications for other organizations, including her own department, and expressed her intent to discuss the plans further with the AFSB.

Members of the public are invited to participate in planting thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon. Organized by the Woodland Trust, this event is part of a four-year project to create four new woods across the UK. The initiative aims to plant millions of native UK trees to commemorate the millions who died during World War I, under the pledge: "We will stand for those who fell." At Brackfield Wood, the trust plans to plant 40,000 trees, representing the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. Director Patrick Cregg encourages people to join in this hands-on opportunity to contribute to the young woodland. Volunteers will be provided with saplings and are advised to wear sturdy footwear. Brackfield Wood is located about seven miles outside Derry city, just off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available. The trees planted will serve as a lasting tribute to the soldiers, their families, and loved ones from Ireland who were affected by the war.

Hilary's novel *Someone Else's Skin* won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the Harrogate crime writing festival. Judges, including Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham, praised the book as an emotionally powerful and finely written story that tackles domestic violence and honor crime. The novel introduces Detective Inspector Marnie Rome and is the first in a series.

US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career featuring the female private investigator VI Warshawski. Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, highlighted Paretsky's impact on the genre, noting that VI Warshawski was a groundbreaking female protagonist who changed readers' perceptions of female writers. Actress Kathleen Turner portrayed the detective in a 1991 film adaptation. Paretsky also founded Sisters in Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers globally.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015, is set to rejoin Worcestershire Rapids after recovering from a finger injury sustained in his second game for the county in 2016. Director of Cricket Steve Rhodes expressed enthusiasm about Santner's return, noting that losing him was a significant blow to the team's qualifying hopes that year. Santner is eager to make up for lost time and contribute with both bat and ball following the ICC Trophy in June. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

In 2008, Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car while attempting to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev. His wife, Ganna "Anna" Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant to retrieve a missing glove at the time of the incident. The car that struck Mr. Pring had stolen license plates, did not brake, and fled the scene.

At an inquest held at Exeter County Hall, coroner Dr. Elizabeth Earland recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, expressing satisfaction beyond reasonable doubt of this conclusion. She highlighted the challenges of investigating deaths abroad and extended condolences to Mr. Pring's family for their prolonged distress.

Close friend and lawyer Peter Clifford testified that he had "no reasonable doubt" Mr. Pring was murdered. Mr. Pring's family suspected that he was killed in a staged hit-and-run orchestrated for financial gain. They noted that Ms. Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than Mr. Pring, had attempted to claim his assets shortly after his death, sold his belongings, and transferred funds from his bank account. It was also revealed that she stood to inherit the first £200,000 of his estate and was reportedly involved in an affair with a Ukrainian man.

The couple had met online in 2006 and married in 2007 after a brief four-day engagement. Mr. Pring's mother, Irene, alleged that Ms. Ziuzina had misrepresented herself as a teacher but was actually working as a lap dancer and stripper. Despite "strenuous attempts" by the inquest to secure her attendance, Ms. Ziuzina did not appear, stating she had already provided statements to Ukrainian police.

Detective Constable Jonathan Watts reported that Mr. Pring was struck by a car traveling at 75 mph without headlights. Witnesses at the scene described the incident as a deliberate act. Although Ukrainian authorities initially closed the investigation, it was reopened in 2011 as a murder inquiry; however, the case remains active but is not being actively pursued.

Charlie, a young boy from Merseyside, urgently needs T-Cell therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital in the United States after his previous transplant failed. His mother, Sophie Fearns, stated that after his third relapse in April, there were no treatment options left for him in the UK. The family was "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" when an anonymous donor generously offered to pay for his treatment, calling the donor a "selfless amazing person." Charlie's father, Rob Fearns, expressed their gratitude, saying they received confirmation from the hospital that someone had offered to cover the bill. Now that financial clearance has been received, they are expecting to start Charlie's treatment as soon as possible.

Following reports that third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud, Apple has updated its security measures to prevent such breaches. The company extended its two-step verification system to cover access to iCloud backups. Now, when users sign into their account from a new device, they must enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile number or via the Find My iPhone app, in addition to their password. If the code isn't entered, access to iCloud and purchases from iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store are denied.

Despite this enhancement, the two-step verification remains an opt-in feature. Security experts, like Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey, suggest that Apple should make it the default setting, citing vulnerabilities in single-step password verification. Previously, even with two-step verification enabled, attackers could use tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download complete backups of user data without needing the secondary authentication.

Elcomsoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged that Apple's changes have blocked the techniques used by his software, noting that it can no longer access device lists or backups linked to an account. He praised the immediate email notifications sent to account owners when a backup starts downloading. However, Katalov expressed concerns about the recovery key system, stating it's hard to remember and could be lost or stolen, potentially causing users to be locked out or compromising their data.

Apple CEO Tim Cook told the Wall Street Journal that the company plans to "more aggressively encourage people" to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords. He emphasized the need to raise user awareness about security practices, stating, "I think we have a responsibility to ratchet that up. That's not really an engineering thing."

Dan Groves indicated that final details are pending on a deal that may see Wright purchase a 20% stake in Billericay Town Football Club. According to The Sun, the 30-year-old Wright is expected to become a club director. Billericay currently ranks eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off position. Wright, who was the runner-up on "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011, previously played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. In early March, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35.

Mr. Ashley has been asked to provide evidence concerning the treatment of workers at Sports Direct, following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse practices in Derbyshire. He has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. Mr. Ashley had invited the committee to meet at the company's Shirebrook location, but the committee prefers a public meeting at Westminster and has offered alternative dates. Mr. Ashley has neither accepted these dates nor agreed in principle to attend. The committee warns that failure to comply may lead to further action, including involving the House of Commons over a potential contempt complaint. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment but has previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight. Mr. Ashley is also the owner of Newcastle United Football Club.

The passage discusses a report titled **"Putin. War,"** which was initially begun by the assassinated opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and completed by his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin. The report compiles existing information from Russian and foreign media about Russia's involvement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine since the annexation of Crimea in March 2014.

Despite Russia's consistent denial of deploying regular troops and armor to support pro-Russian rebels—claiming any Russians fighting there are volunteers—the report presents evidence suggesting otherwise. It includes admissions from Russian soldiers and veterans that Russian military units and generals played decisive roles in key victories in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions. Some volunteers reportedly received salaries ranging from $2,000 to $3,000 per month. The estimated Russian spending on the conflict is calculated at 53 billion rubles (approximately $1 billion).

The report faces challenges in publication and distribution due to fear among publishers and a limited initial print run of 2,000 copies. The opposition accuses President Vladimir Putin of orchestrating and directing the war in Ukraine to bolster his declining popularity—a strategy they concede has been successful. However, there is skepticism about the report's impact, as previous works by Nemtsov exposing corruption and the true costs of the 2014 Sochi Olympics did not galvanize public protests against Putin. Many Russians are either unaware of or indifferent to the details, with some accepting the government's actions as support for those seeking independence from Kiev.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old man from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found dead with head injuries at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem examination confirmed he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration over not seeing the Article 50 letter before its publication and not being invited to contribute to its drafting, calling it "unacceptable" and indicative of a lack of respect toward devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns responded with disappointment, highlighting that the Prime Minister had visited Wales multiple times recently and that discussions about the letter had been ongoing for months.

In the letter to Donald Tusk, Prime Minister Theresa May mentioned that as powers return to the United Kingdom following Brexit, there will be full consultation on which powers should reside with Westminster and which should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. She anticipated a "significant increase in the decision-making power of each devolved administration."

Questions have arisen about which specific powers will be devolved—such as those related to farming and economic aid—and whether funding will accompany these powers. Alun Cairns did not provide answers to these queries. Carwyn Jones expressed concern that there may be no accompanying funds after 2020. Some in Whitehall argue that EU funds have been mismanaged in Wales, suggesting a case for transferring powers to Westminster, though this appears politically unlikely at present.

Further details may be revealed in an upcoming white paper on the Great Repeal Bill. However, as of now, the specific powers the UK government intends to devolve remain unclear.

On Friday night, two cars were damaged during an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay at the "mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community." A post on the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police officers were "carrying out duties" when they were attacked and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year following employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In a San Francisco court filing, the company's board stated they do not expect him to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, contends that many of the statements made by the company are false and accuses it of invading Mr. Charney's privacy to gain leverage over him. The court documents include evidence of illicit emails sent to female employees by Mr. Charney and racially derogatory remarks. These filings come in response to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The company's papers allege that he repeatedly violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, leading the board to state that it would be difficult for any company to hire him due to the risks involved. Additionally, American Apparel obtained a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company in the press or attempting to remove board members.

Great Britain's men's basketball team will face Greece at the Copper Box in London in their only home game before competing in FIBA EuroBasket 2017. Earlier this month, the two teams met in Patras, Greece, where Greece won 92-64. With three Greek players absent for the upcoming match, GB sees an opportunity for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, a Stratford native, expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box and emphasized the importance of high-level competition to prepare for EuroBasket. After the game against Greece, coach Joe Prunty's team will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland, their last warm-up before EuroBasket begins in early September in Istanbul, Turkey. The game will be broadcast from 17:30 to 19:30 BST on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app.

The passage recounts a BBC journalist's experience covering the launch of the iPhone in 2007. Initially, the journalist struggled to obtain the new device for a news segment, as it was not yet available to the public. Remembering a missed opportunity to interview Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, the journalist returned to the launch venue and secured access to the iPhone. Using it in a news piece, they faced criticism for seemingly overhyping a product launch. The journalist defended the coverage by comparing the iPhone's potential impact to that of the Model T Ford, a comparison they initially doubted but later found apt.

Over time, the journalist observed how the iPhone revolutionized technology, making smartphones integral to daily life for over two billion people and transforming industries like photography. They reflected on the ease of capturing and sharing images with modern smartphones compared to earlier digital cameras. Acknowledging that while mobile devices with internet and cameras existed before, it was Steve Jobs's emphasis on an attractive user interface that made advanced phone features accessible and appealing to the masses. The passage concludes with the journalist expressing gratitude for witnessing the dawn of the mobile connected era on that pivotal day in San Francisco, noting that companies like Amazon and Google continue to innovate with new technologies.

Several cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting antifreeze, with tests confirming the presence of the toxic substance in all cases. The most recent incident involved a seven-month-old cat named Meereen, who died on Monday after showing symptoms like shivering and foaming at the mouth. Her owner, Adria Pearce, expressed her devastation over the loss. In total, five cats have died in the area over the past two weeks. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings are accidental or deliberate and is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, check for car antifreeze leaks, and clean up any spills properly.

Despite facing imminent implementation of additional austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors—policies previously denounced by the Syriza government—there are no demonstrations on the streets of Athens. Tourism in Greece is thriving, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million, possibly due to travelers favoring Greece over regions near territories controlled by the so-called Islamic State. Greeks are not protesting against painful VAT increases, pension cuts, reductions in farm subsidies, controversial privatizations, and increased competition in various sectors.

This lack of unrest may precede the revelation of the concessions Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has made to secure €86 billion in new credit from the eurozone and potentially the IMF, marking Greece's third bailout. Despite not fulfilling his promise to end fiscal austerity and the added strain of monetary austerity due to partial bank closures limiting lending, Tsipras remains remarkably popular. The economic situation is dire, with businesses lacking confidence to invest and potential shortages in retail due to credit constraints.

Greece is enduring a severe economic squeeze that is likely to further impoverish its people. While the eurozone expresses relief at Syriza's concessions, the sustainability of the new bailout depends on Tsipras's ability to inspire hope for a better future. Many argue that genuine recovery requires creditors to significantly reduce Greece's unsustainably large debts by a third to a half. For the bailout to succeed, it is crucial for Brussels and Berlin to avoid triumphalism and to offer tangible debt forgiveness in response to Athens's capitulation.

Ross Kemp is set to make a brief return to the British soap opera "EastEnders" to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell, a character he last played in 2006. His comeback is timed with the final episodes featuring Dame Barbara Windsor, who portrays his on-screen mother, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy recently reappeared on the show after leaving in 2010 to inform her eldest son, Phil (played by Steve McFadden), that her cancer has returned. It has been revealed that Peggy will die from the disease in emotional scenes scheduled to air in the spring.

Kemp agreed to return for these significant episodes, emphasizing his close friendship with Windsor and the importance of the Mitchell family being reunited for Peggy's farewell. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins expressed that Grant's return allows for a powerful storyline, showcasing Kemp and McFadden at their best as they portray the brothers facing the loss of their mother.

Grant Mitchell is one of "EastEnders"' most memorable characters since his arrival in 1990 alongside his brother Phil. His storylines have included notable family dramas, such as an affair with his brother's wife, Kathy, and his brother later marrying his ex-wife, Sharon. Kemp looks forward to filming these episodes, which are anticipated to be classic moments in the show's history.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and murdered 24-year-old Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, described the moment they learned of her death, immediately suspecting Dhillon. Dr. Hills felt profound guilt for having previously reassured Alice that ignoring Dhillon would make him leave her alone, despite warnings from her other daughter, Emma, who feared he might kill Alice. The family acknowledged that they hadn't recognized the seriousness of the situation. In response, they established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon, 26, denied the murder but was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

French energy company EDF has approved funding for the £18 billion Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant in Somerset, which is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity needs. Despite this approval, UK Business Secretary Greg Clark announced that the government will "consider carefully" before backing the project, leading to a delay in signing the contracts. As a result, EDF Chief Executive Vincent de Rivaz canceled a planned visit to the site.

One-third of the project's funding comes from Chinese investors, raising concerns about foreign governments building critical infrastructure in the UK. Critics have also warned of potential environmental damage and escalating costs. Environmental groups like Greenpeace argue that the power station offers poor value for money and advocate for investment in renewable energy alternatives such as offshore wind.

The project has faced internal challenges within EDF, including the resignation of board member Gérard Magnin and Finance Director Thomas Piquemal due to financial risk concerns. EDF has had to raise €4 billion (£3.4 billion) from shareholders to help fund the project.

Industry leaders like Tom Greatrex of the Nuclear Industry Association urge the government to make a swift decision to avoid potential energy supply issues and increased reliance on less clean energy sources. The delay has also prompted discussions about the UK's investment climate post-Brexit and its relationship with France.

Key milestones in the project's history include:

- **January 2006**: The UK government proposes nuclear power as part of the future energy mix.
- **March 2013**: Construction of Hinkley Point C is approved.
- **October 2013**: The government agrees to pay £92.50 per megawatt-hour for electricity from the site, about double the market rate at the time.
- **October 2015**: EDF signs an investment agreement with China General Nuclear Power Corporation (CGN).
- **July 2016**: EDF's board approves the final investment decision, but the UK government postpones a final decision until autumn.

The Hinkley Point C project represents a significant undertaking with substantial economic, environmental, and political implications, and its future remains uncertain pending government approval.

A newly redesigned divorce application form in England and Wales now explicitly asks for the name of "the person your spouse has committed adultery with." Family lawyers are concerned that including this question may lead petitioners to name the third party, thereby introducing additional conflict and complexity into the divorce process. They caution that involving the third party can delay proceedings, increase costs, and is generally discouraged by judges.

The Ministry of Justice clarifies that there is no obligation to name the individual involved in the adultery. While the form includes guidance stating it is "not normally necessary" to provide this name, lawyers like Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin worry that applicants may overlook this advice due to the prominence of the question. They note that the previous version of the form allowed for naming co-respondents where appropriate but did not prompt for this information as directly.

Statistics from 2015 indicate that out of over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales, 12,148 cited adultery as the reason, while "unreasonable behaviour" accounted for 46,815 cases. Lawyers report that many clients initially wish to involve the third party but are advised against it to prevent additional complications. The Ministry of Justice emphasizes that while the option to name the third party exists, it is not a requirement, and the inclusion of this information has always been a part of divorce proceedings.

Forestry industry groups in Wales, such as Confor, are concerned that government ministers are placing too much emphasis on environmental initiatives at the expense of commercial timber production. Despite Britain being the world's third-largest importer of wood, at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be replanted to meet demand. The forestry sector contributes over £450 million annually to the Welsh economy, but industry representatives argue that current policies favor planting native broadleaf species and increasing recreational access over supporting commercial conifer forests. Martin Bishop of Confor criticizes the bureaucratic obstacles in creating new woodland areas, noting that only 90 hectares were planted last year, whereas 20,000 hectares are needed annually to meet long-term targets. He emphasizes the strong market demand for timber and suggests that sawmills could significantly increase production if more timber were available. The Welsh government seeks a balance between environmental, economic, and social objectives in forestry development, highlighting initiatives like the Glastir scheme to encourage woodland planting.

A boy was badly injured after being struck near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street in Coatbridge around 16:40. Emergency crews responded to the scene, and he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

The Russian Defence attaché, Captain Oleg Kornienko, presented Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys, acknowledging their bravery during World War II. Able Seaman Charles Lewis, 91, from Calmore, Hampshire, expressed that he was "honoured and delighted" to receive the medal. Initially, the UK's Foreign Office had blocked Russia from honoring the veterans, citing rules against accepting foreign medals for actions that occurred more than five years prior. 

The Arctic Convoys were critical missions where ships traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. These convoys faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. Winston Churchill reportedly described the convoys' journeys through the North Sea in winter as "the worst journey on earth."

Minister-Councillor Alexander Kramarenko of the Russian Embassy highlighted the importance of the convoys in defeating Germany on the Eastern Front, stating, "We and Britain were in it together." After a prolonged campaign for recognition, the British government created the Arctic Star medal in 2012. Despite this, campaigners believed that veterans should also be allowed to receive the Russian accolade. An exception to the Foreign Office rules was made, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first Ushakov medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in defending Russia or its interests.

An inspection by HM Inspectorate of Probation revealed significant delays and enforcement issues in the community payback system for offenders. Many offenders faced delays in starting their unpaid work sentences, and too often they were not penalized for non-attendance. One case highlighted an individual who completed only 16 hours of work over 17 months post-sentencing. The report, which examined 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, presented 15 recommendations for improvement. Challenges included organizing offenders with chaotic lifestyles, particularly those with substance abuse issues, and ensuring they attended and completed their sentences promptly. While some high-quality work and positive offender experiences were noted, the overall system lacked effectiveness in delivering and enforcing court sentences. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the shortcomings, accepted all the recommendations, and committed to implementing actions to ensure offenders turn up on time and face consequences if they do not.

The Sun newspaper called a comedian a "hypocrite" for advocating economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home. This accusation has been frequently directed at the star, whose vlogs often showcase his spacious London residence. During a campaign supporting east London estate residents facing displacement for wealthier tenants, he was questioned by a TV reporter about his own housing situation. He responded by calling the reporter "a snide" before walking away.

Although he did not respond to Newsbeat's inquiry about potential legal action against The Sun, the comedian has been active on Twitter, using the hashtag #TheSunLogic to address the accusations. He has faced similar criticisms before and has addressed them by acknowledging his wealth and fame. He emphasizes the need for personal and systemic change, stating that sharing wealth without broader societal transformation is a "futile gesture." Admitting to past mistakes made under "the capitalist fugue," he insists that personal attacks on him don't detract from pressing issues like economic disparity and ecological disaster. He argues that labeling him a hypocrite is a tactic to sideline discussions on inequality, a problem he believes needs urgent attention. He concedes that his own hypocrisy is an issue that can be addressed over time.

Dr. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome, transforming it into a competitive race that drew criticism from the scientific community. Born in 1946, he was initially uninterested in academics, spending his youth surfing in Southern California. Drafted in 1967, his experiences as a naval hospital orderly during the Vietnam War inspired him to pursue medicine and instilled in him a sense of urgency about life's brevity.

At the National Institutes of Health in the 1980s, Venter became frustrated with the slow pace of gene decoding. Embracing new technology, he acquired an automated decoding machine and innovated by focusing on messenger RNA, allowing for rapid gene sequencing. Despite criticism from prominent scientists like James Watson and challenges in securing public funding, he left NIH in 1992 to establish The Institute for Genomic Research. In 1995, he unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism, *Haemophilus influenzae*.

In 1998, Venter founded Celera Genomics with the ambitious goal of sequencing the entire human genome in just three years, directly competing with the publicly funded Human Genome Project. Both initiatives published their findings in 2001. His approach, which included proprietary control over data, attracted both financial success and criticism for deviating from scientific norms of open access.

With his accumulated wealth, Venter founded the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006 to pursue the creation of synthetic life. After over a decade of research, his team published details of "Synthia," the world's first synthetic organism, in the journal *Science*. Concurrently, Venter embarked on the Sorcerer II expedition, collecting and sequencing genomes from marine microbes to enhance understanding of gene and protein functions.

Despite controversies, Venter remains focused on the potential of synthetic microbes to drive an industrial revolution. He envisions these organisms helping to reduce dependence on oil and mitigate environmental damage by capturing carbon dioxide.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that school lunches are encouraging children to try new foods. Four out of five children who ate school meals had tried foods at school that they hadn't tried at home, and half of the parents reported their children asked for these foods to be cooked at home. Popular vegetables among children included carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research was commissioned by England's School Food Trust after concerns that some parents thought their children were too fussy to eat school meals. Officials like Rob Rees, the Trust's chairman, noted that school meals can help increase the variety of foods in children's diets due to positive peer pressure. Carrie Longton from Mumsnet added that children may be more willing to try new foods at school to fit in with peers. School meals in England now comply with strict nutritional guidelines. Approximately 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools, while about 46% of children in Scotland do so. The survey was conducted online between 26 February and 5 March among parents with at least one child aged 4–17 years old in school.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. His move to Italy included a buy-back option for Real Madrid, with the fee reported to be up to €30 million (£23 million). Previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, Morata has scored three goals for Spain in the tournament in France. During his two years at Juventus, he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles, and two Coppa Italia trophies. Morata played in consecutive Champions League finals—appearing as a substitute in Real Madrid's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus's 3-1 defeat to Barcelona in 2015. Standing at 6 feet 3 inches tall, he progressed through Real Madrid's youth system, made his first-team debut at 18, and scored 10 goals for the La Liga club.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013 but has been without a team since his release in May. In his second spell at Forest's City Ground, he made 51 appearances, having previously spent four seasons at the club before signing for Celtic. He has also had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant and the world's third-largest retailer, has been seeking to dispose of its loss-making U.S. food chain, Fresh & Easy, which has operated 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona since its unprofitable launch in 2007. As part of an agreement deemed an "orderly and efficient exit from the US market," Tesco will transfer around 150 stores and approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees to Yucaipa Companies, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm focused on supermarket and restaurant businesses, run by billionaire investor Ron Burkle. The remaining 50 stores will be closed. Under the deal's terms, Tesco will loan the new business about £80 million and incur a total cost of £150 million to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand, though part of this amount is a loan that may be repaid. Additionally, Tesco retains the option to buy a stake in the business if Yucaipa successfully turns it profitable. Earlier that year, in April, Tesco reported its first decline in annual profits in 20 years.

An athlete who initially experienced racial abuse explains to BBC Sport's Nick Hope how he overcame it. After briefly considering representing France, he is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. For those interested in martial arts, a special guide is available.

A recent study presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting highlights significant glacier retreat in the French Alps over the past four decades. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, glaciers descending from Mont Blanc and surrounding mountains covered approximately 375 square kilometers. By the late 2000s, this area had diminished to about 275 square kilometers, marking an average loss of 26%. The research, conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie, assessed around 600 glaciers across several massifs, including Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves, and the Mont Blanc Massif.
