The findings align with concerns about the over-prescription of antibiotics contributing to unintended health consequences, including obesity, eczema, digestive problems, and antibiotic resistance. Additionally, there is growing worry that antibiotic overuse may lead to the emergence of superbugs, with the government warning of a new strain that could infect up to 200,000 Britons and cause 80,000 deaths in a single outbreak.

During a recent Changing of the Guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident occurred as the guard was taking his position in the sentry box; he lost his footing, slid sideways, bumped his bearskin hat against the box, and dropped his rifle. Tourist David Meadwell, visiting from Newcastle-upon-Tyne with his family, captured the entire event on video. The guard quickly scrambled to his feet as his colleagues marched past, blushing upon realizing the crowd had witnessed his fall. It's believed the slip was due to metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on "a young man falling over while doing his job." The Changing of the Guard is a daily summer event attracting thousands of tourists, and contrary to popular belief, the guards are fully operational soldiers, not merely ceremonial figures.

"Roots," the monumental 1977 miniseries about African slave Kunta Kinte and his descendants, is being remade by A&E networks to air in 2016 across A&E, Lifetime, and History channels. LeVar Burton, who originally portrayed Kinte, will co-executive produce the new adaptation. Described as "original" and "contemporary," the remake will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and will consult African and African-American history scholars for authenticity. Executives like Dirk Hoogstra and Mark Wolper emphasize the importance of retelling Kinte's story to both fans of the original and a new generation that has witnessed significant events like Barack Obama's presidency and ongoing racial issues. Burton highlights that many young Americans are unfamiliar with "Roots" and its significance, underscoring the need for this new adaptation.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler alleges that in January 1978, on his first day working at Clarence House when he was 27, he was sexually assaulted by palace aides who attempted to force him into an orgy. He claims he was pinned to a chair, groped, and that the aides tried to undo his trousers before he managed to escape and left the job the same day. Lawler reported that he was threatened to keep quiet after the incident. Years later, prompted by inquiries into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by VIPs in the 1970s and '80s, he contacted palace officials, but his complaints were initially ignored before being passed to Scotland Yard. Police are now investigating his claims. A retired royal aide in his 80s was interviewed but denied involvement, citing that he was working at Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate fully with any police investigation, while a police spokesman declined to comment due to ongoing investigations.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child by creating a rap video set to the theme song of the 1990s television sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." The video features them rapping while driving in a car, with lyrics adapted to share their journey toward parenthood. Notably, Melissa raps about discovering her pregnancy, and at the end of the clip, they reveal a sonogram of their unborn child. The video was made to inform loved ones living far away and unexpectedly gained significant attention, amassing over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The Meeks mentioned it took five takes to film and are considering making another video after learning their baby's gender. Jesse is identified as the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Additionally, it's noted that Melissa previously recorded Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy news, and another couple from Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, had made a similar announcement video using the same theme song the previous year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at an auction held by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray but now faded to light gray with age, was featured in key scenes of the film, including encounters with Rhett Butler, played by Clark Gable, and an attack in a shanty town. The dress was part of over 150 items auctioned from the private collection of James Tumblin, former head of the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. Tumblin began collecting memorabilia from the film in the 1960s, acquiring the dress for $20 when it was about to be discarded. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500; a suit worn by Gable for $55,000; and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland, which fetched $30,000. "Gone With the Wind," celebrating its 75th anniversary the previous year, is based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel and featured Hattie McDaniel, who became the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role as Mammy.

A two-year-old boy fell into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents allegedly dangled him over the edge. The incident occurred around 3 p.m. on Saturday when the boy's mother was holding him and another child. He slipped and fell approximately 10 to 12 feet into the enclosure. The parents rescued their son before emergency responders arrived. The child sustained minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents during the incident. Zoo officials, citing eyewitness accounts, believe there is a strong likelihood that the child was dangled over the railing. As a result, the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A decommissioned speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been mysteriously turned to point directly at a house's front door. The bright yellow Gatso camera, which previously enforced a 30 mph speed limit on the residential road, has not been operational since March 2013 when around 300 outdated speed and traffic cameras were switched off across the West Midlands. Since then, speed enforcement has been carried out by mobile units, motorway cameras, and patrol officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the re-angled camera; an engineer will inspect the site, and it may be removed completely. The council spokesperson confirmed there are no plans to include this Wellington Road camera in upcoming digital technology pilots. The homeowners were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA). Expressing his enthusiasm, Bolt stated, "I'm happy to be part of the Jamaican team for the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas. I am fit, healthy, and ready to run." He added that he looks forward to the event's great atmosphere and is committed to making his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle commented on Bolt's participation, saying, "We were extremely pleased that Usain was available for selection and that the world's fastest man will be running for Jamaica. We can expect some sprint magic on the track in the Bahamas on 2nd and 3rd May." The full Jamaican team lineup will be announced soon.

Barcelona footballers Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Euro League basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid, known as El Clásico, alongside Neymar's sister Rafaella. The Barcelona basketball team secured a narrow 85-80 victory, though Real Madrid remains top of their division due to points difference. Earlier, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, a feisty match marked by several brutal challenges, including an apparent stamp by Chile's Gary Medel. Before the international break, Luis Enrique's Barcelona football team won their El Clásico match, moving four points clear at the top of La Liga. Barcelona is set to face Celta Vigo on Sunday as they continue their pursuit of a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a significant increase in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe via the Mediterranean Sea. Between Friday and Monday, the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants, including responding to SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. On Tuesday, Save the Children expressed concerns that 400 migrants might be missing after survivors reported that a ship carrying 550 people capsized approximately 80 miles off the Libyan coast. However, the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident, noting the absence of evidence such as survivors, bodies, or wreckage, despite conducting extensive search operations.

According to the International Organization for Migration, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy during the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily. Most of these migrants originate from West African countries, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. Since the beginning of the year, at least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean, often due to bad weather and the use of overcrowded, unsafe vessels operated by smugglers who sometimes abandon the ships. Last week alone, 978 migrants were rescued in a single day in the Mediterranean Sea.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger expressed his satisfaction that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool after leaving Barcelona. Wenger acknowledged that Sanchez had several options and that only the player could explain his decision, but he is pleased with the Chilean forward's impact, highlighting his efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit. Sanchez has made an instant impression in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger also mentioned that Liverpool might have leveraged their interest in Sanchez during negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Additionally, he praised Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for adapting the team following Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injury, while downplaying speculation about a potential transfer move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Lee Valley VeloPark. Turning 35 on April 28, Wiggins aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, a challenge he describes as cycling's "holy grail." The current record of 52.491 km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February after the UCI reformed the event's regulations.

Wiggins recently concluded his Team Sky career at the Paris-Roubaix race and will compete in the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire with his new team before focusing on the hour record attempt. He is also targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games in the team pursuit event. Tickets for the June 7 attempt, expected to draw a capacity crowd of 6,000, will be available from April 19, with the event broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams struggled but ultimately defeated Italy's Sara Errani 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 in the Fed Cup, admitting the match was a significant "eye-opener" for her claycourt readiness. Despite her win, the United States lost the tie 3-2 to Italy and were relegated to World Group II after Williams and Alison Riske suffered a 6-0, 6-3 doubles defeat to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. Williams acknowledged she needs to adjust her game for clay courts, stating she's been "playing like I'm on hard court and I'm not." U.S. captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need to "work harder" to return to the top tier. Williams, who secured her 19th Grand Slam title at the Australian Open, aims to improve her performance on clay ahead of the French Open, where she has won twice but considers it her least successful major.

River Plate is eager to re-sign striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Despite acknowledging that a deal is complicated, River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed their desire by stating, "We dream of Falcao García. The doors are open." Falcao, currently 29, has struggled during his season-long loan at Manchester United, netting only four Premier League goals. It remains uncertain whether United will retain him or if he will return to his parent club, Monaco. Meanwhile, Falcao has been in good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games to equal the country's all-time scoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the 19-year-old pop star who gained fame on the 2012 series of *The X Factor*, has been announced as the official face of Batiste's 2015 "Ready For It" campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign images feature Henderson showcasing a variety of hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop, including her glossy, wavy hair worn down with a black fringed leather jacket, and a tousled half-ponytail paired with a long-sleeved maxi dress featuring black animal-print sheer panels and nude makeup.

The partnership between Henderson and Batiste, the UK's number one dry shampoo brand, was facilitated by the MILES agency. The international campaign launched with a TV advertisement featuring her latest single, "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about working with a product she uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, which manages Henderson, commented on the natural synergy between the artist and the brand, anticipating an exciting 2015.

Aaron Siler, a 26-year-old man wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant, was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, on March 14 after a vehicle and foot pursuit during which Siler reportedly armed himself with a weapon. While Torres is on leave pending the outcome of an ongoing investigation into the shooting, a billboard paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association was erected in the city featuring a photograph of Torres and his dog with the message, "Thank you for your support, Kenosha."

Siler's family and friends have expressed shock and called the billboard "disrespectful," requesting its removal. Family friend Kathy Willie stated, "I felt like they were saying thank you for killing Aaron," highlighting the family's distress over the billboard's message. The police association responded by saying the billboard was intended to thank the community for its support during challenging times that have impacted the officer, his family, and the entire police department, and no offense was intended.

The incident with Siler came just ten days after Officer Torres was involved in another shooting where he wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was reportedly armed with two knives during a response to a report of a suicidal man. Knight was charged with second-degree recklessly endangering safety. The Kenosha police requested that both shootings be investigated by the state Division of Criminal Investigation. The shooting of Knight was reviewed, and District Attorney Robert Zapf determined that it was justified. The investigation into Siler's death is still ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur, as reported by Iranian state media. Three militants were also killed in the fighting. Iranian authorities stated that the militants crossed into Iran from Pakistan and have asked Pakistani officials to apprehend the surviving assailants.

The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack through state media reports and a Twitter account believed to be associated with the organization. Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group that has emerged in recent years in Pakistan's Balochistan province, which borders southeastern Iran. The group has targeted Shiites and aims to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. It has previously conducted attacks on Iranian territory, including a 2013 incident near the city of Saravan where 14 Iranian border guards were killed.

Iranian officials have criticized Pakistan for not effectively controlling militant activities along the border. In response to the latest attack, the Pakistani government condemned it as an "act of terrorism" and announced that security agencies are investigating the incident. Pakistan has requested Iran to share any evidence and stated that if the militants entered Pakistani territory after the attack, they would be apprehended and brought to justice.

Japanese lawmaker and former professional wrestler Antonio Inoki asked Defense Minister Gen Nakatani whether Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had ever scrambled jets in response to extraterrestrial threats and if research into alien visitors was being conducted. Nakatani responded that while the ASDF does scramble fighter jets to investigate unidentified flying objects that could violate Japan's airspace, they have not encountered any UFOs believed to be from outer space. Inoki, known for his wrestling career and political activities, claims to have seen a UFO himself but admits he doesn't know if aliens exist. The article also notes that this is not the first time Japanese officials have discussed potential extraterrestrial visitors; in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal ramifications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

At Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China, 35-year-old passenger Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on collapsed. Worried about cleanliness, he stood on the rim of the porcelain toilet instead of sitting. The toilet tipped over and shattered, causing significant injuries. Too embarrassed to call out, he phoned his traveling companions for help. Emergency personnel took him to a local hospital, where he received several dozen stitches. While he initially admitted to his friends that he was squatting, he later told police he was sitting when the toilet gave way, possibly to avoid compensation claims. Authorities considered the incident an accident, and a police spokesman reminded the public that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl over a four-year period and secretly filming her and others using a hidden camera in a bathroom. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera under her bathroom sink in March. She reported that Rebbie had been watching her undress and entering her bedroom to molest her from the age of nine until she was 13. Investigators discovered 41 videos from the hidden camera showing the girl and others in the bathroom, with 34 videos capturing victims while they showered. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims, including other juveniles, and purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim. He is being held on a $500,000 bail, with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series, featured in his book roughly titled "Daughter and Salaryman," captures fathers leaping energetically into the air next to their daughters. In each photograph, the daughters stand wearing casual clothing, often looking directly into the camera with po-faced or smiling expressions, while their fathers, dressed in sharp suits, perform dramatic poses despite their age. Some fathers show pained expressions during their jumps, adding to the charm of the images. According to the photographer's website, the series allows fathers, who usually have to act serious, to express their fun side by being "a hero jumping the sky, enfolding strong excitement and hope." The families are photographed in front of various Japanese landmarks. Though little else is known about the project, the curious and engaging nature of the photos is generating significant interest online.

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has reignited discussions about Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the national cricket team. During a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval ahead of the County Championship season, Pietersen appeared both contemplative and jovial, engaging with photographers and joking with teammates like Chris Tremlett. Downton's sacking removes a major barrier for Pietersen, who was controversially dropped from the England squad by Downton in 2014 after the unsuccessful Ashes tour in Australia. Determined to regain his place in the England setup before the home Ashes series, Pietersen has rejoined Surrey and aims to make a strong impression in the upcoming season, starting with a match against Glamorgan on April 19.

Relegation-threatened Romanian football club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have sacked their Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially dismissed on Wednesday after a series of poor results, Ze Maria was reinstated the following day when owner Angelo Massone decided to give the coaching staff another chance. However, after a 2-0 defeat to mid-table FC Botosani on Saturday, Ze Maria was sacked again. The 41-year-old former right back, who was capped 25 times by Brazil during a five-year international career and played for Inter Milan and Parma, had become Ceahlaul's third coach of the season when he replaced Florin Marin in January. The latest loss left Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points adrift of safety. Ze Maria will be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes that the Colombian striker must be regretting his loan move to Manchester United, even though he was unhappy in France. Falcao joined Manchester United on a season-long loan from Atletico Madrid but has struggled to regain his form after a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals all season. Manchester United would need to pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent, but they are unlikely to do so due to his underperformance. Dirar suggested that while Falcao was not feeling well in Monaco, he might have been better off staying, as he would have played more and participated in the Champions League.

A tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt robbed a dairy on Union Street in east Christchurch, New Zealand, around 12:30 pm on Saturday. He demanded cash from the owner's daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, and fled with the till drawer containing about $1,500. The dairy owner noted that while previous thefts involved items like cigarettes, this incident was more frightening due to the use of a mask. Police reported no signs of any weapons and are appealing to the public for assistance in identifying the robber. They urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers at **0800 555 111** or to message the police online.

Math teacher Kaitlyn Granado, 24, from MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for alleged inappropriate relationships with two 15-year-old male students. On March 19, she was first arrested after admitting to kissing a student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave by the school district. Shortly after, a second student came forward, claiming that he had sexual encounters with Granado on two consecutive nights in January, in her car parked near another school in Dallas. Granado was arrested again on these new allegations and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district has reassured families that immediate and appropriate actions were taken to prevent her from interacting with students or being on school property.

A video viewed over half a million times online shows a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws. The crocodile, holding the black dog wearing a red collar, was witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston and his wife while on holiday. Mr. Weston described how the crocodile kept the dog in its mouth for hours without moving much. The dog belonged to the local bike shop owner. Onlookers were shocked by the sight, and social media reactions included expressions of horror and fear toward crocodiles. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta due to the nearby mangroves and a crocodile sanctuary located about 200 meters away from the marina. The local "American Crocodiles" can grow up to six meters long and are increasingly encountering humans as urbanization encroaches on their natural habitats.

After a 2-0 defeat to Southampton, Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident that his team can avoid relegation from the Premier League. Hull City is just two points above the drop zone with six games remaining, including tough fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Despite having only six wins this season—short of the ten wins Bruce initially targeted—he hopes that eight or nine victories might be enough for survival. Bruce attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries of key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. With some players returning from injury, he believes a positive mindset will help them secure the necessary results. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory moved them up to fifth place. Manager Ronald Koeman intends to address team discipline after intervening when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty designated for James Ward-Prowse, emphasizing that team rules must be respected.

Teacher **Ian Guffick** from Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, has been banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers following the completion of the national curriculum tests (SATs) for 11-year-olds. Guffick not only instructed pupils to amend their answers but also altered some of the exam responses himself before the papers were submitted. This misconduct led to an investigation by the local education authority after school officials were alerted to the breach of exam rules.

The investigation revealed that changes were made to exam scripts outside of test conditions, which is prohibited. As a result, the Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the entire school for that year. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct, although he claimed he asked pupils only to make their answers more legible.

A conduct panel, run by the National College for Teaching and Leadership and chaired by Martin Pilkington, acknowledged that while Guffick's actions were dishonest, they fell short of fraud or serious dishonesty. The panel recognized his remorse and the fact that he was forthcoming during the investigation. Acting on behalf of Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, Paul Heathcote imposed the ban, stating that Guffick's deliberate actions had a serious impact on the school. Guffick was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard has struggled for playing time since joining the club in 2010, making only 19 league appearances over five seasons. Despite being third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdés and being told he can leave the club, Lindegaard is enjoying life off the pitch. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri last year in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius. The couple, who have been dating since 2012 and share a son, often share their happiness on Instagram. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots and over 17,000 Instagram followers, frequently posts her modeling photos. While Lindegaard's football career at Manchester United has not flourished, he appears to be thriving in his personal life.

Thirteen glowing blue letters that once crowned Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday. Expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000, the only bid—a $260,000 offer—came from a Sotheby's employee attempting to spark interest. The letters, each 10 feet tall and some also 10 feet wide, have been owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson since he purchased them after the stadium's final game in 2008. Installed atop the stadium in 1976, a year before Jackson joined the team, the signage had become an iconic symbol of the Yankees and New York City. Jackson, who attended the auction, hoped that "a new generation" would own and enjoy the letters but joked that he might have overestimated their appeal due to their massive size. He had promised to personally visit the new owner if the letters were sold to someone in the United States. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s exceeded expectations by selling for $112,500, significantly higher than its estimated $20,000 to $30,000 value.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities following incidents where Sterling was seen inhaling nitrous oxide and both players were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to them privately but will not discipline them, emphasizing the importance of appropriate behavior for elite athletes. Ahead of the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, Rodgers has not disclosed whether Steven Gerrard, returning from suspension, will play. He is focused on leading Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management, believing that past near-misses have prepared the team to progress.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's £42.5 million playmaker, returned to London after impressing in Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win over Georgia. Upon his return, he shared a photo on Twitter relaxing at home with his dog, captioned "Home Sweet Home." Ozil missed Arsenal's previous match against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start in the upcoming Premier League game against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium. Rumors circulated that he was spotted in a Berlin nightclub during his absence, but manager Arsene Wenger dismissed these claims. Since recovering from injury in January, Ozil has been in fine form, recording four assists and three goals. He expressed that he is adjusting well to English football's demanding schedule, stating, "It's demanding because you don't have many breaks to recover, but as a footballer it's great to have so many games... that's why I fit perfectly here."

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has confirmed that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique and is "very happy" with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title, with only six games remaining. Despite speculation about his future, Bartomeu praised Enrique's dedication, noting his hard work in preparing for matches against Paris Saint-Germain and Valencia. He emphasized that there is plenty of time to discuss Enrique's contract in the future and highlighted that Barcelona is one of the few clubs still capable of winning three trophies this season. Recently, Barcelona secured a comfortable victory over Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez, who scored in the first minute, and Lionel Messi, who added a second after skillfully rounding goalkeeper Diego Alves at the Nou Camp.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay at the club until 2020 with a deal worth around £100,000 per week. The 24-year-old vice-captain had 14 months remaining on his current contract, and negotiations had been ongoing since the beginning of the season. Henderson is the third key player under manager Brendan Rodgers to commit his future to Liverpool, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Having contributed 13 assists and seven goals from midfield this season, Henderson is considered a candidate to replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy this summer. Meanwhile, discussions with Raheem Sterling over a new contract are expected to resume after the season's end, despite his initial rejection of a new deal. Manager Rodgers is eager to secure important players like Henderson, with up to ten players anticipated to leave the club.

Filipe Luis asserts his desire to remain at Chelsea until the end of his three-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him this summer. Since moving from the Spanish champions last July, the full-back has struggled to secure the left-back position at Stamford Bridge. Although Atletico hopes his situation might facilitate a return, Luis affirms, "I'm happy at Chelsea. I want to stay at the club until the end of my contract." After participating in Brazil's friendly victories over France and Chile during the international break, Luis is refocusing on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho urges the team to stay focused and strive to win every remaining game. Acknowledging the difficulty of the nine upcoming matches, Luis believes the team is prepared to handle the challenges ahead.

Nathan Hughes, the Wasps No. 8, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after initially being suspended for accidentally knocking out George North during a match on March 27. The disciplinary panel had originally ruled Hughes "reckless" for failing to prevent his knee from colliding with North's head as the Northampton player scored a try. The incident left North unconscious—the third such occurrence for him in two months—and he was stretchered off the field at Franklin's Gardens. Hughes was shown a red card and subsequently missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon while awaiting the appeal.

The ban sparked widespread criticism from players and commentators, including Wasps captain James Haskell and former England player Austin Healey, who called the suspension a "total joke." On appeal, the panel, led by Jeremy Summers, reviewed new evidence and concluded that no act of foul play occurred and that the collision was accidental. As a result, Hughes's ban was rescinded, allowing him to return to play immediately, though he was not included in the match-day squad for the upcoming game against London Welsh. Meanwhile, George North has been advised to take a minimum of a month off from playing to recover fully from his concussion symptoms.

Fiery sunsets with a deep reddish hue appeared in Washington and parts of the Pacific Northwest, captivating locals like Seattle native Tim Durkan, who photographed the stunning scenes. These dramatic sunsets were caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, where farmers' grass-burning activities on April 14 escalated out of control due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. Although rescue crews extinguished the flames, atmospheric winds carried the lingering smoke across the Pacific Ocean to North America. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelengths of sunlight—greens, blues, yellows, and purples—allowing red and orange hues to dominate the sky, especially during sunsets when sunlight passes through more of the atmosphere. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the fiery sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Missouri resident Becky Schoenig had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. When police recovered the car after a tip from Mick Sexton, she discovered that the thieves had modified it by spray-painting the rims red, adding red detailing on the sides, and incorporating orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig embraced the changes and posted a photo on Facebook with the caption: "I want to thank the car thieves for pimping out my vehicle for me.... This b***h is pimpin now!!!"

To honor Sexton for his help, she created a new smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, featuring banana, pineapple, peach, and coconut cream. While she is having the car professionally cleaned to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana, her positive and humorous outlook remains. Friends describe her as vibrant and happy, someone who loves making people laugh.

Manchester City players risk losing £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. Star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure have incentivized contracts to help the club comply with financial fair play regulations. Following a defeat to Manchester United in the Manchester derby at Old Trafford, City's European ambitions are uncertain. They sit in fourth place and could be just four points ahead of Liverpool if Liverpool wins against Newcastle United. While the top three Premier League teams qualify automatically for the Champions League, the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. The squad has a total of approximately £12 million in bonuses hinging on this qualification. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged the team's decline, stating, "In the last three months, we have thrown it into the garbage." The club now faces challenges in signing world-class players like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who is also pursued by Manchester United. Meanwhile, Manchester United's manager, Louis van Gaal, remains confident in attracting top talent, saying, "I don't have any doubt that players are coming to Manchester United."

Manchester United's Under-18 team secured a 1-0 victory over Manchester City in the 'mini-derby' held at Moss Lane, the 6,000-capacity home of Altrincham FC. The match, which kicked off at 3 p.m. on Saturday with free entry, drew close to 1,000 spectators. Remarkably, 13 of the 22 starting players were English, including 10 Mancunians, highlighting local talent on both sides.

United's Callum Gribbin, an England Under-17 star known for his impressive skills, scored the only goal of the match with a delightful free-kick after being fouled on the edge of the box. Coach Paul McGuinness deployed a formation mirroring the first team, featuring three at the back with wingbacks, to acclimate his players to senior-level play.

The game was filled with notable moments, including near-misses from United's Marcus Rashford and a striking 25-yard drive from Cameron Borthwick-Jackson that hit the crossbar. City's Marcus Wood attempted an audacious chip, and late efforts from substitutes Aaron Nemane and Javairo Dilrosun threatened an equalizer.

The victory leaves Manchester United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand in the Barclays Under-18 Premier League end-of-season playoff series. The match showcased high levels of skill and commitment, suggesting that several players from both teams have the potential to progress to senior football in the coming years.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th international cap in a 1-1 draw between England and Italy. Hart, who marked his own milestone with his 50th cap for England, expressed admiration for the 37-year-old Buffon, stating that he continues to learn by watching him. Acknowledging the significant gap in their caps, Hart found Buffon's achievements inspirational and aspired to continue playing well for both his club and country to increase his own cap tally.

Chipotle, the Mexican fast-casual restaurant chain, is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. Customers will incur a 9% service charge, with delivery fees starting at $5 and varying based on distance and demand. Previously hesitant to collaborate with third-party delivery services, Chipotle has now approved this partnership, leveraging Postmates' network of independent contractors who use their own vehicles, similar to Uber's model.

The move comes as Chipotle continues to grow in popularity, highlighted by visits from presidential candidates. Hillary Clinton was seen ordering a meal at a Chipotle in Maumee, Ohio, shortly after announcing her campaign, while Marco Rubio is a regular customer who emphasizes his practice of tipping staff.

Other major food and beverage chains are also tapping into the lucrative delivery market. Starbucks plans to deliver coffee in parts of Seattle and New York by year's end through a partnership with Postmates. Taco Bell is set to test a delivery service this year, McDonald's is developing its "McDelivery" program, and Burger King has launched a pilot delivery program in select markets, including parts of New York City, via bkdelivers.com.

Bill and Denise Richard, the parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard—the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings—have written a front-page opinion piece in *The Boston Globe* urging the U.S. Justice Department to remove the death penalty option for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. While acknowledging the brutality of Tsarnaev's actions, which also severely injured their 7-year-old daughter Jane, the Richards argue that pursuing the death penalty will lead to prolonged appeals, forcing their family to relive the painful events for years to come. They believe that a sentence of life in prison without the possibility of release, along with Tsarnaev waiving all rights to appeal, would help their family, the city of Boston, and the country to heal and move forward.

A mystery billionaire has transformed a Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet into an opulent private residence in the sky, at an estimated cost of £400 million and over three years of customization. Originally capable of seating up to 600 passengers, this aircraft has been redesigned to accommodate the owner and several dozen guests in unparalleled luxury. The interior resembles that of a high-end hotel, featuring multiple lounges, a state room, and a master bedroom furnished with lavish decor, including a spacious bed, armchair, and sofa for relaxation.

For dining, the jet boasts a large dining room connected to a fully equipped kitchen, allowing a private chef to prepare gourmet meals. The central dining area serves as a communal space where guests can enjoy exquisite cuisine. Business needs are met with a conference room outfitted with a long table, ideal for meetings during flights. Additional sleeping accommodations are provided in the "aeroloft" on the top deck, which houses eight full beds for guests seeking rest.

Designed by Greenpoint Technologies, the aircraft's layout emphasizes both comfort and elegance. The lounges are adorned with plush furnishings and are designed for leisure activities like watching television, offering a serene environment that contrasts sharply with conventional airplane cabins. The guest bedrooms can double as offices, complete with porthole-style windows that hint at the plane's true nature.

The jet's interior images reveal spaces that could easily be mistaken for those in a luxury hotel, with over-the-top decorations and meticulous attention to detail. This exclusive airborne home sets a new standard for private air travel, providing an experience that surpasses even the most extravagant first-class accommodations on commercial flights.

SpaceX successfully launched a two-stage Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station (ISS) on Tuesday. While the Dragon is en route to deliver over 4,300 pounds (1,950 kilograms) of supplies—including research equipment and an espresso maker called ISSpresso—the company's attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful. According to SpaceX founder Elon Musk, the rocket landed on the droneship but tipped over upon impact.

This mission marks SpaceX's sixth resupply trip to the ISS and underscores the company's ongoing efforts to reduce space exploration costs by developing reusable rockets. Despite the landing setback, SpaceX plans to continue attempting rocket recoveries at sea, with the long-term goal of perfecting land-based landings. The Dragon spacecraft will spend about five weeks docked at the ISS before returning to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of experiments, trash, and other materials, ultimately splashing down in the Pacific Ocean off California. The launch was the second attempt for this mission after a weather-related delay on Monday.

Priscilla Presley, 69, is collaborating with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the "ultimate wedding" at the brand-new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas. The winning duo, to be announced next Monday, will tie the knot on Thursday, April 23, with Priscilla serving as a witness. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who married Elvis in 1967, has been involved in the design of the chapel, emphasizing that it is "first-class" and not a joke, with no impersonators allowed. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside his Memphis home. Couples wishing to enter the contest must submit a video or photos along with an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after their 2-0 victory over Newcastle United on Monday night. Both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, matching the highest number of appearances by any player in Europe's top five leagues this campaign. With Liverpool now four points behind Manchester City, who recently lost 4-2 to Manchester United, Henderson feels they can "pile the pressure" on City in the race for Champions League qualification.

In the match against Newcastle, Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute with impressive skill at Anfield. Joe Allen doubled the lead with 20 minutes remaining, capitalizing on a defensive error to score his first Anfield goal. Allen acknowledged the significance of the win following recent defeats and admitted that Newcastle had a strong case for a penalty when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez. The victory keeps Liverpool in contention for a top-four finish in the Premier League.

Roma ended their four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli 1-0 in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanić scored the decisive goal in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan De Sanctis delivered an outstanding performance, making several key saves in the second half to secure the victory. The win moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in second place. Security was heightened for the match due to past incidents between fans, but no problems were reported. Napoli extended their winless run to five matches and remained fifth in the standings. Notably, Napoli forward Lorenzo Insigne made his return from a knee injury late in the game.

Doncaster Rovers' lackluster season continued with a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town, whose playoff hopes had faded, at the Keepmoat Stadium. The uninspiring match tested even the most dedicated fans' patience. Faced with the challenge of creating match highlights, Doncaster's media team produced a brief 27-second video for the club's YouTube channel, featuring just 14 seconds of action that included the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man named Roland Giroux has developed a remarkable relationship with his pet blood parrot cichlid fish. Despite the typical limitations of interacting with marine pets through touch, Mr. Giroux gently cups and massages his fish inside its tank, capturing these interactions on camera. The fish initially moves away but quickly returns to rest between his fingers, appearing to enjoy the sensation as it stays completely still during the massage. Repeatedly, the fish swims off only to return for more stroking, even swimming up his arm and circling his fingers.

Previously, the fish shared its tank with two others who bullied it, prompting Mr. Giroux to remove them. He began hand-feeding it frozen blood worms, noticing it becoming more sociable over time. The fish grew to enjoy being stroked and would become frustrated if deprived of daily interaction. Now, Mr. Giroux spends at least 15 minutes each day massaging and playing with his pet. The video concludes with the fish displaying apparent sadness when Mr. Giroux removes his hand from the tank, following it to the surface. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlids, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery temperament in the England cricket team, returned to the Kensington Oval—a venue where he previously broke his wrist punching a locker after a dismissal. This serves as a reminder for him to channel his aggression constructively now that he's back with the team. Recently, Stokes clashed with Marlon Samuels during the second Test against the West Indies but responded positively after a discussion with coach Peter Moores. While his passionate nature brings energy to a sport sometimes criticized for lacking personality, it's crucial that his aggression remains controlled to translate into runs and wickets. England is keen to have Stokes play as much as possible to help him realize his full potential. Despite considerations like possibly including a second spinner, Adil Rashid, the team aims to develop exciting talents like Stokes and Chris Jordan, balancing their natural exuberance with the discipline needed for international cricket.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out all 33,000 tickets due to overwhelming demand following their impressive 3-0 victory over Israel. Both teams lead Group B with 11 points from five games, with Belgium, ranked fourth in the world, ahead on goal difference. Expectations are high for Wales to qualify for their first major tournament since the 1958 World Cup. Despite speculation about moving the match to the larger 74,500-capacity Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevent changing venues within 120 days of the match, and the Wales squad prefers the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium, where they have not played Belgium since 2011.

England Under-17 coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The defending champions, known as the Young Lions, secured their place in the tournament with a perfect record in qualifying. Drawn into Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, England will kick off their campaign against Italy in Burgas on May 7, followed by matches against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

The squad features talented youth players from several Premier League clubs. Notable inclusions are Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal duo Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, both receiving their first call-ups to the national team. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return to the squad after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers, where England achieved victories over Romania, Norway, and Slovenia.

**England Under-17 Squad:**

*Goalkeepers:*
- Paul Woolston (Newcastle United)
- Will Huffer (Leeds United)

*Defenders:*
- Danny Collinge (Stuttgart)
- Reece Oxford (West Ham United)
- Easah Suliman (Aston Villa)
- James Yates (Everton)
- Jay Dasilva (Chelsea)
- Tayo Edun (Fulham)

*Midfielders:*
- Trent Arnold (Liverpool)
- Daniel Wright (Sunderland)
- Herbie Kane (Liverpool)
- Tom Davies (Everton)
- Marcus Edwards (Tottenham Hotspur)
- Nathan Holland (Everton)
- Chris Willock (Arsenal)

*Forwards:*
- Layton Ndukwu (Leicester City)
- Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal)
- Ike Ugbo (Chelsea)

The team aims to defend their title with a blend of newcomers and experienced youth players, hoping to replicate last year's success when they defeated Holland on penalties in the final.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly regarded playmaker from Anderlecht's youth academy. Considered one of the best talents to emerge from the Belgian club, Patoulidis has also drawn attention from Arsenal and Barcelona. At age 12, he declined an offer to join Barcelona's La Masia academy to continue his studies. Continuing to impress, Patoulidis is now the subject of discussions between Manchester City and Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock, as City hopes to agree on a compensation package. Manager Manuel Pellegrini is looking to build for the future by acquiring the young talent.

A 33-year-old Mexican national, Vanessa Santillan, who worked as a transgender escort, was found dead at the end of March in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, southwest London. She died from injuries to her head and neck, having been strangled and beaten. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been released on bail pending further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan on the days leading up to her death to come forward. According to her website, she worked in London, Paris, and Miami and described herself as visiting from Miami in search of "upscale" gentlemen. In the weeks before her death, she expressed her love for London and Paris on social media.

Dawn, a woman who suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on *The Jeremy Kyle Show* to confront her housemate and longtime friend, Jamie, over the theft of £207. She and her partner, also named Jamie, had been saving this money toward a £500 headstone for their buried child, Daniel James—the only one of her miscarried babies she was able to bury. Suspecting that housemate Jamie and his girlfriend Carol were responsible, Dawn requested a lie detector test on the show. The test revealed that Jamie had indeed stolen the money. During the journey to the show, Jamie sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to the theft, declaring his love for her, and blaming Carol. Upon learning the truth, Dawn was devastated, feeling betrayed by someone she had trusted. She expressed her deep hurt, stating that the headstone was a final gesture of love for her son, and lamented how her goodwill had been repaid with betrayal.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidi captives in northern Iraq on Wednesday, according to officials. Most of those freed were women, children, the elderly, or the ill. The release was coordinated with Arab tribal leaders, though the exact motives remain unclear. The freed individuals were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil.

The Yazidis, a Kurdish-descended minority whose religion incorporates elements of Christianity, Judaism, and Zoroastrianism, have long faced persecution, often labeled as devil worshipers by some Muslims. Last summer, ISIS overtook Yazidi towns in northern Iraq, leading to mass killings, kidnappings, and a significant humanitarian crisis. Thousands fled to the mountains of Sinjar, where many were trapped without food or water, while others escaped on foot to neighboring Syria. Reports emerged of ISIS committing widespread atrocities against the Yazidis, including rape and enslavement of women.

In response to the crisis, an international coalition initiated humanitarian aid drops, rescues, and, starting in August, airstrikes targeting ISIS positions in Iraq and Syria. The U.S. State Department estimates that approximately 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, comprising less than 1% of the country's population.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham Hotspur striker known for his animated celebrations on the pitch, is now featured in an animation off it as well. Having broken into both Tottenham's first team and Roy Hodgson's England squad during a remarkable season, Kane is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new video produced by Copa90 showcases some of his best goals and celebrations using layered still photographs to create an animated effect. Titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?", the animation includes his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and the moment he scored on his England debut. Released ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday, where Kane competes with Chelsea's Eden Hazard and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez for the top prize, the video highlights his impressive achievement of reaching 20 Premier League goals, including scoring past Newcastle's Tim Krul.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers remains the right man to lead Liverpool forward despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Speaking after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, Carragher acknowledged the difficulties with new players not yet bedding in but expressed confidence that Rodgers, the players, and the staff will aim to win a trophy and regain a top-four position next season. He emphasized the importance of making the right signings to improve the team. Carragher's 23 Foundation provides coaching in eight schools in deprived areas of Merseyside, and he hopes to inspire youngsters to achieve their goals, giving back to the community that supported him.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated by security officers at East Midlands Airport before a flight to Lanzarote. The brightly colored toy, which fires sponge darts, was packed in his hand luggage and detected by X-ray machines. Security staff deemed it a security risk, performed a thorough pat-down of James, and confiscated the toy. His father, Phil Hayward, a software engineer, criticized the checks as "ludicrous" and the staff as "over-zealous." East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience, noting they had offered to post the toy back to the family's home in Doncaster. They defended their decision by citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items, including "replica or model guns," from being carried in hand luggage.

A 31-year-old man identified as "Rich" from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife with specific qualities. He offers accommodation and mentions that the position may include a company car, phone, and laptop for the "successful candidate." Rich prefers a non-drinker and non-smoker—acknowledging he's "dreamin"—who is fit and attractive. The successful applicant will receive a free gym membership and a phone of their choice. He desires someone who is reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, handy, a good cook, and "great in bed." The ideal partner should enjoy the outdoors but also be "a princess when need to be."

Rich describes himself as white, athletic build, heavily tattooed, with brown hair and eyes. He is 175 cm tall, "well endowed," does not drink, smoke, or use drugs, and enjoys traveling, outdoor activities, sports, fishing, and camping. He owns properties, makes "great money," loves cars and bikes, and is very independent. Rich states he is "not shy of blowin cash on my woman," promising that his partner would "receive lots of benefits." He invites all reasonable offers and specifies that former partners need not apply. Attempts by Daily Mail Australia to contact him were unsuccessful.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is proposing significant changes to boost the number of home-grown players in English football. He aims to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve and redefine "home-grown" as players trained in England for three years before the age of 18, instead of 21. Despite opposition from the Premier League, Dyke has received backing from five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. In a letter addressed to Dyke, they warn that blocking these proposals could harm the future of English football and hinder England's chances of winning major tournaments. They highlight the declining presence of English players in the Premier League—only 36.8% of starters were eligible for England selection in the last round of matches. While acknowledging their own part in past failures, they emphasize the need to provide more opportunities for emerging talents like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane. The former managers urge the football community to support Dyke's proposals to prevent England from falling further behind other leading football nations.

In the upcoming episode of "Poldark," viewers will witness a swift progression in Demelza's pregnancy. Despite barely showing last week, Demelza, portrayed by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to a baby daughter within the first ten minutes, with little acknowledgment of the passing months. Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, lovingly gazes at their newborn, signaling his deepening affection for Demelza—whom he initially married out of duty but now admits makes him a better man. Fans have noted the show's rapid pregnancy timelines, humorously commenting on social media about how pregnancies reach full term between episodes, as previously seen with the character Elizabeth. While Ross remains a heartthrob to many admirers, his strengthened relationship with Demelza suggests his heart is firmly committed.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to remain focused on their own performances and not be distracted by their relegation rivals as they battle for Premier League survival. Despite being at the bottom of the table, back-to-back victories, including a 3-2 win over West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner, have brought them within three points of safety. Pearson emphasizes that their future is in their own hands and cautions against over-optimism, insisting that they must concentrate on their remaining games to give themselves a realistic chance of staying up.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, set a new record for the longest migration ever recorded for a mammal by swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers). She journeyed from her feeding grounds near Russia's Sakhalin Island, crossed the Pacific Ocean, and traveled down the West Coast of the United States to Baja, Mexico. This feat surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale that migrated 10,190 miles. Scientists, including Bruce Mate from Oregon State University, were surprised to find that Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales. This unexpected behavior suggests that Varvara may actually be an eastern gray whale rather than a western gray whale as previously thought. The discovery has significant implications for the estimated population of western gray whales, which could be even lower than the believed 150 individuals, and indicates a need to reevaluate the genetic distinctions between eastern and western gray whale populations.

Residents of Japan's Hokkaido Island witnessed an unexpected change when a 1,000-foot stretch of seabed surfaced overnight along the Shiretoko Peninsula near the town of Rausu. The new landmass rose as high as 50 feet above sea level in some areas, revealing what was once the ocean floor with marine life like seaweed and sea urchins still attached. Geologists attribute this phenomenon to a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, which caused a section of land to drop and pivot the underwater area upward. Locals reported no sounds or tremors during the event, and authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further. Officials noted that this occurrence is different from an earthquake and is not connected to the recent 7.8-magnitude quake in Nepal.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims that he intends to leave Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, reaffirming his love for the club, the city, and his teammates. Despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea, he insists he is happy at PSG and wants to sign a new contract. Van der Wiel stated he is ready to play whenever called upon. Meanwhile, PSG's continued interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves raises questions about Van der Wiel's future with the club.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to terminate his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016, to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, confirmed they are close to finalizing a deal but emphasized that Tevez must first resolve his contract situation with the Italian champions. While Juventus are reluctant to lose their top scorer—Tevez has netted 17 league goals this season—they acknowledge his wish to leave and are seeking potential replacements. Argentina's national team manager, Tata Martino, stated that a move back to Boca Juniors would not affect Tevez's international future, highlighting that continued strong performances are what matter most. Tevez began his professional career at Boca Juniors, and returning to finish his career there aligns with his longstanding intention.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, securing a place in the semi-finals. Overturning a 3-1 deficit from the first leg in Portugal, Bayern led 5-0 at halftime with goals from Thiago Alcântara, Jérôme Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Manager Pep Guardiola tore the left leg of his grey trousers during the excitement of the match, revealing his underwear, and joked afterward about needing new ones. He also removed his suit blazer in the latter stages. Bayern's dominant performance showcased their superiority over a shell-shocked Porto side.

A three-vehicle collision occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale in Brisbane's west, on Wednesday afternoon, involving ten people including four children. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were the first to be airlifted by rescue helicopter to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane. Shortly after, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl suffering from abdominal pain were also flown out. Six others—including an infant and two young girls—were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. Emergency crews freed one person trapped in their vehicle using hydraulic cutting gear. The affected stretch of the highway has been closed with diversions in place south of Fernvale, and police expect it to remain closed for a few hours.

This weekend, Arsenal, currently second in the Premier League, will host league leaders Chelsea in a crucial match at the Emirates Stadium. Arsenal's playmaker Mesut Özil expressed his excitement for the upcoming game by showcasing his new Apple Watch on Instagram. He compared the gadget to Michael Knight's watch from the classic TV show "Knight Rider," captioning his post: "Excited about my new cool gadget! It's just like Michael Knight's watch, but a real one #knightrider #phone." Özil obtained the watch ahead of its general release on Friday.

Özil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches across all competitions this season, is expected to start in Sunday's encounter. Arsenal trails Chelsea by ten points with six league games remaining but is buoyed by the return of midfielder Jack Wilshere. Wilshere was on the bench during their FA Cup semi-final victory over Reading after spending five months sidelined due to injury.

Club legend Ray Parlour spoke highly of Wilshere, asserting that he is the future of Arsenal if he can maintain his fitness. Parlour highlighted Wilshere's quality and potential impact on the team but expressed concerns over his injury history, drawing parallels with teammate Abou Diaby's struggles to stay fit over the past few years. Wilshere was recently pictured training at London Colney, signaling his readiness to contribute to Arsenal's pivotal end-of-season fixtures.

Referee Mark Clattenburg, regarded as one of the Premier League's leading officials despite past controversies, will preside over the upcoming Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford on Sunday. Although accused of favoring United, Clattenburg has issued only two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. Additionally, he sent off City's captain Vincent Kompany during Belgium's 1-0 victory over Israel in a Euro 2016 qualifier, leading to Kompany's suspension for a future international match. Manchester United have recently overtaken City in the league standings after City's 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace, moving a point ahead and intensifying the significance of the derby, which could determine the runner-up behind leaders Chelsea. While City's form has dipped since the start of the year under Manuel Pellegrini, United are in strong form with five consecutive league wins. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss acting as the fourth official.

Australian MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string" after Gordon faced allegations of domestic violence and admitted to a past criminal record. Katter questioned why it was assumed Gordon would resign from parliament, noting that in similar federal cases, resignation was not expected. His statement sparked criticism on social media due to the terminology used. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent and has faced racism himself, defended his remarks, stating he intended to highlight the racial overtones he perceived in the government's actions. Despite leaving the Queensland Labor Party, Gordon announced he would remain in parliament as an independent, impacting the government's slim majority. Katter vowed that Gordon would not become a puppet for the government, unlike other independents before him.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but refuses to let her disability define her. Facing bullying and frequent stares, she creates enthusiastic dance videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. Through her performances and motivational speaking at local schools, Dayna aims to change how disabilities are represented in media and society, encouraging people to look beyond her condition and see her as just like everyone else. Her message emphasizes that while she might do things differently, she should not be treated differently, and she hopes to inspire others to think before judging.

Orlando City has expressed interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez. The Mexican international, who has struggled during his loan spell at Real Madrid, would be a significant commercial draw for the MLS side due to their large Latin-American fanbase and the presence of captain Kaká. While Orlando made inquiries last week about a potential deal, Hernandez is also attracting interest from eight European clubs. Premier League teams Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton are interested, with Manchester United willing to sell for around £8 million. Additionally, European clubs Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan are keen on the 26-year-old, who has one year left on his contract.

Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira after he rejected their initial proposal. Pereira, who was on the bench against Aston Villa on Saturday, is being courted by several European clubs. Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord have all contacted his father, Marcos, expressing interest in signing the midfielder if he does not agree to terms with United.

Around 12:15 a.m. on Saturday in South Los Angeles, a group of at least three individuals set a car on fire at a 76 gas station. The incident began when the driver of a white Dodge Charger got into an argument with the suspects while pumping gas. According to the driver's grandmother, the suspects attempted to carjack her grandson, brandished a gun, and he fled the scene. The suspects then poured gasoline over the vehicle and ignited it while two passengers were inside. Fortunately, no one was injured, but the car's front end was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance footage from the gas station is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to misconduct, including accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing the charges against him. In an agreement signed last month, Manuel admitted his misdeeds and pledged not to apply for reinstatement for at least ten years. Before resuming practice, he must prove that the circumstances leading to the revocation no longer exist. Despite these issues, Manuel received outstanding patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, achieving a perfect five out of five stars based on three survey responses. He also recommended that patients stop taking medications he had prescribed. Additionally, his practice's address listed on Yelp appears to be a home on a residential street in Lamoni. A woman at his former practice stated that he hadn't worked there for some time, and a woman who answered a call to his home declined to comment.

The United States is formally complaining to Russia after a Russian SU-27 Flanker jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in what the U.S. describes as an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland, with the Russian pilot performing aggressive maneuvers at high speed in close proximity to the U.S. aircraft. Russia's Defense Ministry, via state news agency Sputnik and spokesman Maj. Gen. Igor Konashenkov, claimed the U.S. plane was approaching the Russian border with its transponder turned off, prompting the interception to identify it and obtain its tail number. A U.S. European Command official refuted the claim about the transponder being off. Pentagon spokesman Mark Wright stated that the U.S. will file an official complaint through diplomatic channels. This incident is not isolated; a year prior, a Russian jet flew dangerously close—within 100 feet—of a U.S. RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, leading to a similar complaint. Encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in regions like Northern Europe and the areas between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle was stolen from his car parked at the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City on March 27, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured in a hard case, locked with padlocks and chains to a truck safe. The thief broke the rear right passenger-side window, tied a rope around the rifle case's handle or cable lock, and used the momentum from another vehicle to forcefully rip it free, pulling the window frame from the door. The agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also taken; some items were later found at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains missing. Police discovered skid marks and pieces of rope near the car but are unsure if the agent's vehicle was specifically targeted. The hotel lacked surveillance cameras. The Secret Service was informed of the theft before the president's visit but did not comment on any changes to security measures.

In July 2012, 71-year-old Luigi Costa was accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra. The alleged attack involved stomping on Freebody's head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times in his home on Mugga Way, Red Hill. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa after the incident and testified that Costa's mental state had been deteriorating due to dementia and alcohol abuse leading up to and during the event. Professor Mullen noted evidence such as fluctuating moods during emergency calls made by Costa and a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet, suggesting confusion. He believed that Costa's compromised mental state meant he did not understand his actions or their consequences at the time. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold proposed that Costa might have feigned memory loss during interviews, but Professor Mullen dismissed this, asserting the likelihood of Costa's ongoing demented illness. Costa's mental condition is pivotal to the case, as a proven unstable mindset at the time could lead the jury to return a not guilty verdict.

In Everton's 1-0 win over Burnley at Goodison Park, manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after the midfielder missed a 10th-minute penalty. Despite the presence of Leighton Baines—who has scored 15 of 16 Premier League penalties—Barkley opted to take the spot-kick awarded for a foul on Aaron Lennon. This decision echoed a previous incident in January when Kevin Mirallas took a penalty over Baines and missed. Martinez supported Barkley's choice, emphasizing his approval of multiple players being willing to take penalties based on their confidence at the moment. Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton saved Barkley's well-struck but poorly placed shot. Fortunately for Everton, Mirallas later scored the match's only goal in the 29th minute, securing the victory.

Two passengers aboard the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam were found dead in their stateroom while the ship was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cruise line stated that the guests appear to have died in a murder-suicide. The cabin was immediately secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating the incident. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise. The deceased were discovered by the cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland forward and assistant coach, made a successful debut as the coach of Curaçao's national football team in their World Cup qualifying campaign. Curaçao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup after a 2-2 draw against Montserrat in the second leg, securing a 4-3 aggregate victory. They had previously won the first leg 2-1 in Willemstad. A pivotal moment came when Charlton Vicento, a former Holland Under-21 international, scored in the 87th minute shortly after coming on as a substitute, preventing the match from going into extra time. Curaçao is set to face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curaçao, was a World Cup semi-finalist as a player in 1998 and served as an assistant coach to Louis van Gaal during the 2014 World Cup.
