Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds related to the transfer; he is under investigation but denies any wrongdoing. Although Barcelona initially stated the transfer cost was €57 million (£48.6 million), it is alleged that the actual cost is higher when all contracts are considered. A Spanish judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer. The club denies any tax-related crimes but has made a supplementary tax payment of €13,550,830.56 to address any differing interpretations of their fiscal obligations, stating confidence that their original tax payment was appropriate. There has been no confirmation whether the case will be dropped following this payment. On the field, Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three goals in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

Twenty-seven-year-old Nottingham resident Michael Luciw died when a van he was in was hit by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way on a motorway by elderly driver Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died in the crash. Luciw's family is calling for retired people to undergo regular driving tests, expressing concerns about slowed reactions with age and advocating for measures to prevent similar incidents. Andy Harrington, the van's driver who sustained serious injuries, supports the call for medical examinations for older drivers, suggesting that stricter regulations could have prevented the accident. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must renew their licenses every three years via a self-assessment form without a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has no plans to impose age-based restrictions, stating there's no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK's charity director emphasized the importance of supporting older people to drive safely for as long as possible to maintain their independence.

Many women in Scotland have suffered debilitating side effects from transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, raising concerns about the safety of the devices. Two patients involved in an independent review of the implants, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigned in protest, alleging that the final report was "watered-down" and that parts had been removed. Professor Alison Britton, an expert in healthcare and medical law from Glasgow Caledonian University, has been appointed to examine the process by which the review reached its conclusions.

The report recommended that mesh procedures should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse, advising instead that patients be offered a range of treatments and provided with information to make informed choices. It also called for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls from campaigners for an outright ban, Health Secretary Shona Robison confirmed that the Scottish government would continue to implement the report's recommendations but stated that the authority to ban the procedures lies with the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency.

The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for not being able to achieve consensus among all panel members, describing her task as "almost mission impossible." Her testimony before Holyrood's public petitions committee was met with interruptions from affected women in the public gallery. Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh or tape implants, with some experiencing painful and debilitating complications. Currently, over 400 women are pursuing legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers related to mesh implant surgery.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5000m record by 14 seconds, recording a time of 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. Initially, McColgan expressed concerns about the race meeting all UK Athletics criteria for record-breaking attempts, noting that Muir was the only competitor to complete the 5K distance in a mixed race where others ran 3K, and questioned whether drug testing protocols were in place. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time is expected to be officially ratified, stating that if there is no doping control at the event, athletes are not required to submit drug tests.

McColgan praised Muir's performance, acknowledging her potential to run even faster—possibly down to 14 minutes and 30 seconds—which would position her among the world’s elite. She compared Muir's solo effort to her own record-setting run 25 years earlier, where she lapped competitors, including a young Paula Radcliffe. McColgan expressed excitement that her record was broken by a fellow Scot and highlighted Muir's world-class status, emphasizing that with refined race tactics, Muir could begin winning major medals. Prior to this achievement, Muir had broken her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris and reached the 1500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung secured the gold medal in equestrian eventing aboard Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou after the latter contracted an infection in July. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, while American Phillip Dutton earned bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th; the 47-year-old was competing just 10 months after recovering from an induced coma following a fall. Despite leading after the dressage phase, Fox-Pitt's medal hopes were dashed due to time penalties in the cross-country phase, dropping him to 21st before a flawless performance in the final show-jumping phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray advanced to the fourth round at Wimbledon after defeating Italy's Fabio Fognini in a tense four-set match lasting two hours and 39 minutes. Murray won 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5, clinching match point at 20:57 BST. Despite trailing 5-2 in the fourth set and facing five set points that could have forced a fifth set, Murray rallied to win five consecutive games. The match featured high drama, including Fognini receiving a point penalty for a visible obscenity and Murray expressing concern about the fading light potentially causing a suspension of play. With this victory, Murray reached the last 16 at Wimbledon for the 11th time and is set to face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the next round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also progressed, reaching the second week for the first time with a win over Maria Sakkari of Greece.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics were called at 6:00 AM to Joe's Bar in Dungiven due to a sudden death. Police arrived shortly afterward and found several people still present at the bar. Till receipts showed that alcohol had been served as late as 4:49 AM, beyond the legal licensing hours. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, of Kevin Lynch Park—the license holder—was charged with two counts of allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours and fined £3,000. James Thomas, 44, from the same address, faced one count of the same charge and was fined £1,000. The judge described Ms. O'Neill's record as "appalling" and expressed concern over not having the power to impose a custodial sentence, stating, "This was as bad a case as I have come across."

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP), reaffirmed his stance on vote transfers to the Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP), stating he prefers forming a partnership with them over Sinn Féin. Despite senior party colleague Danny Kennedy distancing himself from these remarks, Nesbitt expressed no regrets and emphasized that he "wouldn't withdraw a word" of what he said. He highlighted that domination doesn't work and that partnership does, aiming to shift the election focus onto how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled. The UUP's manifesto, titled **"Real Partnership,"** calls for action on tackling waiting lists, increasing Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) numbers to 7,500, prioritizing the York Street interchange project, standing up for the LGBT community, and guaranteeing that no group is worse off because of Brexit. Nesbitt acknowledged differing views within his party on vote transfers but remained confident in his position, hoping his message about addressing "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and the strong whiff of corruption" will resonate with voters more than the controversy over his remarks.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will go before the Northern Ireland Assembly seeking approval to pardon men convicted under now-abolished sexual offence laws. This initiative aims to align Northern Ireland with England and Wales, where plans for automatic pardons—dubbed "Turing's Law" after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing—were announced the previous month. The proposed motion includes provisions for both posthumous pardons and allows living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons. Ms Sugden has secured executive agreement to request the assembly's passage of a legislative consent motion to pardon these convictions, emphasizing swift arrangements to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland. She stated that this step is an opportunity for the criminal justice system to "right the wrongs of the past" and offers a quicker resolution than an assembly bill. The motion will now proceed to consideration by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old athlete from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the mile run with a time of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This performance broke Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60 and moved Muir to second place on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m record and finished fifth in last year's World Championships, expressed her delight at the achievement. Balancing her athletics with her veterinary studies—having recently completed her fourth year of vet school—she aims to secure a spot for Great Britain in the Rio Olympics at the upcoming British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June. Muir began her season with an 800m victory in Montbéliard, France, and is set to compete next in a 1500m race in Stockholm.
The passage showcases some of your pictures from the 26 beaches that have been ranked as Scotland's "most excellent" for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that while suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, the Russian state was likely the sponsor of his murder due to numerous reasons for wishing him harm. Litvinenko, who defected to the UK in 2000 after accusing the FSB of corruption and political assassinations, was poisoned with a fatal dose of radioactive polonium-210 in London in 2006 after meeting with Kovtun and Lugovoi. He died nearly three weeks later. Horwell emphasized that this does not necessarily implicate President Vladimir Putin personally but highlighted Litvinenko's criticisms of Putin and the potential view of his defection as treachery. The suspects left a "trail of polonium" and have provided no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. Attempts to extradite them have failed, and they remain in Russia. The inquiry into the case was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as Australia's new Test captain following Michael Clarke's retirement after the Ashes defeat to England, which left the hosts with a 3-1 lead. Smith already leads the one-day side and will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain despite a history of disciplinary issues. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith as a "fine young man with extraordinary talent" and expressed confidence in his leadership abilities. Smith previously captained Australia in three Tests against India when Clarke was injured and has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Marsh also noted Warner's maturation and development into an important senior figure, believing he will respond well to his new responsibilities. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval starting on 20 August.

Earlier this week, Mr. Farron refused to directly answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, stating instead that "we are all sinners." Despite this, he emphasized his commitment to LGBT-plus rights and equality. As the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, he stated that defending equal marriage would be at the top of his agenda and expressed a desire to extend marital rights to transgender people. Specifically, he aims to address the "spousal veto," which currently requires a spouse's consent for a marriage to continue after one partner changes gender. When questioned about his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill—a law intended to prevent businesses from discriminating against gay people—Mr. Farron explained that he had concerns about the "protection of individual liberties." Although he did not elaborate on these concerns, he reaffirmed his support for equal legal access for all individuals, regardless of their sexuality.

After French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses, Accord Healthcare is set to reopen the plant for pharmaceutical production, potentially rehiring former Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to have an "extremely positive" impact on the area, boosting the local economy and strengthening Newcastle and the North East's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Local officials, including Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes, praised the move. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to about 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis is leaving his position at the local authority on Friday as his contract ends. Alongside him, Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, commented that these departures indicate the council's inability to retain senior staff and anticipates further exits in the coming months. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude to the trio for their "dedication and professionalism."

English rider Martin crashed at this year's TT due to mechanical problems with the Fireblade bike. Although he told MCN he was quitting road racing, he later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing but has no plans to do more road racing on Hondas this year. Martin didn't race at the North West 200 after his teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a disaster and felt he was merely a test rider because the bike was uncompetitive. After further testing at Cadwell, he informed the team that the bike wouldn't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix. The team decided to withdraw him from the event without notifying him, which he accepted. Martin stated there's no unfinished business and expressed interest in racing classics and unusual events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) achieved a significant victory in Nigeria's recent elections, winning 19 of the 28 contested governorships. This marks the most substantial defeat for the People's Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's leader, Muhammadu Buhari, who previously defeated President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential election, is set to be inaugurated on May 29.

The PDP lost control of key northern states, including Katsina and Kaduna—the home state of outgoing Vice-President Namadi Sambo—and Adamawa, which has been severely affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP retained Rivers State, an important oil-producing area. Overall, the PDP secured eight governorships, mainly in the southeast.

Analysts note that the APC's gains have transformed the political landscape, relegating the PDP to a regional party with strength primarily in the southeast and the Niger Delta. The APC now controls most northern states and Lagos, the commercial hub in the southwest. Despite these gains, the APC did not win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose challenges for President-elect Buhari, as militants in these regions might disrupt oil production and reduce crucial federal revenue.

The elections were marred by some violence due to intense rivalry, ethnic tensions, and the high stakes of power and resource control. Notably, incidents occurred in Rivers and other southern states, leading to extended voting times in some areas. Despite these issues, the elections were generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating progress in Nigeria's democratic maturity.

Nigeria's governors hold significant power, often controlling budgets larger than those of neighboring countries' national governments, especially in oil-rich states. The PDP faces a period of introspection and rebuilding under new leadership after 16 years in power. The party's decline was exacerbated by defections to the APC and widespread allegations of corruption and ineffective response to the Islamist insurgency in the northeast, where it suffered considerable defeats.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, has accused Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, state-owned investment company Temasek, of contributing to unsustainable palm oil practices that lead to environmental damage, including the haze affecting Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia. Mighty alleges that Olam purchases 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, creating a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" by sourcing from unknown producers who may engage in illegal slash-and-burn methods. They also claim Olam is involved in deforestation in Gabon by clearing rainforests for monoculture palm oil plantations.

Both Olam and Temasek reject these allegations. Olam's CEO, Sunny Verghese, states that the company has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and is committed to responsible sourcing, having recently released the names of its 14 suppliers. He acknowledges that vetting suppliers thoroughly will take several years and assures that non-compliant producers will be removed from their supply chain. Temasek emphasizes that it supports no-burn policies but does not direct the operations of its portfolio companies.

The situation highlights ongoing tensions in the global palm oil industry, which, despite being a major economic player projected to be worth $88 billion by 2022, faces criticism for environmental degradation and labor issues. Activists urge stricter government enforcement against non-compliant palm oil firms, while industry executives argue that monitoring third-party suppliers is challenging. Olam maintains that its operations in Gabon are responsible and transparent, aligning with the country's right to develop agricultural land sustainably.
Following the introduction of a new law permitting dogs to dine at outdoor restaurant areas, a restaurant began serving "puppy platters." It looks like a right dog's dinner—check out this clip.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury, having only come off the bench in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a recall after scoring a late equalizer as a substitute against the Terriers.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) announced that the ban was no longer necessary because Google provided a process for the PTA to request the blocking of access to offending material directly. However, YouTube stated that government requests for content removal would not be automatically granted and would undergo a thorough review in line with its community guidelines. Activists in Pakistan are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms agreed upon between Google and the government. The original ban was imposed in 2012 after the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded, which led to widespread protests and the deaths of more than a dozen people in Pakistan. Additionally, Google has launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss-Italian head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, shares nationality with Gianni Infantino, one of the five candidates in the upcoming FIFA presidential election scheduled for 26 February in Zurich. Liberian Football Association boss Musa Bility has called for Scala to step down, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which states that any committee member with a conflict of interest must be replaced. Bility argues that sharing nationality with a candidate constitutes such a conflict and has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw within three working days.

In the 2015 elections, Scala and fellow committee member Claudio Sulser, both Swiss nationals, voluntarily withdrew to avoid any appearance of conflict of interest when Swiss incumbent President Sepp Blatter was a candidate. However, Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, countered that shared nationality does not constitute a conflict of interest under FIFA regulations. He explained that Scala's previous withdrawal was a precautionary measure due to Blatter's incumbency, and with no incumbent president in the current election, there is no conflict.

Bility, who was denied participation in the election after failing an eligibility check in November, emphasized the importance of fairness and integrity in FIFA's electoral process, especially after recent turmoil within the organization. He has pledged his vote to Prince Ali of Jordan and is urging other African nations to do the same. The other candidates vying to replace Sepp Blatter are Frenchman Jérôme Champagne, Sheikh Salman of Bahrain, South African Tokyo Sexwale, and Gianni Infantino. The election will be decided by votes from FIFA's 209 member associations.

Two workers, 29-year-old Daniel Timbers and 56-year-old Barry Joy, were killed shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, a company that manufactures buckets for diggers. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon following a forensic search. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Durham reported significant progress in forensic inquiries and witness statements, indicating that a flashover explosion occurred due to a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, resulting in a fireball effect. The Health and Safety Executive stated that inspectors and electrical safety experts are gathering evidence.

Tunisia and Morocco overcame disputes with the Confederation of African Football (Caf) to participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers. Tunisia faced expulsion after protesting a controversial penalty awarded to Equatorial Guinea in their 2015 quarter-final match, leading to a heated letter to Caf. The issue was resolved after Tunisia's Football Federation apologized following discussions with Caf President Issa Hayatou. Meanwhile, Morocco was initially banned and fined by Caf for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns but successfully appealed the decision at the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which overturned the ban and reduced the fine. Both nations are now preparing for the qualifiers: Tunisia will play against Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and São Tomé in Group F. If Tunisia reaches the 2017 finals in Gabon, it will mark their thirteenth consecutive appearance, setting a new record.

In a match at Etihad Stadium that Chelsea won 3-1, a mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute. Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz—his second dismissal for violent conduct this season. Fernandinho clashed with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas in the ensuing scuffle and will serve a three-match ban. While Fabregas will not face further action, City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales and parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. To address this issue, a pilot scheme in the Cynon Valley and Neath is focusing on patients whose GPs suspect cancer but who do not show urgent signs or symptoms. This initiative follows a visit by Welsh doctors to Denmark, where they observed diagnostic systems that improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that patients without clear symptoms wait too long for a diagnosis because they don't fit into specific treatment pathways, leading to delays as they undergo multiple tests over several weeks. The pilot allows 40 doctors in the Cynon Valley to refer such patients to a diagnostic centre at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days. An estimated six patients per week will be seen and tested, ideally on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms receive a diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. Doctors aim to diagnose patients with less obvious symptoms earlier. A similar clinic will be established at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another trial. If the six-month Cynon Valley pilot is successful, other health boards will offer the same service in the following months.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the four-match series. They declared their innings twice, scoring 589-8 and 173-1, marking their second-largest victory over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket in his only over. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance as "as good an innings as I've seen." Commentators Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott highlighted England's dominant display, with Boycott doubting Pakistan's ability to make a comeback. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged the team's disappointing performance but remained hopeful they would work hard to improve. The teams will play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston begins on 3 August.

With head coach Warren Gatland leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and naming Rob Howley as part of his backroom team, forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, having previously led tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed his honor and excitement at leading the team again at the end of the season. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde, with WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips indicating that discussions are at an advanced stage and the full management team will be confirmed next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies, also on the Lions' selection panel, believes that the involvement of Welsh coaches in different environments will benefit Welsh rugby in the years ahead, providing valuable opportunities to develop and inspire both coaches and players.

In a Premier League match at the KCOM Stadium, Hull City overcame an early deficit to defeat Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. Southampton took the lead in the sixth minute when Charlie Austin scored a penalty after Curtis Davies fouled Maya Yoshida. Hull faced additional challenges as starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane left the game in the first half due to injuries.

Robert Snodgrass, returning from an ankle injury, entered as a substitute for Keane and revitalized Hull's attack. In the 61st minute, Snodgrass equalized with his fourth league goal of the season, finishing Sam Clucas's low cross. Just two minutes later, Snodgrass delivered a free-kick that Michael Dawson headed past goalkeeper Fraser Forster to give Hull the lead.

Despite Southampton's efforts to find an equalizer—including several attempts saved by Hull goalkeeper David Marshall and a last-minute goal-line clearance by Sam Clucas—Hull held on for the victory. Manager Mike Phelan praised his team's resilience and highlighted the performances of Marshall and Snodgrass. Southampton's manager, Claude Puel, attributed the loss to a lack of concentration following their Europa League win over Inter Milan.

The victory provided a much-needed boost for Hull City, who remain in the relegation zone but gained confidence heading into the international break. Southampton missed an opportunity to capitalize on their early lead and will look to rebound in their upcoming match against Liverpool.

A motorcyclist from the local area was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at about 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses to the incident to come forward. Following the crash, the B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

Macedonian President Ivanov canceled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. His decision was condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and urged protests in the capital, Skopje, where hundreds gathered outside the prosecutor's office. EU officials, including Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, criticized Ivanov's actions as inconsistent with the rule of law and warned that it could jeopardize Macedonia's EU membership ambitions. The crisis began in 2015 when Zaev started releasing covert recordings alleging government corruption, including wiretapping 20,000 people, mismanagement of funds, dubious prosecutions, and cover-ups of killings. The government denies these accusations and accuses Zaev of attempting to destabilize the nation, a claim he rejects.

Alan Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea City in their upcoming match against Bournemouth following the dismissal of Bob Bradley. The club is eager to appoint a new manager promptly, with former Derby manager Paul Clement as their top choice. Curtis stresses the need for someone who can steer the team out of trouble, acknowledging the real possibility of relegation and the challenges of returning to the Premier League from the increasingly competitive Championship. He reflects on the club's rise from near bankruptcy in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, attributing past successes to stable management under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup. Curtis believes frequent managerial changes have diluted the "Swansea Way" and questions whether departed players have been adequately replaced. Despite these concerns, he maintains that the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation. Curtis makes a point of educating new signings about the club's history, often through the documentary "Jack to a King," to instill a sense of purpose and underscore the importance of remaining in the top flight not only for the club but for the entire community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, ending their nine-year tenure in the Football League. The Daggers needed a win to maintain their slim hopes of survival. Leyton Orient's Jay Simpson scored twice to give the O's a 2-0 lead, but Dagenham fought back with goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona to level the match. However, Armand Gnanduillet's winning goal ensured Orient's victory, keeping their play-off aspirations alive.

Under manager John Still—who previously guided Dagenham from the National League to League One—the team struggled throughout the season. They recorded the worst goal difference in League Two, conceding 20 more goals than at the same point in the previous season. Veteran striker Jamie Cureton, 40, scored nine goals, a drop from the 20 he netted in the 2014-15 campaign when the team finished 14th.

Leyton Orient, now two points shy of the play-off spots, secured the win shortly after the removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan from his managerial role. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler expressed the challenges of losing two managers in a season but emphasized professionalism and the importance of winning games for the fans. John Still acknowledged his team's lack of organization and discipline, attributing their relegation to an inability to respond effectively throughout the season. Despite the setback, Still remains committed to helping Dagenham gain promotion from the National League next season.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, aged 36, is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp expressed enthusiasm for Gerrard's appointment, calling it "wonderful news" and noting that Gerrard aspires to become a manager in the future. Klopp emphasized the importance of Gerrard gaining experience, combining his playing background with managerial skills he aims to develop. Gerrard made his debut for Liverpool in 1998 and left at the end of the 2014-15 season to join MLS side LA Galaxy. During his time at Liverpool, he won the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup, and the League Cup three times. After being linked to the managerial position at League One side MK Dons—a role he felt came "too soon"—Gerrard is now working towards his UEFA A coaching licence, required for managing in the Premier League.

Morton secured a comfortable home victory over Alloa. McManus opened the scoring at the 15-minute mark, and Ross Forbes quickly doubled Morton's lead with a deflected strike. Kyle McAusland pulled one back for Alloa before half-time. In the second half, McManus scored again, and Denny Johnstone added a late goal to ensure the win for Morton.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in squalid and unsafe conditions in three places in Birmingham, which have now been closed. Operators of illegal schools could face jail terms of up to 51 weeks. Ministers are considering stricter regulations for educational settings that teach more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, reported that inspectors were visibly shocked by the conditions and believes these cases are just the "tip of the iceberg," expressing serious concerns about risks of abuse or radicalization.

A total of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated recently. While some part-time education centers legally support home-educated children, officials are worried that others are exploiting home education rights to operate illegal schools. Sir Michael criticized officials for being slow to act and providing confusing advice to proprietors.

The government has funded a team of six inspectors dedicated to investigating illegal schools. Inspections will apply to all religious groups, including Muslim, Jewish, and Christian communities. The Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools, stating that it is unacceptable for a child to spend even a single day in such institutions. Government consultation on further regulation is ongoing and will run until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is a new distillery based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes aims to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence" by producing gin on a small scale; their still, one of the smallest in the UK, fits into a cowshed. They utilize the rich abundance of wild food from the Teviot valley to capture the local flavor palette and the Borders "terroir." John Henderson of Born in the Borders considers the gin distillery a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery onsite, appreciating their commitment to local sourcing with Borders botanicals. The gin is named after Lilliard, the legendary heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, reflecting both the local landscape and their strong female production team.

In August 2013, at Swithens Farm in Rothwell near Leeds, **Harry Whitlam** died after **Gary Green**, 51, of Bradburn Road, Wakefield, reversed a vehicle into him. **Leeds Crown Court** heard that Green was more than twice the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. Harry's mother, **Pam Whitlam**, who worked at the farm's cafe, stated that her close-knit family had been "changed forever" and emphasized that it is unacceptable for anyone, whether on public roads or private land, to drive while intoxicated.

Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law because the incident occurred on private land. He was jailed for **16 months and two weeks** after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. An investigation by the **Health and Safety Executive (HSE)** found that Harry had been walking towards a worker in a closed-off area of the farm when Green backed the tractor into him around 09:15 on 9 August. HSE inspector **Julian Franklin** described the case as "an extremely tragic case" and called Green's behavior "reckless."

Uruguayan striker Luis Suarez's four-month ban from all football-related activities has been partially reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). While the ban on playing in competitive matches remains, Suarez is now permitted to train with his new club, Barcelona, and participate in friendly matches. Barcelona announced that he will join the first team's training session on Friday and will be officially presented at the Camp Nou on Monday. It is uncertain if he will play in the upcoming friendly against Mexico's Club Leon.

The CAS upheld Suarez's nine-match international ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during a 2014 World Cup match but deemed the complete prohibition from all football activities "excessive." Suarez's legal team argued that FIFA's initial punishment was too harsh. World players' union FIFPro expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not further reduced and suggested that treatment should have been part of the decision.

Suarez will remain unavailable for competitive matches until late October, with a possible debut for Barcelona against Real Madrid in El Clasico. He is eligible to play in Uruguay's forthcoming friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. Previously, Suarez faced suspensions for similar biting incidents involving players Otman Bakkal and Branislav Ivanovic and was banned in 2011 for racially abusing Patrice Evra.

On 18 March 2014, Richard "Rich" Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a challenging race, defeating Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. Rich attributed their success to a week of dedicated training, stating, "We put in a whole week's work, running around the athletics track near where we live—and it's paid off." The race featured a 380-metre course with obstacles such as haystack hurdles, a steep slope, and participants had to dodge water pistols. Competitors did not need to be married to participate, and the event included various pairings: men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman. Following their victory, Rich and Anna are set to compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond announced that job roles at the DVLA would change when the paper car tax disc system is scrapped in October 2014. In a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, the minister reassured that there would be no job losses, and any reductions in staff needed for certain activities would be managed through redeployment to other areas of the business. Concerns had been raised about the future of some of the 5,000 DVLA workers after Chancellor George Osborne's Autumn Statement, which introduced an electronic system for car tax, allowing monthly direct debit payments. Mr Hedges welcomed the minister's assurances, expressing that, although disappointed by the reduction in job opportunities at the DVLA, he recognized the advantages of the new system and was pleased with the commitment to redeployment rather than redundancies.

Hungary's Foreign Minister, Mr. Szijjarto, stated that the European Union (EU) should not interfere with Hungary's domestic matters and confirmed that Poland would veto any EU move to strip Hungary of its voting rights. The EU objects to Hungary's strict controls on asylum seekers, new legislation affecting non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and a higher education law that critics fear could lead to the closure of the Central European University (CEU), founded by George Soros. Despite protests from thousands of Hungarians and pressure from European institutions to withdraw these laws, Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban's right-wing Fidesz party, insists it will not backtrack, asserting that these issues fall under national competence. Hungary is currently housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers, raising legal concerns within the EU. Additionally, proposed NGO legislation may label such organizations as "foreign-backed," which human rights groups argue is stigmatizing. EU Commission Deputy Head Frans Timmermans warned that action would be taken if there are no positive developments, but any sanctions would require unanimous approval from EU member states, and Poland has pledged to support Hungary.

The passage announces casting updates for the upcoming live-action "Beauty and the Beast" film, set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. A star will portray Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper transformed into a teapot, a role originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Oscar-winner Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as the villainous Gaston. Josh Gad joins the cast as LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Directed by Bill Condon, known for "Dreamgirls" and the last two "Twilight" films, production begins at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist and writer for *The Sunday Times* since 1993, has died after being diagnosed with what he described as the "full English" of cancers. Despite undergoing chemotherapy, he maintained that he did not "feel cheated" and considered himself "very lucky" in life. Gill was celebrated by colleagues as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper, known for his incomparable wit, dazzling and fearless writing, and a style recognized purely from his prose. Tributes from fellow writers and editors highlighted his brilliance and compassion, even as they acknowledged his penchant for controversy.

Gill's career was marked by provocative articles that stirred public debate. Notable controversies included his description of the Welsh as "dark, ugly little trolls," his admission of shooting a baboon in Tanzania, and various scathing remarks about places like Rhyl, Norfolk, and the Isle of Man. In 2010, he was censured for referring to broadcaster Clare Balding as a "dyke on a bike."

Overcoming dyslexia, Gill dictated his writings and became a published author and respected critic. His personal life saw marriages to author Cressida Connolly and later to Amber Rudd, now the Home Secretary, with whom he had two children. Prior to his death, his illness prompted him to become engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins. Gill often affectionately referred to Formby as "The Blonde" in his restaurant reviews. His final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, is scheduled to appear in the upcoming edition of *The Sunday Times*.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, known as Amraa and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai (Black Rose), was allegedly assaulted during a performance in Ulan Bator. He was reportedly hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, resulting in serious brain injuries and a coma lasting about ten days. The alleged attacker is a Russian diplomatic officer who has not been identified. The Russian embassy stated it is investigating the incident but described local press reports as "distorted," particularly regarding the details of the event.

The incident occurred after Sukhbaatar performed wearing a red *deel*—a traditional Mongolian robe—embroidered with a swastika. While the swastika is commonly associated with Nazism, in Mongolia it is a traditional symbol of eternity that predates the Third Reich by centuries. Sukhbaatar and his representatives emphasized that the symbol is not a hate symbol in Mongolia and denied social media claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance.

Mongolian authorities are investigating the case. A police spokesman noted that the suspect was not detained because the injuries were not considered serious and denied that diplomatic immunity was the reason for the lack of detention. Sukhbaatar's lawyer insisted that the suspect should be investigated under Mongolian law regardless of diplomatic status.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a protest on the airport's northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, opposing the airport's expansion plans. The men and women involved have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area of an aerodrome; they are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. Following the incident, the Metropolitan Police stated that security at the airport would be reviewed.

In a county cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire, Glamorgan's total of 220 was dominated by opener Nick Selman's resilient 101 off 144 balls—his second first-class century. After being dropped on eight in the first over, Selman anchored the innings despite wickets falling regularly due to effective bowling by Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles in cloudy conditions in Cardiff. Aneurin Donald contributed a swift 36 off 30 balls, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten added late runs to secure a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire's batsmen also faced challenging conditions, with the day ending evenly balanced as bowlers remained on top. Glamorgan was led by stand-in captain Michael Hogan, filling in for Jacques Rudolph, who was sidelined with a neck injury. Post-match, Selman expressed relief at returning to form after a series of low scores, acknowledging the difficulties of opening batting in the UK. Taylor reflected on his successful bowling performance and anticipated tough conditions for Gloucestershire's batting lineup but remained hopeful for a reasonable score.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after online communications with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee raised concerns about a planned ambush on police officers. Prosecutors stated that Hughes intended to make false reports to lure officers to the Dee Estuary, where he planned to shoot them. The threats were made on two occasions late at night while he was drunk. Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday and is scheduled for sentencing next week. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody, noting his previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Hughes's legal team asserted that he did not intend to harm himself or carry out the threats against the police. At the time of the threats, North Wales Police were particularly concerned because Hughes was on bail awaiting trial for firearms offences, for which he was later cleared. The Hope Line Crisis Centre provides confidential support and counseling to individuals experiencing difficulties.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 19 runs after recovering from 8-2 to post 255-7, thanks to a pivotal 130-run partnership between Steven Davies and Ben Foakes, who scored 90. Yorkshire's run chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, who dismissed Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance, and Jack Leaning in nine balls. Despite Tim Bresnan's valiant 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the team's collective effort and the game-changing partnership between Davies and Foakes. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment, noting that despite excellent bowling, the lack of significant contributions from their top five batsmen cost them the match.

At 07:00 BST, the crew of a 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack radioed Holyhead coastguards because their onboard pump couldn't manage incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided an additional pump and towed the vessel back to Holyhead.

Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, has announced she will not join the Scotland team at next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, with exams in May conflicting with the Games in April. She recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m. In that event, Hellen Obiri won gold by upsetting defending world champion Almaz Ayana, with Sifan Hassan placing third. Despite being disappointed about missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir is prioritizing her degree but is considering targeting the World Indoor Championships in March. She remains optimistic about her athletic future, believing she has "at least two, even three more Olympics" ahead.

In his BBC Sport column, football pundit Robbie Savage analyzes Liverpool's decline from last season's title challenge, their forthcoming match against Chelsea, and the challenges faced by club captain Steven Gerrard. Savage observes that Liverpool are currently far from the level required to contend for the Premier League title and may struggle to secure a top-four finish. This downturn is partly due to the team overachieving last season, which has led to unrealistic expectations among fans.

Savage critiques manager Brendan Rodgers' transfer decisions, particularly in replacing strikers Luis Suarez and the injured Daniel Sturridge. The current forward options—Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini—are deemed insufficient, lacking both goal-scoring prowess and the high work-rate that characterized Liverpool's attack last season. This deficiency has resulted in a significant drop in early goals and a lack of pressing intensity, leaving the team often chasing games.

Defensive frailties persist despite substantial investments in players like Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren. The back line lacks leadership, and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet's hesitance to command his area exacerbates the issue. Set-piece effectiveness has also declined sharply, removing a crucial source of goals from the previous campaign.

Ahead of the clash with Chelsea, Savage proposes a lineup that includes Kolo Toure over Lovren, citing Toure's solid performance against Real Madrid. He emphasizes the need for disciplined full-backs and a dynamic midfield trio of Adam Lallana, Philippe Coutinho, and Raheem Sterling to challenge Chelsea's robust defense. However, Savage concedes that even with these adjustments, it's difficult to envision Liverpool defeating a Chelsea side that appears superior in all facets of the game.

Addressing Steven Gerrard's situation, Savage acknowledges the psychological and physical hurdles the 34-year-old faces. Despite the infamous slip against Chelsea that marred last season and ongoing speculation about his future, Gerrard remains one of Liverpool's key players. Savage believes Gerrard's experience, skill set, and enduring fitness make him integral to the team's long-term plans. He commends Gerrard's resilience and continued contributions, underscoring his status as one of the Premier League's greatest midfielders.

Overall, Savage's analysis underscores the significant challenges Liverpool face in replicating past successes and the critical decisions required to restore their competitiveness at the highest level.

A £45 million educational facility is planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council intends to seek permission from William McIlvanney's family to name the campus in his honour. McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock, was passionate about providing quality education for young people. After graduating from Glasgow University, he became an English teacher before transitioning to full-time writing in 1975. His debut novel, **"Remedy Is None,"** gained immediate recognition, and he earned the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for works like the acclaimed **Laidlaw trilogy**, **"Docherty,"** and **"The Big Man."** McIlvanney was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster who contributed to Scotland's political and sporting life through columns and TV programs. He passed away at his Glasgow home on December 5.

A British sea mine, believed to date from the 1940s or 1950s, was spotted near the swimming pool in Gourock on Monday, leading to evacuations and safety precautions. An area of the town was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon, affecting three streets, while residents within 500 meters were advised to open windows, stay indoors near walls, and avoid going outside. Exclusion zones were established on the river and at sea—about half a mile offshore—with small boat owners advised not to sail. Ferry services by Caledonian MacBrayne between Gourock and Rothesay experienced disruptions. Officials stated the evacuation was a precautionary measure with no immediate danger to the community. Due to the mine's deterioration and uncertain explosive content, experts decided to move it to a safer location before rendering it safe. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated £345 million to fund 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, which is £2 million less than the £347 million provided for Rio 2016. Despite the investment, several sports including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton have had their funding cut or entirely removed. Badminton, which secured a bronze medal through Marcus Ellis and Chris Langridge in Rio after receiving £5.74 million, has lost all funding. Badminton England's CEO Adrian Christy labeled the decision "incomprehensible" and highlighted its "catastrophic impact" on the sport. In contrast, judo, which also won a bronze medal in Rio, saw a slight increase in funding.

Cycling, despite delivering 12 medals in Rio, has faced a funding reduction of over £4 million, now receiving £25.98 million. UK Sport CEO Liz Nicholl explained that funding decisions prioritize protecting and enhancing medal potential to avoid underperformance at the Games. Sports minister Tracey Crouch supported UK Sport's approach, aiming for a successful medal haul in Tokyo.

Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball, which previously lost funding, criticized UK Sport for not supporting the development of performance pathways despite a review acknowledging the need. With £9 million still unallocated, funding decisions for new Olympic sports added for Tokyo 2020—such as baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sport climbing, and surfing—as well as new Paralympic sports like para-taekwondo and para-badminton, are yet to be confirmed. Liam Carroll, head coach of the GB baseball team, remains hopeful for future investment to unlock the team's potential.

Three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth—the Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View—will be demolished to make way for a new development. The project includes a six-storey, four-star, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks of nine and seven storeys, comprising 122 apartments, located on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive. Despite strong objections from English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society, who argue that the scale of the development will cause "severe harm" to the designated conservation area and diminish its historic character, the council voted seven to three in favor of the plans. Councillor David Kelsey, chair of the planning board, stated that while the buildings are "nice," they are no longer "necessarily functional" and emphasized the need to enhance tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. The council received 246 letters supporting the development and 49 objections from residents concerned about the loss of historic buildings and trees. Kelsey acknowledged that while the loss is "regrettable," progress is necessary for the town's future.

Private Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, serving with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked and killed by 24-year-old Jake Vallely during an off-duty night out in Brecon. Boyd was making his way back to the barracks after training exercises at the infantry battle school when Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon," assaulted him outside The Cellar bar. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching Boyd, beating him until he was unconscious, and then dragging his body away before fleeing the scene. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he had left before the attack occurred. Vallely is scheduled to be sentenced on 8 December. The attack shocked the community, prompting Detective Superintendent David Guiney to urge others to avoid violence. Boyd's family paid tribute to him as a loving, caring individual with a promising career, expressing that Vallely's actions had created an irreplaceable void in their lives.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, has left his position by "mutual agreement" following a significant polling error during the recent election. On election day, voters were initially turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the electoral register. The council apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes to those affected, but residents questioned the fairness of the election results since not everyone was able to vote as intended. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily assume Travers's duties while longer-term arrangements are made. An independent investigation into the error has been launched, with findings to be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee by the end of May. The review will also assess the appropriateness of arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead won 2-1 against Wrexham in a closely contested match. Josh Gillies put Gateshead ahead with a fine free-kick, but Wrexham's Sean Newton equalized before half-time with an equally impressive set-piece. Ryan Bowman secured the victory for Gateshead by heading in Craig Baxter's cross in the second half. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improved performance after the break, noting the quality of the winning goal. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, highlighting his team's recent trend of weaker second-half displays and missed opportunities.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. According to the index, Norway ranks first, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb, in partnership with Airbus, is developing a global broadband network by deploying a constellation of at least 600 satellites, potentially expanding to over 2,000. The goal is to provide broadband internet access to every corner of the globe, with a particular focus on connecting all schools. To achieve this, Airbus is revolutionizing satellite manufacturing by adopting high-volume, low-cost production methods akin to automobile and airplane assembly lines. This approach aims to produce three satellites per shift at a cost of less than a million dollars each.

The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with two additional lines planned for a new factory in Florida. The project entails the most extensive rocket launch campaign in spaceflight history, utilizing over 20 Soyuz rockets to deploy clusters of 32-36 satellites into orbit at an altitude of 1,200 km. OneWeb plans to have nearly 300 satellites operational by the end of 2020 or early 2021, over 600 a year later, and more than 800 by the middle of the decade.

While other companies like SpaceX, Boeing, and ViaSat are pursuing similar mega-constellations, OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage, having already raised $1.7 billion in equity and seeking additional funding to complete the rollout. Registered in the UK's Channel Islands, OneWeb collaborates with the UK Space Agency for licensing and emphasizes its significant economic impact on the UK, including fostering a local ecosystem and advancing regulatory leadership.

Addressing concerns about space debris, OneWeb commits to setting new standards in debris mitigation by de-orbiting its satellites within two years, surpassing the five-year guideline suggested by recent studies. The satellites are equipped with extra hardware to enhance the reliability of the de-orbit process and include adapters that allow for retrieval by a "chase vehicle" if necessary.

Airbus and OneWeb anticipate that their innovative manufacturing methods will disrupt the satellite industry and hope to produce satellites for other companies. However, they acknowledge that while mass production is suitable for certain applications, bespoke, "gold-plated" satellites will remain essential for specialized missions, such as deep-space exploration.

Scottish Deputy First Minister John Swinney criticized the UK government's recent spending review, stating it places "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland's public expenditure. He highlighted that due to cuts imposed since 2010, Scotland's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with a 4.2% reduction occurring between now and 2019-20. Swinney accused Chancellor George Osborne of choosing unnecessary austerity measures, asserting that debt and deficit could have been reduced without such significant cuts. He emphasized that key public services like schools, hospitals, and the police would not be sacrificed, citing achievements such as more police officers, lower crime rates, better schools, tuition-free university education, and a record-level health budget.

In response, a spokesperson for the UK government's Scotland Office stated that the Scottish government would have £390 million more in spending available next year, increasing to £750 million when including its own underspend. They noted that the block grant to Scotland would be nearly £30 billion and suggested that remaining part of the UK is beneficial, especially given current oil prices. The spokesperson urged the Scottish government to focus on utilizing new powers effectively rather than expressing grievances.

Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, challenged Swinney to substantiate his anti-austerity position with concrete actions in the upcoming budget. She called for a long-term financial plan and stated that Scottish Labour would offer a real alternative to austerity, proposing different tax decisions from those of both the Conservatives and the SNP.

Many people with severe disabilities and their carers face challenges when venturing outside due to the lack of suitable toilet facilities. Standard accessible toilets often do not meet the needs of those who require assistance from multiple carers, hoists, or changing benches. "Changing Places" toilets, which offer enhanced features and more space, are recommended for larger public buildings like shopping centres, cinemas, and sports facilities. However, these recommendations are not compulsory, leading to insufficient availability.

Campaigners such as Lorna Fillingham, mother of six-year-old Emily-May, are advocating for changes in building regulations to make the installation of Changing Places toilets mandatory in new large developments. The lack of appropriate facilities forces families to use unsuitable and unhygienic spaces, causing stress and feelings of marginalization. With only 893 Changing Places toilets currently in the UK, there is a significant gap in accessibility.

Architects like Vaila Morrison highlight that without compulsory legislation, recommendations are often overlooked during the design process. Financial and logistical challenges, especially in existing buildings, further hinder the installation of these facilities. However, examples like Arsenal Football Club demonstrate that adapting spaces to include Changing Places toilets is possible and has a positive impact on inclusivity. Campaigners continue to push for mandatory regulations to ensure that public spaces become more accessible for the estimated quarter of a million people who need these facilities.

Italian consumers' organizations have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's. They allege that McDonald's is abusing its dominant market position by forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, and by requiring them to sign longer-than-average contracts that hinder them from switching to competitors. This, they claim, results in poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchised stores compared to those owned directly by the company. McDonald's denies these accusations, stating that its risk-and-reward sharing model has been successful for many years and supports franchisees in operating their businesses. The complaint is supported by unions like the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and the UK's Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union. The European Commission is reviewing the submission and may launch an investigation if it finds the allegations credible. Notably, 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe are owned and operated by franchisees, and in 2014, McDonald's earned $9.27 billion in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide.

Thirteen-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve during what was supposed to be an appendix operation at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. Doctors unexpectedly discovered and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. In response, his family and Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father serves on the pastoral staff, initiated the hashtag #prayforjosh on Facebook and Instagram to seek support and prayers. The hashtag went viral, garnering over 79,000 views and 948 shares on a Facebook update, with people worldwide showing support. A mystery donor erected a large billboard with the phrase #prayforjosh at Holywood playing fields, further amplifying the campaign. Josh's classmates from Bangor Grammar and many others continue to use the global hashtag to support him during his recovery, showcasing widespread community and international solidarity.

The UK Ministry of Defence announced the closure of several military sites in Wales as part of a reorganization of military facilities and regiments. Among them is the historic Brecon Barracks, operational since 1805 and home to troops who fought at Rorke's Drift against the Zulus. Conservative MP Chris Davies of Brecon and Radnorshire condemned the decision as "abhorrent" and plans to fight it by launching a petition. He emphasized the barracks' significant history, its role in every conflict since the early 19th century, and its importance to a town with high unemployment and a thriving military tourism industry. While Brecon Barracks employs about 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel, it is not believed that jobs are immediately at risk. Nearby facilities like the Sennybridge training ground and the infantry school at Dering Lines are not affected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon stated that the reorganization would include establishing a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan in the Vale of Glamorgan. Additionally, Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire is set to close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need to restructure the estate but warned that closing bases could impact livelihoods and create uncertainty for many people.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has warned that, in Brexit negotiations, the UK may need to allow EU-registered fishing vessels access to its waters in exchange for continued tariff-free trade of fish with the EU. Despite fishing communities around the UK having voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU—seeing Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and enhance the nation's fishing industry—the Lords caution that these communities risk being marginalized in broader negotiations.

Fishing constitutes only 0.5% of the UK's GDP and employs about 12,000 fishers, potentially making it a low government priority. However, the committee emphasizes the industry's importance, noting that most commercial fish stocks are shared with EU countries, the majority of UK-caught fish are exported primarily to the EU, and a significant portion of fish consumed in the UK is imported from EU states. Therefore, maintaining market access is crucial for a successful industry.

The report highlights that the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), though criticized by the UK fishing industry for its quotas and equal access principles, includes elements that should be retained post-Brexit, such as basing total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice. There is also concern that leaving the CFP framework could lead to fragmented fisheries management within the UK's constituent nations—England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.

While acknowledging potential risks, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic. Recent increases in allowable catches for species like plaice, haddock, and prawns under the CFP are seen as positive indicators. Bertie Armstrong, chief executive of the Scottish Fishermen's Federation, expressed confidence that Brexit will grant the UK full control over its 200-mile exclusive economic zone, leading to fairer catch opportunities and better sustainable fisheries management, benefiting coastal communities.

In response to the report, a government spokesperson reiterated the aim to secure maximum freedom for British companies to trade within the single market while viewing Brexit as an opportunity to review fisheries management. The goal is to ensure fair access to quotas, sustainable fish stocks, and a healthy marine environment as the UK navigates its future outside the EU.

Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks about extensive U.S. surveillance programs. He disclosed that the National Security Agency (NSA) has large-scale access to personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking information, through a program called Prism. Prism allegedly enables "backdoor" access to servers of major technology companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and others, though these companies deny involvement. The U.S. government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call durations, locations, and phone numbers involved in calls.

Officials like NSA Director Keith Alexander defended the surveillance efforts as essential for national security but provided few details. President Barack Obama stated that achieving 100% security while maintaining 100% privacy and zero inconvenience is impossible. Some experts question the capabilities of Prism, suggesting access may be limited and regulated through legal orders.

Data-protection laws vary by country and typically regulate company use of customer data rather than government access. User data is often stored in the U.S., subjecting it to laws like the Patriot Act and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA), which allow U.S. authorities access with limited transparency, even for non-Americans abroad. European Union officials expressed concern and sought more details from U.S. authorities.

Privacy advocates, such as Privacy International, argue that Prism validates fears of widespread privacy violations, as anyone using popular services could be affected. Snowden stated he acted because he found the extent of surveillance "horrifying" and did not want to live in a world where everything is recorded.

OpenAI is a venture backed by prominent figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Aiming to advance digital intelligence for the collective benefit of humanity, it operates without the constraints of financial obligations. The organization focuses on research with a positive human impact, acknowledging the vast potential benefits of human-level AI as well as the significant risks if it is developed or used improperly. Notably, Elon Musk has described AI as humanity's "biggest existential threat," and Stephen Hawking has warned it could surpass humans by outpacing biological evolution. While some experts consider these risks to be remote, OpenAI emphasizes that AI should be an extension of individual human wills and be broadly and safely distributed. Only a small fraction of the $1 billion pledged will be spent in the next few years.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, has received thousands of Facebook friend requests after carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June. Due to Facebook's limit of 5,000 friends per personal page, he cannot accept all the requests. Accompanied by hundreds of supporters, he walked for nearly half an hour with the torch, assisted by someone supporting his arm. His nomination highlighted that while a brain injury initially took his speech, his personality and sense of humor remained intact, and he now speaks unaided. Ben spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehabilitation, walks with crutches, and dedicates the rest of his time to raising money for military charities, serving as a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, described the public response as phenomenal, noting increased online engagement and support, including over 5,000 friend requests, thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits website, and a surge in email and mail. Facebook suggested that Ben consider creating a public figure page or using the subscribe feature to accommodate the overwhelming interest. The Olympic torch relay involves 8,000 people carrying the flame over an 8,000-mile, 70-day journey to the opening ceremony of the London 2012 Olympic Games on 27 July.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate held steady at 15%, leaving 46.2 million Americans in poverty after three consecutive years of increases. The real median household income declined by 1.5%, and income inequality grew by 1.6% as measured by the Gini index—the first annual rise since 1993. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. Notably, poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who moved from Somerset to Lancashire in 2013, has extended his contract with the club until 2019. A specialist in short-format cricket, Buttler holds England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan last year. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised him as "one of the most talented cricketers in the game" and highlighted his key role in Lancashire's T20 Blast victory at Edgbaston. Buttler has been playing in the Indian Premier League with the Mumbai Indians and will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour and are up for sale. Interested bidders had until 23 January to register, with viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a final decision expected in the spring. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. The government's Disposal Services Authority, managing the sale, intends to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. 

Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, emphasizes the importance of supporting UK recyclers but also advocates for saving at least one ship from the scrapyard. She suggests converting a frigate into a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income, balancing best value for the budget with economic benefits. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers but has not disclosed bid details due to commercial sensitivity.

The Type 22 frigates, initially designed for anti-submarine warfare, evolved into powerful surface combatants with substantial weapon systems and excellent command, control, and communication facilities, making them ideal flagships with a crew of about 280. Previously, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for £3 million.

Since 1987, Fiji has faced significant racial and political tensions that have led to instability and international isolation. A coup by indigenous Fijians in 1987 overthrew an elected, Indian-dominated coalition government, triggering adverse events such as the introduction—and subsequent withdrawal—of a constitution promoting indigenous Fijian political supremacy. In 2000, a coup led by businessman George Speight resulted in the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister, his cabinet, and several MPs being held hostage for several weeks. These events severely harmed Fiji's economy, particularly the tourism industry, and tarnished its international reputation.

Persistent disputes over granting amnesty to those behind the 2000 coup fueled ongoing tensions, culminating in a bloodless military takeover in 2006—the fourth coup in 20 years. In September 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth due to a lack of progress toward democracy, marking only the second full suspension in the organization's history. The government agreed in 2012 to hold free elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and Fiji's reinstatement in the Commonwealth after the elections.

Fiji's population is primarily based on the two main islands, Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, and is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians—the descendants of indentured laborers from India.
