With the help of Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and some volunteers, a compilation of early music videos called "soundies" was shown to her at the nursing home where she lives. Reacting to the footage, she exclaimed, "It's just fabulous."

A recent survey by vehicle leasing firm OSV indicates that the tradition of Britons washing their own cars is diminishing. The study of 1,100 adults found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do performing the task regularly. Among women, three-quarters reported never washing their own vehicles, opting instead for local car wash services. Contributing factors to this decline include the rise of Sunday shopping, increased live football on TV, the availability of affordable hand car washes, and larger vehicle sizes like 4x4s that are more challenging to clean. Furthermore, only 5% of respondents have asked their children to wash the car for extra pocket money. During holidays such as Easter, there's a surge in car washing by owners—an estimated 15 million cars—though a quarter admit doing it merely to get out of the house. The practice of self-washing is most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least common in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Owners of Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are more likely to wash their own cars, while those with Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are less inclined. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley commented that while car washing was once a national Sunday tradition, modern lifestyles, larger cars, disinterest from children, and convenient alternatives have led to its decline.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard for his significant impact since Skrtel joined Liverpool in 2008, noting Gerrard's assistance in helping him settle at the club. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool, acknowledging that the team will be different without him. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, which would be his final match before moving to LA Galaxy. Despite the challenge of replacing Gerrard, Skrtel believes Liverpool has players capable of filling the void with the team's support. Both Skrtel and Gerrard are expected to return to the lineup after serving three-match bans for violent conduct in a previous match against Manchester United.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus delighted fans by scoring a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus watched his ball sail past the flag before spinning back into the hole, marking his first ace at Augusta. The day saw a total of five hole-in-ones, tying the record set in 2002. Camilo Villegas made two aces on the fourth and eighth holes but narrowly lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, who became the youngest to wear the green jacket in 1963 and secured his sixth Masters win in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career Grand Slam—an achievement Rory McIlroy aims to match with a victory at the upcoming major.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens blared in Kansas as storms brought reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted about six miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. CNN's severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that storms would continue throughout the night and emphasized that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous.

Additional tornado sightings were reported near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. Kansas wasn't the only state affected; the National Weather Service indicated that a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. Reports from CNN affiliate KMOV mentioned wind damage and flooding in the town. Social media users shared images of fallen trees, damaged roofs, flooded streets, unusual dark clouds, and baseball-sized hail.

The Weather Service forecasted more storms on Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and areas near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve sheriff's deputy in Tulsa County, Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates claims he intended to subdue Harris with a Taser but mistakenly used his firearm instead. During his hearing, the judge granted Bates permission to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, a decision that prompted criticism from Harris's family, who viewed it as a sign of apathy toward the shooting and their loss.

Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. His lawyers expressed eagerness to address the facts in court rather than in the media. Meanwhile, Harris's family alleges that Bates was unqualified for his role and received preferential treatment due to donations he made to the sheriff's office and his friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz. The *Tulsa World* newspaper reported claims that some supervisors were instructed to falsify Bates's training records and were reassigned when they refused; the sheriff's office denies these allegations.

In response to scrutiny over his qualifications, one of Bates's lawyers released most of his training documents, asserting they demonstrate proper law enforcement training. Additionally, two deputies involved in Harris's arrest have been reassigned because of threats made against them and their families. Both Bates and Sheriff Glanz have apologized to the Harris family for the incident.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the encounter, McGregor unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, adding to his existing chest tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart. He shared the new ink on Instagram with the caption, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor claims that Aldo lacks the same motivation and highlighted their tense relationship, which included grabbing Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin. Aldo will be defending his title for the eighth time, while McGregor aims to claim it in front of his supporters.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism after he was filmed skolling a schooner of beer in about six seconds at an Australian Rules Football club function. The act, cheered on by players chanting his name, drew the ire of anti-drinking campaigners. Dr. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor at the University of Technology Sydney, labeled his behavior "problematic," arguing that it glorified binge drinking and reinforced stereotypes associating masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption. She expressed concern that such displays promote a culture focused on drinking quantity and speed rather than socializing responsibly.

Opposition Leader Bill Shorten commented on the incident with a quip about Abbott's previous preference for light beer, referencing a past critique where Abbott was called "un-Australian" for ordering a light beer during his 2010 campaign. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating there was "nothing wrong" with his actions and highlighting his commitment to fitness.

The event also sparked comparisons to former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, known for his beer-skolling antics. However, Dr. Robert noted that attitudes toward binge drinking have shifted, emphasizing increased concern over such behavior. The incident ignited a broader discussion on the role of public figures in promoting responsible drinking practices and the impact of their actions on cultural perceptions of alcohol consumption.

Indiana is facing a significant HIV outbreak in Scott County, where the number of confirmed cases has risen to 120, with an additional 10 preliminary positive cases. This increase is linked primarily to intravenous drug users sharing needles while using the prescription painkiller Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary 30-day needle exchange program on March 26. 

Since the program's initiation, over 5,322 clean syringes have been distributed to 86 participants, and approximately 1,400 used syringes have been returned. Health officials, including Brittany Combs of the Scott County Health Department, note that participation has increased, partly due to mobile units reaching out to at-risk individuals. Officials expect the number of HIV cases to continue rising as more people undergo testing.

The future of the needle exchange program is uncertain. Governor Pence, who generally opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, is reviewing whether to extend the program beyond its April 25 end date. Concurrently, legislation proposed by House Public Health Committee Chairman Ed Clere aims to allow 23 Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates—a key indicator of potential HIV outbreaks—to establish their own needle exchange programs. However, some lawmakers, including Senate President Pro Tem David Long, express concerns that such programs might promote drug use.

Funding remains a challenge, as federal funds cannot be used for needle exchange programs due to a ban in place since 1989. Governor Pence's executive order did not allocate state funds for the program, leaving agencies to source their own funding. Health experts like Dr. Beth Meyerson from Indiana University question the sustainability of this approach and emphasize the need for long-term solutions to address the epidemic.

An ardent Arsenal fan gave his girlfriend, Saskia, a detailed exam to test her knowledge of his favorite football club. The test mimicked a formal school exam with multiple-choice questions, tables to fill out, and open-ended responses, complete with instructions like "Read every question at least twice" and "Calculators may be used." Saskia scored an impressive 43.5 out of 50 (87%), and her boyfriend humorously commented that he would not be dumping her as a result.

Saskia shared images of the test on her Twitter account, expressing mixed emotions about the ordeal. The exam included questions such as naming Arsenal's starting 11 in their relevant positions, detailing the scoreline of the 2014 FA Cup final against Hull City, and explaining why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard. While she made a few errors—misplacing player positions and struggling with some answers—she earned extra points for creative responses that pleased her boyfriend.

The incident garnered mixed reactions on social media. Many praised the boyfriend as a "legend" and considered Saskia "proper girlfriend material" for her efforts and knowledge. Some men joked about giving similar tests to their own partners. However, others felt the boyfriend had gone too far, calling the act excessive. Despite the criticisms, the overall tone suggested it was taken in good humor, and the couple's playful interaction amused many online observers.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellín cartel, became a crucial informant for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s due to a conflict with his boss. For 27 years, he worked undercover for the DEA without pay, under the promise of receiving U.S. citizenship. Toro's information was instrumental in the prosecutions of major figures like cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. After retiring due to declining health, Toro now faces deportation because the promised citizenship was never granted, leaving him in the U.S. illegally since his temporary visa expired on January 1. He fears for his life if returned to Colombia, believing he would be killed within hours. Despite support from former DEA agent Mike McManus, who asserts that Toro deserves to remain in the U.S. for his service, the DEA has refused to assist him with his legal status. Unable to collect Social Security benefits without proper documentation, Toro is prepared to go into hiding and expresses regret for his past, stating that he has atoned and seeks only what was promised to him.

A 14-year-old girl from Kosi Kalan in Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district, India, set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. The assault occurred on Sunday when she went outside her house to relieve herself. On Tuesday, distressed by the incident and reportedly told by her family to remain silent, she used kerosene to set herself ablaze. Her brother discovered her in flames and extinguished them with water. She is currently in critical condition at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested.

This incident highlights the ongoing issues of sexual assault and women's safety in India. It follows the government's ban on "India's Daughter," a documentary about the 2012 gang rape and murder of 23-year-old student Jyoti Singh in Delhi, which had ignited widespread protests and calls for increased protection for women. Additionally, instances of vigilante justice have emerged, such as the mob killings of individuals accused of rape in Nagaland. In one case, an 18-year-old man named Ibo Cha was beaten to death by a crowd after being accused of raping and murdering an 11-year-old girl. In another, Syed Sarif Khan, accused but not convicted of raping a 19-year-old student, was taken from prison and killed by a mob; the Nagaland government later stated he was innocent.

These events have intensified public outcry and demand for stronger measures to combat sexual violence and ensure justice, shedding light on issues of misogyny and the challenges within the legal system in addressing such crimes.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has ruled out Robin van Persie for Sunday's derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford, stating that while van Persie believes he is fit after recovering from ankle trouble, he is not fit enough to play. Van Gaal emphasized the importance of the match, noting that a victory could elevate United to third place, improving their chances of avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture. He expressed his ambition to defeat City, acknowledging the challenge but highlighting the need to control aggression, referencing their earlier 1-0 loss to City. Van Gaal also mentioned that Luke Shaw is not fit to play. As the team prepares for the derby, van Gaal praised the support of the fans and looked forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford. Key players like Wayne Rooney, Angel Di Maria, and Ander Herrera participated in training, aiming to continue their recent strong form.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The demonstration was a response to escalating costs, with the cheapest tickets priced at £64—among the highest in the league—despite the Premier League's recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans from both clubs united, displaying banners that read, "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket," inside and outside the 60,000-capacity stadium. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. Representatives like Kelvin Meadows and Roy Bentham criticized the commercialization of football, labeling ticket prices as "extortionate," and warned that the sport risks losing future generations of working-class fans. Further protests were anticipated after the match concluded.

A newborn baby named Star Reader from Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth when her skin developed a persistent yellow tinge. Biliary atresia is a rare condition affecting about 1 in 16,000 babies, where the bile ducts are blocked or absent, leading to liver failure if untreated. An initial surgery to unblock her bile ducts was unsuccessful, and doctors determined that a liver transplant was necessary for her survival. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were not suitable donors. Jade's twin sister, Shanell Reader, was found to be a compatible match and volunteered without hesitation to donate part of her liver. In November, Star underwent the transplant surgery. After spending six weeks in the hospital, she returned home and is making a good recovery. Star will require regular blood tests and anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life, but she now has the chance to live a normal life thanks to her aunt's selfless donation.

Chelsea footballers Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge, competing in pairs. Hazard and Ake faced off against Remy and Willian in a series of creative football tasks involving Audi cars. In the first round, the teams aimed to kick balls into the boot of a car from close range, with Hazard and Ake winning 5-3. The second round featured a makeshift tennis game where an Audi R8 V10 Plus served as the net; Hazard and Ake prevailed again, extending their lead to 6-0. In the final challenge, players attempted long-range shots to land balls into convertible Audis. Remy and Willian won this round, but not without incident—Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the cars with a powerful shot. Despite the mishap, he was later seen laughing and driving one of the Audis involved in the challenge.

In December 2013, Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a highway crash that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé, Jason Timmons, 29. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated that he was not suicidal at the time of the crash, countering earlier claims by prosecutors that he had intended to kill himself by driving his pickup truck across a median at over 100 mph into oncoming traffic. His defense attributed the crash to health issues, including Ambien withdrawal, effects of psychiatric medications, Prozac, and advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces a prison sentence of 12 to 24 years. The victims' families have filed a wrongful death lawsuit against him.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears. She was convicted of poisoning him by administering a lethal amount of salt through his feeding tube while he was hospitalized in a suburban New York hospital. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill to gain attention, highlighting her social media posts about his health and photos of his final hours on life support introduced as evidence during the trial. Garnett endured repeated hospitalizations and unnecessary surgical procedures due to his mother's actions, which prosecutors described as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Despite prosecutors seeking the maximum sentence of 25 years to life, Spears was given 20 years and displayed no emotion during sentencing. The judge acknowledged she suffers from a mental illness. Her lawyer maintained her innocence, blamed the hospital for negligence, and planned to appeal the verdict. Garnett's father, Chris Hill, expressed outrage on Facebook after the sentencing, hoping Spears would face harm in prison and criticizing her lack of emotion in court.

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia later than expected due to the inclusion of protection against two new strains: Influenza A strain H3N2 and Influenza B strain B/Phuket. This decision was made after a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter, where the existing vaccine did not effectively combat these strains. High-risk groups—including the very young, the elderly, and most Indigenous Australians—will have access to free, government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasizes that everyone should get vaccinated, as it also provides protection against Influenza A strain H1N1 and helps protect vulnerable populations. He notes that the updated vaccine should be a good match for circulating strains globally and may prevent more deaths per capita than occurred in the northern hemisphere. The vaccine being introduced in Australia will be the same as the one to be used in the next northern winter. People are encouraged to book their flu shots promptly due to the delay in vaccine stocks arriving.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending the site against a critical article in *National Geographic* magazine that described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and being "a disappointment" reconstructed in "incongruous art deco style." This critique comes at a challenging time, as the tomb faces potential budget cuts proposed by Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner, who has suggested eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the site by merging it into another department. The timing is particularly sensitive as the state commemorates the 150th anniversary of President Lincoln's assassination.

Budget reductions have already affected the tomb, leading to reduced hours and staffing after a $1.1 million funding cut for Springfield area historic sites. Supporters like Pam VanAlstine, president of the Lincoln Monument Association and a volunteer tour guide, express deep concern about the future management of the tomb, stating, "We're all scared to death... We don't know how things are going to be run." They also dispute the negative portrayal in the magazine, arguing that the author’s view is not reflective of most visitors' experiences.

According to the state historic preservation agency, over $2.5 million has been invested in recent repairs and renovations, including updates to the interior plaster, paint, bronze, marble construction, and lighting upgrades costing approximately $730,000. Additional projects, such as waterproofing the receiving vault and landscaping improvements, are underway.

The tomb, designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has undergone reconstructions in 1899 and 1930 to address foundational issues and enhance public access. It is a circular structure topped with an obelisk, featuring an interior sheathed in alternating black and tan marble trimmed with bronze. Hallways lead to the family burial chamber, where Lincoln rests beneath the inscription, "Now he belongs to the ages."

Visitors like William Sparks disagree with the magazine's assessment, praising the tomb as "absolutely gorgeous" and "very impressive," despite not being able to view the interior due to reduced hours. Chris Wills, spokesman for the historic preservation agency, notes that while the author of the article is entitled to his opinion, it does not align with the majority of visitors' sentiments.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, many of which are gaining popularity among a new generation of fashion enthusiasts. While some styles like chokers and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts are embraced, others are met with skepticism. The article highlights nine specific trends that some believe should remain in the past:

1. **Bucket Hats**: Once a staple for fishermen and farmers, bucket hats became a casual fashion item in the '90s, worn by celebrities like Christina Aguilera. The trend is reappearing with stars like Rihanna sporting them.

2. **Camouflage Print**: Popularized by bands like Destiny's Child in the early 2000s, camouflage patterns are making a comeback, seen on models like Jourdan Dunn.

3. **Overdoing Trends**: The practice of taking fashion trends to the extreme was common in the '90s, with celebrities like Victoria Beckham and Britney Spears wearing all-denim outfits. This maximalist approach is exemplified today by Kylie Jenner.

4. **Ugg Boots**: These shapeless sheepskin boots were a celebrity favorite in the 2000s, often worn by Paris Hilton. They continue to be worn today by actors like Kristen Bell.

5. **Daisy Dukes**: Extremely short denim shorts gained renewed popularity after Jessica Simpson wore them in the 2005 "Dukes of Hazzard" film. Miley Cyrus is known for wearing them in current fashion.

6. **Juicy Couture Tracksuits**: Velour matching tracksuits were iconic in the 2000s, favored by Nicole Richie and Britney Spears. Nicki Minaj has been seen reviving this trend.

7. **Colored Sunglasses**: Vibrant, tinted lenses were a '90s favorite among artists like Justin Timberlake and Britney Spears. Models like Cara Delevingne and reality stars like Kylie Jenner are bringing them back.

8. **Corsets as Outerwear**: Originally undergarments from the 16th century, corsets were worn as tops in the '90s by stars like Victoria Beckham. Selena Gomez has embraced this style in modern red-carpet appearances.

9. **Harem Trousers**: Characterized by a loose fit that tapers at the ankle, these trousers were worn by Kim Kardashian in the late 2000s and are now seen on models like Elle Macpherson.

The passage suggests that while some nostalgic fashions can be fun, these particular trends might be better left in the past due to their impracticality or unflattering styles.

The passage highlights several trending stories from the week:

- **Quadruple Rainbow in New York:** After heavy rainfall, a rare sight of four rainbows appeared over the New York area on Tuesday morning. Amanda Curtis, the CEO of a fashion company, captured this remarkable phenomenon.

- **Crackdown on Strippers at Funerals in China:** In rural China, the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes has become increasingly common. Authorities are now cracking down on this trend as part of a wider effort to curb vice.

- **Robert Downey Jr.'s Interview Incident:** Actor Robert Downey Jr. grew agitated during an interview with a Channel 4 UK reporter when questioned about his personal life.

- **#KylieJennerChallenge Trend:** Inspired by Kylie Jenner, a new trend involving lip plumping by sucking on a jar has gone viral on social media, using the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge.

- **Alice Barker's Trip Down Memory Lane:** With the assistance of filmmakers, 102-year-old Alice Barker was able to revisit moments from her past.

- **Controversial Prom-posal:** A student's prom invitation referencing bombs was deemed unacceptable by school administrators. The student alleges that the decision was motivated by racism.

- **Ewan McGregor Cast in 'Beauty and the Beast':** Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in the upcoming "Beauty and the Beast" film, generating significant interest on social media.

- **Johnny Depp in 'Black Mass' Trailer:** Johnny Depp appears nearly unrecognizable in the trailer for "Black Mass," showcasing his transformation for the role.

- **Creative Pregnancy Announcement:** A couple announced their pregnancy with a reference to "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."

- **Military Dad's Photobomb:** A military father creatively photobombed his son's picture, earning accolades for originality.

At the Miami Open, Serena Williams achieved her 700th career victory by defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 to advance to the semi-finals. To celebrate the milestone, a giant cake was presented to her, mirroring a similar celebration for Andy Murray's 500th win the previous day. Williams's hopes for a match against her sister Venus were dashed when Venus lost to Spain's Carla Suarez Navarro. In the semi-finals, Serena will face Romania's Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5. The tournament holds special significance for Serena as it is close to her hometown.

Sabeen Mahmud, the owner of the Second Floor (T2F) cafe in Karachi, Pakistan, was a prominent advocate for free speech, human rights, and progressive values. Her cafe, painted with psychedelic colors and decorated with socially critical graffiti, was a haven for open discussions on technology, politics, and women's entrepreneurship. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud hosted a discussion on the controversial situation in Baluchistan, where allegations of mass abductions and a separatist insurgency persist. Shortly after closing the cafe for the night, she was shot dead by two gunmen, who also wounded her mother. Mahmud's death has sparked widespread grief among those who admired her courage and dedication to creating space for free thought in a country where such expression is dangerous. Her work at T2F inspired many young Pakistanis seeking freedom of thought, and she is remembered as a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, has lived as a refugee in Indian-administered Kashmir since fleeing the violence of the 1947 Partition of India. For nearly 70 years, he and thousands like him—known as West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs)—have been denied citizenship rights in the state. They are unable to own property, vote in state elections, access state-run educational institutions, or obtain state government jobs, leading to generations living in poverty.

The reluctance of successive Kashmiri governments to grant rights to the predominantly Hindu WPRs stems from concerns about altering the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state, which has special autonomy enshrined in the constitution. Approximately 100,000 people are classified as WPRs, most of whom were born in India and have never been to Pakistan. Despite living in one of India's more prosperous states, they reside in slum settlements in the Jammu region, often marrying within their community due to economic constraints.

The recent electoral success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), which gained a share of power in Kashmir's state government, has given the WPRs hope that their status may improve. The BJP has pledged to normalize their situation and advocate for their rights. Activists like Labha Ram Gandhi express optimism but also warn that the community is prepared to take action if their hopes are dashed again.

The passage also highlights ongoing unrest in Kashmir, including attacks by suspected militants seeking independence or a merger with Pakistan. Despite these challenges, the WPRs continue to advocate for recognition as citizens in the land where they were born and have lived their entire lives.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane revealed that Chelsea have made an offer of around £4 million for the Japan international. While Chelsea intend to loan Muto to their partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season, Muto is keen to join a team where he can play regularly and continue his development. After scoring against Shonan Bellmare, Muto expressed his desire to carefully consider his options to find a club that suits him.

Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut at FC Tokyo in 2013 and is now the manager of Real Zaragoza, believes Muto could be successful at Stamford Bridge. He praised Muto as an intelligent, fast, and confident player with a strong educational background. Popovic highlighted Muto's unique qualities, including his noble demeanor and exceptional potential.

Chelsea manager José Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto but refrained from discussing details out of respect for FC Tokyo. Mourinho admitted that commercial interests, such as Chelsea's recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, play a part in the club's transfer policy. However, he emphasized that the club only signs players who are good or have promising prospects, aligning financial considerations with on-field success.

The passage advocates for England to allow their rugby coach, Stuart Lancaster, to select the best players regardless of where they play, following Australia's recent decision to drop their policy of excluding overseas-based players. Australia recognized the value of including top performers like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell from Toulon, strengthening their squad ahead of the World Cup. The author argues that England's policy is outdated and diminishes the quality of the World Cup by preventing top talent, such as Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon—who have improved significantly while playing in France—from representing their country. The passage emphasizes that all players, fans, and stakeholders want England to succeed, and this starts with selecting the strongest team possible. It is noted that other nations, like South Africa and Wales, select players based abroad, exemplified by Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny at Toulon. The author concludes that England should prioritize winning and unite the best players, regardless of their club affiliations, especially as they host the upcoming World Cup.

Open Garden, the developer of the FireChat app, has introduced GreenStone, a small egg-shaped device designed to enhance wireless mesh networks. FireChat allows users to chat without internet access or mobile signals by utilizing Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) on iOS and similar Bluetooth features on Android. This technology creates local networks where each phone acts as a node, enabling messages and photos to be sent securely and anonymously to nearby users within approximately 30 feet (9 meters).

The "Everyone" setting in FireChat extends this capability by connecting all nodes into one network, allowing messages to relay from one node to another, reaching recipients up to about 200 feet (61 meters) away. GreenStone serves as a beacon or booster within these networks, filling gaps to extend the range and reliability of message transmission. With a range of around 20 feet (6 meters), GreenStone holds messages until another FireChat user comes within range, features a one-year battery life, and can store up to 1,000 recent messages.

This technology is particularly useful in situations where traditional networks are unavailable or overloaded, such as on planes, in underground transport, at music festivals, protests, or sporting events. Open Garden is collaborating with manufacturers to design and distribute GreenStone devices, aiming to provide resilient communication options in various environments without relying on conventional connectivity.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is advocating for body positivity by reclaiming the word "fat" as an honest and neutral descriptor of her physique. In a TED Talk, she explained that just as she calls herself "short" because she is 5'3" and "wife" because she is married, "fat" is simply another factual characteristic that doesn't equate to being "ugly." Bustle highlighted the rise in size discrimination—up 66% in the past 30 years—and noted that negative perceptions of larger bodies begin at a young age, with many girls wishing to be thinner.

She emphasized that increased exposure to diverse body types leads to greater acceptance and appreciation. By performing burlesque, Bustle aims to present her "fat" body in a positive, glamorous way, challenging societal beauty standards. Inspired by other performers who promote body diversity, she began performing in 2012 and found the experience empowering and transformative for her self-esteem. She encourages others to find their own "courage reference"—a personal moment of bravery to draw strength from during times of insecurity.

After her TED Talk was posted on YouTube, Bustle received an overwhelmingly positive response, including messages from individuals re-evaluating their views on their bodies. Despite encountering some negative comments, she remains optimistic about the progress of the body-positivity movement, believing that increased exposure and open dialogue are helping to shift perceptions in a more inclusive direction.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger who has spent much of the season on the substitutes' bench, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris's oldest fashion house and Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Alongside runway model Olga Sherer and teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Özil, Walcott posed for an official portrait. The Arsenal first-team players will wear similar attire when they head to Wembley Stadium for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott, who has been named on the bench for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games, came on for the last six minutes in the 0-0 draw with Chelsea. He hopes to make his first start since March 14 when Arsenal face Hull City at the KC Stadium on Monday.

An extensive collection of over 400 original props, costumes, and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker is set to be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at propstore.com. Valued at approximately $746,100, the items span Baker's 30-year career and originate from more than 50 productions, including **"Men in Black," "Batman Forever," "How the Grinch Stole Christmas,"** and **"Gremlins 2: The New Batch."**

Notable pieces include the **Alien Edgar Bug** from *Men in Black* (estimated at $40,000), the **Grinch costume** worn by Jim Carrey (listed at $8,000), the **Two-Face mask** from *Batman Forever* (valued at $1,500), and various Gremlin puppets from *Gremlins 2* (each valued around $8,000). Other significant items are the **Mikey costume** from *Men in Black* (estimated at $30,000), the **Hammerhead Alien** from the same film (listed at $8,000), and the **Worm Guy** from *Men in Black II* (valued at $10,000).

The auction also features props from **"An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," "Batman & Robin," "Hellboy,"** and Michael Jackson's **"Thriller"** music video and **"Moonwalker"** film. Brandon Alinger of Prop Store expressed excitement about offering these items to the public, highlighting it as a unique opportunity for collectors and fans to own pieces of Baker's remarkable work.

Seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, tragically died in a skiing accident in the French Alps. Described by his family as a "daring, outgoing, and determined" child whose "handsome smile lit up any room," Carwyn was an experienced skier who began skiing at the age of three.

While on a family holiday in the resort of Flaine, France, Carwyn became separated from his mother, Ceri, and his sister, Antonia, during their last run of the day. After Antonia lost a ski on a jump, Ceri stopped to assist her, and Carwyn pressed on ahead. Believing he could reach the resort he saw through the trees, he left the piste, removed his skis, and entered dense woodland. Unfortunately, he fell over a 164-foot drop.

His mother desperately searched for him, and police were eventually led to his body by following his footprints and sliding marks in the snow. The tragedy has left a "vast void" in his family's hearts. Friends, classmates, and the community are mourning his loss, remembering him as a lively and likeable pupil who made life full of laughter. The family, well-known for their award-winning farm shop frequented by figures like David Cameron, remains in the Alps as they grieve.

At 13, Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay developed anorexia, severely restricting her food intake to as little as one piece of fruit a day. This extreme dieting led to her collapsing from starvation and being hospitalized on a heart monitor as her body began to shut down. Laura spoke about the immense pressure on teenagers to attain a "size zero" figure, stemming from bullying and societal expectations. After receiving support from eating disorder organizations and focusing on her recovery, she regained her health and confidence. Now 15, Laura has reached the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a contest that promotes positive experiences for young girls and moves away from size zero stereotypes.

Raheem Sterling, despite recent speculation about his future after rejecting a £100,000-a-week contract and hinting at interest from Arsenal, joined teammates in unveiling Liverpool's new home kit at Anfield. Fans urged him to stay, with one shouting, "Make sure we see you in that next season," which was met with applause. The new kit features a gingham design and honors the Hillsborough disaster victims with a memorial flame and the number 96. It is the first produced by New Balance under a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal, replacing Warrior as the club's supplier. Players Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, Simon Mignolet, Adam Lallana, Jordan Henderson, and Philippe Coutinho also participated, promoting the message "Hold Nothing Back." The players expressed appreciation for the fans and looked ahead to the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley. Liverpool legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush attended the launch, adding to the event's significance.

Scientists have produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter, marking the first in a series that will eventually provide a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky. Researchers from the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, spent two years measuring the shapes of galaxies to construct the map, which was released at the American Physical Society meeting in Baltimore, Maryland. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera (DECam), a 570-megapixel imaging device used in the Dark Energy Survey (DES) based at the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile.

Covering about 0.4% of the sky, the map displays clumps of dark matter by detecting the distortion of light from distant galaxies—a phenomenon known as gravitational lensing. Since dark matter does not emit or block light, its presence is inferred from these gravitational effects. The DES aims to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, creating a comprehensive 3D map of dark matter and dark energy.

The findings support theories that galaxies form in areas with large concentrations of dark matter due to stronger gravitational forces. The maps reveal large filaments of matter where galaxies and clusters reside, as well as cosmic voids with few galaxies. Analyzing the clumpiness of dark matter will help scientists understand the nature of dark energy, which is believed to cause the accelerated expansion of the universe. The project involves analyzing 130 million images of galaxies, a task that requires substantial computational resources, including some of the world's most powerful supercomputers. As the survey progresses, researchers expect to better test cosmological theories by comparing the distributions of dark and visible matter.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign their 21-year-old star winger, Memphis Depay. PSV's technical director, Marcel Brands, confirmed that Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and a third major European club have expressed interest in Depay. United's manager, Louis van Gaal, is eager to secure Depay as one of his first signings of the summer, having previously worked with him during the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup campaign, where the team finished third.

Depay has had an impressive season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games, contributing significantly to PSV securing their first Eredivisie title in seven years with a 4-1 victory over Heerenveen. His performances have increased his market value beyond the £15 million bid that Tottenham Hotspur had rejected the previous summer.

Known for his pace, dribbling skills, and powerful right-footed shots from distance, Depay predominantly plays on the left wing and cuts inside. PSV manager Phillip Cocu compares his potential to that of Arjen Robben, while scout Ed van Steijn believes Depay may be ahead of where Cristiano Ronaldo was at the same age. Internationally, Depay has made impactful contributions to the Dutch national team, scoring crucial goals during the 2014 World Cup and earning a nomination for the tournament's Best Young Player award.

Manchester United are positioned as front-runners to sign Depay but face competition from other top European clubs. His blend of athleticism, skill, and determination marks him as one of Europe's most promising young talents.

Chelsea's youth team secured a commanding 3-1 victory over Manchester City's young side at the Academy Stadium in Manchester. Tammy Abraham shone for Chelsea, scoring two first-half volleys—his 35th and 36th goals of the season—to give his team the lead. Despite Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalizing for City with a measured finish, Abraham's acrobatic second goal restored Chelsea's advantage. Dominic Solanke sealed the win late on with a neat third goal after a powerful performance alongside Abraham.

The match featured notable performances from several promising players. For Chelsea, the defensive duo of Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori formed a commanding partnership, effectively nullifying City's attack. Ola Aina was influential down the right flank, repeatedly finding space and contributing both defensively and offensively. Jay Dasilva, at just 16 years old, was solid at the back and lively going forward, delivering numerous quality crosses. Midfielder Ruben Sammut expertly protected the back four and initiated counter-attacks, while captain Charlie Colkett led by example in the center of the park.

On the Manchester City side, captain Tosin Adarabioyo was a commanding presence at the heart of defense, displaying movement reminiscent of Yaya Touré. Brandon Barker, tipped for big things at the Etihad, showed flashes of brilliance with his two-footed skill and created a fine chance for Manu Garcia. However, City struggled to capitalize on opportunities, with Kean Bryan missing a chance to tie the game and Aaron Nemane unable to find the final killer ball despite his impressive runs.

Both teams showcased a wealth of young talent, but Chelsea's clinical finishing and strong defensive work gave them a significant advantage to take back to West London.

Marco Rubio, a U.S. senator from Florida and presidential candidate, stated on CBS's "Face the Nation" that he believes people are born with their sexual preferences. While he is not personally against gay marriage, Rubio maintains that marriage should be defined as a union between one man and one woman. He believes that state legislatures, not courts, should decide on the legality of same-sex marriage and does not view it as a constitutional right. Despite his stance, Rubio mentioned he would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cares about, emphasizing that he would not hurt loved ones over disagreements. He compared this to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong, yet he would still love someone who is divorced. Rubio recently announced his presidential bid and has reportedly secured significant financial commitments exceeding $51 million for his campaign.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado, 27, and Latvian cyclist Ilze Zebolde, 31, are a couple traveling the world by bicycle with no specific plans or agenda, simply aiming to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time." After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they began their open-ended journey from London, living on less than three euros each per day. In 356 days, they've cycled nearly 7,000 miles (over 11,000 km) through 16 countries, including France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia.

They keep their expenses minimal by camping under the stars for most nights (161 out of 256), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and occasionally relying on the kindness of strangers. Their primary expense is food, costing them just 2.74 euros each per day. They consume simple meals like pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, and seasonal fruits and vegetables, sometimes benefiting from invitations for meals or free produce.

Pablo and Ilze document their journey on their blog, TheCrazyTravel, sharing experiences like cycling over the symbolic bridge from Greece to Turkey, marking their departure from Europe into Asia. They have traversed the northern coast of Turkey and plan to continue through Asia, with the goal of cycling across the Pacific and traveling the length of the American continent. Embracing an open-ended adventure, they intend to remain on the road for the coming years, exploring the world one pedal at a time.

In 2012, a Texas couple hired photographer James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, for their wedding, including a photo booth service. They allege that the photo booth printed a racist slur containing a derogatory term against African Americans on the bottom of some snapshots. The bride's sister discovered the offensive captions but withheld the information until after the wedding to avoid upsetting the couple on their special day. Months later, upon learning about the incident, the groom contacted Evans, who allegedly did not apologize and responded by telling them to "sue" him. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, filed a lawsuit against Premiere Photos under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, citing negligence and breach of contract. They are seeking at least an apology from Evans. Evans denies the allegations, stating there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive captions and claiming the couple showed "no sign of any mental anguish." Mediation is scheduled, and if no agreement is reached, the case is set for trial in July.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to his recovery from a recent concussion and is unsure when he will return to play. After experiencing headaches following the match against France and pulling out of Harlequins' game against Saracens, he is determined not to rush back and risk a longer-term absence like those faced by George North and Johnny Sexton. Brown emphasizes the importance of recognizing concussion symptoms and being honest about them, a lesson reinforced by World Rugby's online modules. He is taking his recovery step by step, monitoring his response to light exercise. As a Land Rover ambassador speaking at the launch of the "We Deal in Real" campaign, Brown highlighted the necessity of not pushing through concussion symptoms and encouraged teammates to do the same for the sake of their health.

Research indicates that Britons are engaging in sexual activity less frequently, with the average dropping from five times a month in 1990 to three times a month currently. Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge University suggests that increased smartphone use and constant connectivity have blurred the lines between work and personal life, reducing the time couples spend together. He notes that people are often checking emails and remain connected to work even during personal time. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, echoes this sentiment, stating that with numerous demands on people's time, sex becomes a lower priority. The integration of technology into daily life is cited as a key factor contributing to the decline in sexual frequency among couples.

Once highly prized and commanding prices up to £1.2 million, Tibetan Mastiffs in China have experienced a sharp decline in popularity. This downturn is attributed to the government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has curbed the practice of wealthy businessmen gifting these dogs to officials to gain favor. Additionally, bans on owning large dogs over 50 kg in several cities, along with increased urbanization, have made people realize that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living. Breeding practices aimed at maximizing profits have led to cross-breeding, resulting in a deterioration of the breed's quality in terms of appearance and temperament. Consequently, there is a surplus of unsold, poor-quality dogs. Many Tibetan Mastiffs are now being abandoned, sent to slaughterhouses where they are used for meat and leather products, or rescued by animal welfare groups.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area revealed that every respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on the city's public transport, with half reporting their first incident occurred before the age of 18. The harassment ranged from verbal insults and intimidating behaviors—such as insistent flirting, whistling, and comments on appearance—to more severe offenses like sexual assault or rape. Many women remain unaware they have been harassed due to societal conditioning that normalizes low-level abuse.

These pervasive experiences have led six out of ten women to fear attacks on public transport, compared to three out of ten men. As a result, women often alter their daily routines by changing routes, modes of transportation, schedules, attitudes, and clothing to avoid confrontation, effectively limiting their freedom and participation in public life. The report, presented to the French women's rights ministry, calls for campaigns to combat sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains.

Pascale Boistard, president of the High Council for Gender Equality—which compiled the report—expressed surprise at the widespread nature of the problem and affirmed that women must be able to move freely without fear or threat. Ernestine Ronai, also from the council, noted that attackers often feel they can act with impunity by blending into crowds. She emphasized the importance of educating women that such experiences are not normal and stressed that touching someone inappropriately constitutes sexual assault, punishable by up to five years in prison and a €75,005 fine. The council advocates for increased awareness among aggressors, victims, and witnesses to address and reduce these incidents.

Leeds-based company Direct Line is hosting the #everydayfix competition, inviting design groups to create prototype products that solve common everyday emergencies identified by a survey of 2,000 people. The top emergencies include inability to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery.

Designers from London-based Makerversity devised solutions, and three products were shortlisted:

1. **Snooze** by Instruments: An alarm clock that connects to a phone to silence notifications, promoting better sleep.
2. **Forget Me Lock** by Onn Studio: A device that attaches to a key and indicates if a door is locked (red) or unlocked (green), providing reassurance.
3. **Nipper** by Impulse: Claimed to be the world's smallest mobile phone charger, it uses any household battery to give a phone a power boost.

Public voting is encouraged through Twitter by retweeting with the #everydayfix hashtag. The product with the most retweets by April 46 will proceed to a Kickstarter campaign for development.

Other innovative prototypes that didn't make the final shortlist include:

- **Parking Pin**: A device left in a parking space to alert when the space becomes available.
- **Relay App**: An app allowing users to nominate contacts to receive messages when their phone battery dies.
- **Hat Nav**: A smart cycling helmet using bone conduction headphones to provide navigation without hindering environmental awareness.

Paul Smyth of Makerversity and John Shaw of Direct Line expressed enthusiasm for the creative solutions aimed at resolving everyday emergencies.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice after allocating over £500,000 of taxpayers' money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs alongside Chief Constable Sue Sim. Critics, including Labour's Keith Vaz, accuse them of a conflict of interest and inappropriate use of public funds, likening the situation to a "soap opera" within the force. The Ministry of Justice is probing whether any rules have been breached regarding conflicts of interest. While Baird insists all protocols were followed, concerns have been raised about public reluctance to engage with the charity due to Sim's involvement, as she faces allegations of workplace bullying and is set to retire. The charity was established after a decline in engagement with its predecessor, Victim Support.

In Philadelphia, three individuals were sentenced to prison for assaulting and torturing 53-year-old Greg Valecce. The ringleader, Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, believed Valecce had harmed his cat and stolen money and drugs. Together with his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, Campbell detained Valecce in the basement of Campbell's mother's house in Mayfair. Over approximately 42 hours, they physically abused him, tied him to a chair, and forcibly tattooed offensive images and words on his body. Valecce sustained serious injuries but managed to escape and notify the police. Campbell and Halin were each sentenced to 20 years in state prison, while Ng received a 23-month sentence. Two others involved, David Thomas, 28, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven. Manager Louis van Gaal is keen to secure Depay's transfer, having previously worked with him during the Netherlands' successful 2014 World Cup campaign, where they finished third. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games, and played a key role in PSV winning their first Eredivisie title in seven years with a 4-1 victory over Heerenveen.

PSV's technical director, Marcel Brands, confirmed interest from Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and a third major European club, noting that Depay's value has increased since Tottenham Hotspur's £15 million bid was rejected the previous summer. Depay is known for his pace, dribbling skills, and powerful right foot, often playing on the left wing and cutting inside. He has been compared to Arjen Robben by PSV manager Phillip Cocu, and Ed van Steijn, the scout who discovered Cristiano Ronaldo for Manchester United, suggests Depay might have more potential than Ronaldo had at the same age. Depay's background includes stints at VV Moordrecht and Sparta Rotterdam before joining PSV's youth academy at age 12 and making his professional debut in 2011.

Chelsea's youth team achieved a commanding 3-1 victory over Manchester City's young side at the Academy Stadium in Manchester. Tammy Abraham was instrumental for Chelsea, scoring two first-half goals—his 35th and 36th of the season—to give his team the lead. Although Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalized for City with a well-placed finish, Chelsea regained control, and Dominic Solanke added a late third goal to extend their advantage.

The match featured standout performances from players on both sides. For Chelsea, defenders Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter formed a solid partnership, effectively neutralizing City's attacks. Ola Aina was influential at right-back, frequently finding space and contributing to both defense and attack. Midfielder Charlie Colkett led by example in the center of the park, helping Chelsea win the midfield battle. Abraham's impressive display was cut short due to an injury that saw him substituted in the 67th minute.

On the Manchester City side, captain Tosin Adarabioyo was a commanding presence in defense, displaying attributes reminiscent of Yaya Touré. Brandon Barker, considered City's star man, showed flashes of brilliance with his surging runs but was occasionally guilty of overcomplicating play. Aaron Nemane showcased skill on the wing, outwitting opponents but struggling to deliver the final decisive pass. Goalkeeper Kjetil Haug had uncertain moments under high balls and was unable to prevent Chelsea's goals despite some efforts.

Chelsea's victory gives them a significant advantage as they head back to West London, putting them in a strong position for the next leg of the competition.

Florida Senator and presidential candidate Marco Rubio stated on CBS's "Face the Nation" that he believes people are born with their sexual preferences. While he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of love and respect, he maintains that marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman. Rubio argues that states should regulate marriage and that decisions about same-sex marriage should be made by state legislatures through political debate, not by courts. He does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right. Despite his personal beliefs, Rubio emphasizes the importance of respecting and loving individuals, even if he disagrees with their choices, drawing parallels with his views on divorce within his Catholic faith. Recently, Rubio announced his presidential candidacy and has reportedly received significant financial commitments exceeding $47 million to support his campaign.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado, 27, and Latvian cyclist Ilze Zebolde, 31, have embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world without specific plans or agendas. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they set out from London to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time."

Over the past 356 days, they have cycled nearly 7,000 miles (11,132 km) through 16 countries while living on less than three euros each per day—approximately 10 euro cents per kilometer. They keep costs low by primarily camping (161 out of 256 nights), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and occasionally relying on the kindness of strangers. Their main expense is food, costing about 2.74 euros per day, which they manage by eating simple staples, accepting food donations, foraging wild fruits, and occasionally dumpster diving in western countries.

Their route has taken them from the UK through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, North Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. Crossing the bridge from Greece to Turkey symbolized "riding away from Europe, finally crossing into a different continent," according to Pablo. They plan to continue cycling through Asia, cross the Pacific, and traverse the length of the Americas, intending to remain on the road for the coming years.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to his recovery from a recent concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to action. After experiencing headaches following the match against France, he withdrew from Harlequins' Aviva Premiership clash with Saracens at Wembley. Citing the experiences of other players like George North and Johnny Sexton, who faced extended absences due to concussions, Brown emphasized the importance of not rushing back prematurely. He highlighted that increased awareness of concussion symptoms, influenced by World Rugby's online modules, has been crucial in his decision to prioritize his health. Brown believes it's essential for players to recognize symptoms and not push through injuries, as the long-term risks are significant. He shared these insights while speaking at the launch of Land Rover's "We Deal in Real" campaign for the Rugby World Cup 2028, which supports grassroots rugby clubs.

Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, suggests that increased smartphone use and constant technological connectivity are contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples in Britain. Research presented in his book *Sex by Numbers* indicates that the average British heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes this trend to the erosion of boundaries between work and personal life, as people are frequently checking emails and remaining connected to work during home hours. Catherine Mercer from the British National Survey supports this view, stating that with more competing demands on time and the pervasive use of technology, sex often falls lower on people's list of priorities, and individuals may find it difficult to focus on their partners at bedtime due to ongoing connections with the outside world.

Tibetan Mastiffs in China, once commanding prices of up to £1.2 million each, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity and value. These dogs are now so unwanted that they're being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skin made into leather belts. Several factors contribute to this downturn:

- **Anti-Corruption Crackdown**: The Chinese government's wide-reaching anti-corruption campaign has deterred wealthy businessmen from gifting Tibetan Mastiffs to officials as a means of influence. Luo Yi, general manager of China's largest Tibetan Mastiff puppy farm, noted that people no longer dare to give or accept these dogs as gifts.

- **Urban Restrictions**: Recent bans on owning dogs weighing more than 50 kg in several Chinese cities—including Beijing, Zhengzhou, Shanghai, and Tianjin—have significantly impacted the breed's popularity.

- **Breeding Issues**: Unscrupulous breeders engaged in cross-breeding practices have led to a deterioration in the dogs' appearance and temperament. This has resulted in a surplus of poor-quality dogs that are difficult to sell.

- **Urbanization**: The rapid pace of urbanization has made more people realize that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living.

Animal welfare workers have rescued Tibetan Mastiffs en route to slaughterhouses supplying meat for hotpot restaurants. Many of these dogs were found in cramped cages without food or water, with some already dead or suffering from broken bones. Additionally, there are reports of gangs stealing Mastiffs from the streets to sell to slaughterhouses, and breeders offloading "imperfect" dogs to abattoirs.

The breed's fall from grace is stark compared to its heyday starting in 2005 when Tibetan Mastiffs became status symbols. In 2014, a golden-haired one-year-old Mastiff puppy sold for £1.2 million—the highest price ever paid for a dog at the time. However, due to the factors above, the breed's fortune has dramatically reversed.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, is hosting a competition called **#EverydayFix** to tackle common everyday emergencies identified by a survey of 2,000 people. The top issues included not being able to sleep (46%), losing keys (37%), being stuck in traffic (35%), and running out of phone battery (31%).

Design teams from London-based Makerversity created prototypes to address these problems, and three were shortlisted:

1. **Snooze** by Instruments: An alarm clock that connects with your phone to silence notifications, ensuring a good night's sleep.
2. **Forget Me Lock** by ONN Studio: A device that attaches to your key, displaying red when the door is locked and green when it's unlocked, providing peace of mind about door security even when you're away.
3. **Nipper** by Impulse: Touted as the world's smallest mobile phone charger, it uses any household battery to give your phone a power boost via attached terminals.

The public can vote for their favorite prototype by retweeting tweets about it with the hashtag **#EverydayFix** on Twitter. The product with the most retweets by a specified date will launch a Kickstarter campaign for development.

Other innovative ideas that didn't make the final cut included:

- **Parking Pin**: A device to reserve a parking space and alert you when it's available.
- **Relay App**: An app that allows others to receive your messages when your phone battery dies.
- **Hat Nav**: A smart helmet with bone conduction headphones providing navigation instructions to cyclists without blocking ambient sounds.

The competition showcases creative solutions aiming to alleviate everyday stresses by transforming popular concepts into practical products.

The airline headquartered in the Qatar Airways Tower in Doha operates a hub-and-spoke network from Hamad International Airport, connecting over 160 international destinations across Africa, Central Asia, Europe, the Far East, South Asia, the Middle East, North America, South America, and Oceania using a fleet of more than 200 aircraft.

Paul Merson has reignited his feud with Andros Townsend by mocking the Tottenham midfielder's late substitution in a 0-0 draw against Burnley. After Townsend was brought on with just seven minutes remaining, Merson tweeted: "Just been watching the game, did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes." This follows their earlier clash, where Merson questioned Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, saying that if Townsend could make the team, "it opens it up to anybody." Townsend responded to the criticism by scoring a remarkable equalizer for England against Italy and taunting Merson on Twitter. While Merson initially admitted he was wrong and praised Townsend's goal, he couldn't resist taking another jab after the Tottenham match, suggesting lingering tensions between the two.

Chelsea Football Club has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, confirmed by FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer proceeds, Muto would become the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea and is expected to join their Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Ogane stated that Chelsea's interest in Muto is not connected to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has expressed honor at the offer but has not yet decided whether to move. An accomplished forward, Muto scored 13 goals in his debut season, earning a place in the J-League's Best XI, and has continued his strong performance with three goals in four games this season. Chelsea is also considering a two-week pre-season tour of Japan this summer.

A Finnish study published in the journal *Pediatrics* found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. Researchers compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with their antibiotic prescription records. By age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese, with those who had taken antibiotics as infants being particularly affected. Repeated antibiotic prescriptions before the age of two further increased the likelihood of being overweight, especially among boys, who were also found to be slightly taller than their peers who had not received antibiotics.

The study suggests that antibiotics may disrupt gut bacteria that normally aid in metabolism, potentially leading to increased appetite and weight gain. Although causation was not established, lead author Dr. Antti Saari emphasized the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, noting that such exposure could play a role in the global childhood obesity epidemic, which is more pronounced in boys. The findings align with concerns about the over-prescription of antibiotics contributing to unintended health consequences, including obesity, eczema, digestive problems, and antibiotic resistance. Additionally, there is growing worry that antibiotic overuse may lead to the emergence of superbugs, with the government warning of a new strain that could infect up to 200,000 Britons and cause 80,000 deaths in a single outbreak.

During a recent Changing of the Guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident occurred as the guard was taking his position in the sentry box; he lost his footing, slid sideways, bumped his bearskin hat against the box, and dropped his rifle. Tourist David Meadwell, visiting from Newcastle-upon-Tyne with his family, captured the entire event on video. The guard quickly scrambled to his feet as his colleagues marched past, blushing upon realizing the crowd had witnessed his fall. It's believed the slip was due to metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on "a young man falling over while doing his job." The Changing of the Guard is a daily summer event attracting thousands of tourists, and contrary to popular belief, the guards are fully operational soldiers, not merely ceremonial figures.

"Roots," the monumental 1977 miniseries about African slave Kunta Kinte and his descendants, is being remade by A&E networks to air in 2016 across A&E, Lifetime, and History channels. LeVar Burton, who originally portrayed Kinte, will co-executive produce the new adaptation. Described as "original" and "contemporary," the remake will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and will consult African and African-American history scholars for authenticity. Executives like Dirk Hoogstra and Mark Wolper emphasize the importance of retelling Kinte's story to both fans of the original and a new generation that has witnessed significant events like Barack Obama's presidency and ongoing racial issues. Burton highlights that many young Americans are unfamiliar with "Roots" and its significance, underscoring the need for this new adaptation.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler alleges that in January 1978, on his first day working at Clarence House when he was 27, he was sexually assaulted by palace aides who attempted to force him into an orgy. He claims he was pinned to a chair, groped, and that the aides tried to undo his trousers before he managed to escape and left the job the same day. Lawler reported that he was threatened to keep quiet after the incident. Years later, prompted by inquiries into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by VIPs in the 1970s and '80s, he contacted palace officials, but his complaints were initially ignored before being passed to Scotland Yard. Police are now investigating his claims. A retired royal aide in his 80s was interviewed but denied involvement, citing that he was working at Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate fully with any police investigation, while a police spokesman declined to comment due to ongoing investigations.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child by creating a rap video set to the theme song of the 1990s television sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." The video features them rapping while driving in a car, with lyrics adapted to share their journey toward parenthood. Notably, Melissa raps about discovering her pregnancy, and at the end of the clip, they reveal a sonogram of their unborn child. The video was made to inform loved ones living far away and unexpectedly gained significant attention, amassing over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The Meeks mentioned it took five takes to film and are considering making another video after learning their baby's gender. Jesse is identified as the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Additionally, it's noted that Melissa previously recorded Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy news, and another couple from Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, had made a similar announcement video using the same theme song the previous year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at an auction held by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray but now faded to light gray with age, was featured in key scenes of the film, including encounters with Rhett Butler, played by Clark Gable, and an attack in a shanty town. The dress was part of over 150 items auctioned from the private collection of James Tumblin, former head of the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. Tumblin began collecting memorabilia from the film in the 1960s, acquiring the dress for $20 when it was about to be discarded. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500; a suit worn by Gable for $55,000; and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland, which fetched $30,000. "Gone With the Wind," celebrating its 75th anniversary the previous year, is based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel and featured Hattie McDaniel, who became the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role as Mammy.

A two-year-old boy fell into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents allegedly dangled him over the edge. The incident occurred around 3 p.m. on Saturday when the boy's mother was holding him and another child. He slipped and fell approximately 10 to 12 feet into the enclosure. The parents rescued their son before emergency responders arrived. The child sustained minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents during the incident. Zoo officials, citing eyewitness accounts, believe there is a strong likelihood that the child was dangled over the railing. As a result, the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A decommissioned speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been mysteriously turned to point directly at a house's front door. The bright yellow Gatso camera, which previously enforced a 30 mph speed limit on the residential road, has not been operational since March 2013 when around 300 outdated speed and traffic cameras were switched off across the West Midlands. Since then, speed enforcement has been carried out by mobile units, motorway cameras, and patrol officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the re-angled camera; an engineer will inspect the site, and it may be removed completely. The council spokesperson confirmed there are no plans to include this Wellington Road camera in upcoming digital technology pilots. The homeowners were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA). Expressing his enthusiasm, Bolt stated, "I'm happy to be part of the Jamaican team for the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas. I am fit, healthy, and ready to run." He added that he looks forward to the event's great atmosphere and is committed to making his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle commented on Bolt's participation, saying, "We were extremely pleased that Usain was available for selection and that the world's fastest man will be running for Jamaica. We can expect some sprint magic on the track in the Bahamas on 2nd and 3rd May." The full Jamaican team lineup will be announced soon.

Barcelona footballers Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Euro League basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid, known as El Clásico, alongside Neymar's sister Rafaella. The Barcelona basketball team secured a narrow 85-80 victory, though Real Madrid remains top of their division due to points difference. Earlier, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, a feisty match marked by several brutal challenges, including an apparent stamp by Chile's Gary Medel. Before the international break, Luis Enrique's Barcelona football team won their El Clásico match, moving four points clear at the top of La Liga. Barcelona is set to face Celta Vigo on Sunday as they continue their pursuit of a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a significant increase in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe via the Mediterranean Sea.
