Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco have not received compensation, even though the HM Passport Office made a £42 million profit during the chaos and awarded managers bonuses of up to £3,500. Ministers refused to provide blanket refunds to families who paid extra to expedite their travel documents or missed their trips altogether. Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April last year and January this year, scarcely more than the 2,077 approved the previous year, with an average payout of £92.68. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Chairman Keith Vaz, criticized the lack of compensation, but ministers rejected calls for broader refunds, stating it would set a precedent. Despite efforts to cope with 3.6 million passport applications, over half a million were delayed by mid-June. Many individuals, such as Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham who lost nearly £1,500 on a missed trip to Morocco, received no compensation despite paying for upgrades. Meanwhile, in the 2013-14 period, managers at the Passport Office received a total of £1.8 million in bonuses.

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, untouched since the 1930s, is up for sale with a guide price between £200,000 and £250,000. This semi-detached property is a collector's paradise, featuring original stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, a wood-paneled hallway, and oil-fired central heating. The most eye-catching room is the original bathroom, showcasing a mint green and black color scheme with original tiles, wooden floor, yellow wallpaper, and a green sink. The kitchen retains its 1930s cupboards, a dated sink, and a brick open-face fireplace. A high shelf in the hallway displays vintage tins of produce, including Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate and Lyle sugar, and Colman’s Mustard. While some features like double glazing have been updated, auctioneers are concerned that renovation costs may deter developers. David Beddoe, director of Auction Houses Bristol and Somerset North, suggests it would be ideal for a family passionate about antiques. The historic house is set to be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional football career as a backup to Alex Smith for the San Francisco 49ers. After Smith suffered a concussion in the middle of the 2012 season, Kaepernick became the starting quarterback. He remained in that role for the rest of the season and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, ultimately losing to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

The passage provides information about Anne Rice and Route 495. Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo ([teleˈmundo]) is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London, and around Colchester, Essex. He attended the Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon, and together they formed Blur. Blur's debut album, *Leisure*, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. At 17 or 18 years old, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens and remained there until the age of 37 (circa 347 BC). Working animals are typically domesticated animals kept and trained by humans to perform various tasks. They can be close members of the family, such as guide dogs and other assistance dogs, or animals trained to provide pulling power, like draft horses and logging elephants. Some working animals are used for milking or herding, requiring human training to encourage cooperation. Occasionally, wild animals are tamed and trained to perform work, often for novelty or entertainment purposes, but they usually lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament of true domesticated working animals.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view. Morse code is a method of transmitting text information via on-off signals such as tones, lights, or clicks, which can be directly understood by skilled listeners or observers without special equipment. To enhance communication speed, the code is designed so that the length of each character varies inversely with its frequency in English. Compared to voice communication, Morse code is less sensitive to poor signal conditions and remains comprehensible without a decoding device. It is used by amateur radio repeaters for identification, even when they primarily handle voice communications. In emergencies, Morse code can be sent using simple, improvised methods that can be easily keyed on and off, making it one of the simplest and most versatile telecommunication methods.

The Earth's primordial atmosphere and oceans were likely formed by volcanic outgassing, but this early atmosphere contained almost no oxygen and would have been toxic to most modern life, including humans. After his military efforts were unsuccessful, Francis I formed a Franco-Ottoman alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent, a controversial decision for a Christian monarch. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Camden's population consisted mostly of European immigrants. A city is described as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for "The Canyons," an original 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader. The film was critically derided.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and the incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas. These debates were held in seven towns across the state of Illinois.

The passage states that Homer (Ὅμηρος, Hómēros) is the name ascribed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the **Iliad** and the **Odyssey**, two epic poems that are central works of ancient Greek literature. It also mentions that *The Thicket* is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle (1974–2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band consisting of Soundgarden's lead singer and rhythm guitarist Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass and backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007). He started his career drumming for Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, Wilk is playing in the band Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, comprises rapper and vocalist Zack de la Rocha, bassist and backing vocalist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello, and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed debut full-length studio album, **The ArchAndroid**, a concept album sequel to her first EP; it was released by Bad Boy Records.
"Winter's Tale" is a novel by Mark Helprin published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. At the University of Mississippi, about 55% of its undergraduates and 60% of all students come from Mississippi. Additionally, 23% of the students are minorities, and international students represent 90 different nations.
In July 2016, the series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr held several significant political positions: he was elected twice to the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), served as New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), was a U.S. Senator from New York (1791–1797), and ultimately reached the peak of his career as Vice President of the United States.

Soyuz ("Union" in Russian) is a series of spacecraft designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) for the Soviet space program. Originally built as part of the Soviet crewed lunar programs and succeeding the Voskhod spacecraft, Soyuz remains in service today. The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch these spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with eight uncrewed test flights followed by the first 19 crewed launches.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Due to growing tensions over the band's direction, de la Rocha quit Rage Against the Machine, leading to their breakup. De la Rocha pursued a low-key solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, the former frontman of Soundgarden; Audioslave recorded three albums before disbanding in 2007. In the same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in April 2007. "Renegades," the band's fourth studio album, was released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index consisting of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Tata Motors is one of these companies; it is listed on the BSE and is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index. Additionally, Tata Motors is listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (SRV), is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. With an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, it ranks as the world's 14th-most populous country and the ninth-most populous in Asia. Vietnam is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, it has maintained one of the highest economic growth rates globally and, in 2011, held the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film that marks the directorial debut of John Gatins, who also wrote the screenplay.

Bhagat Singh (died 23 March 1931) was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary known for two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India. His execution at age 23 made him a popular folk hero of the Indian independence movement after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's "Dangal," a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (James Stuart) (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) was King of Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death, uniting the Scottish and English crowns. Despite ruling both kingdoms in personal union, Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws. James was a major advocate for a single parliament for England and Scotland but faced many difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was one of the original cast members of the long-running soap opera **Shortland Street**. Cormack is also known for her roles as the Amazon Ephiny in **Xena: Warrior Princess**, Cynthia Ross in **The Cult**, and Shota in **Legend of the Seeker**. Her other work includes the film **Separation City** (2009) and the Australian series **Rake**. She portrayed Sydney underworld figure Kate Leigh in **Underbelly: Razor**. Her most notable recent role was as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama **Wentworth**, in which she starred for four years before leaving the show in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in films such as **Tommy Boy**, **Black Sheep**, **Joe Dirt**, **Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser**, **Grown Ups**, and **Grown Ups 2**. **Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser** is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

"Artpop" is an album that received generally mixed reviews from music critics but was commercially successful. It debuted at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming Lady Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the U.S. and selling 757,000 copies. Additionally, "Artpop" was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 worldwide, with 2.3 million copies sold.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, titled "Stadium Arcadium." This album was also the group's last to feature Frusciante as their guitarist, as he confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher was a Prime Minister who implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She was always a controversial figure but has been lauded as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, even as debates over Thatcherism persist.

Duff McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his musical career, he has established himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns on a variety of topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, in addition to his acting roles, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain. It is the country's third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative centre. Valencia is also Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. Known as the Valencian Community or Valencian Country, the autonomous community shares its name with its capital city.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
"Make It or Break It" concluded with its third and final season, as announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It incorporates knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces like voice dialing ("Call home"), call routing ("I would like to make a collect call"), appliance control, search functions (finding specific spoken words in content), data entry (e.g., entering a credit card number), preparation of structured documents (such as radiology reports), speech-to-text processing (for word processors or emails), and use in aircraft (termed Direct Voice Input). Advances in this field are evidenced by a surge in academic research and widespread industry adoption of deep learning methods in designing speech recognition systems. Major industry players like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC have publicly acknowledged that their speech recognition technologies are based on deep learning.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 – January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International. Beginning in 1970, he served as its chairman. The convention was founded in 1970 as the Golden State Comic Book Convention by a group of San Diegans that included Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. It was later renamed the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," which starred Bruce Lee in the lead role.

In the Turkish Open, France's Victor Dubuisson shot a 67 to tie with South Africa's overnight leader Jaco van Zyl at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland carded his third consecutive five under-par 67 to move to 15 under par, tying with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy, the world number three and four-time major winner, is bidding to win his first title since May. Despite dropping his first shots of the week by three-putting the third and tenth holes—prompting him to throw his putter at his bag—he recovered with a birdie on the 11th and an eagle on the 13th after a towering four iron from 229 yards. Having ruptured a ligament in his left ankle in July, which sidelined him for several tournaments, McIlroy is aiming for his third Race to Dubai title in four years and currently leads England's Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open. English players Chris Wood (-13) and Richard Bland (-12), who were tied for second overnight, are now fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain's al-Wefaq opposition group, told the BBC that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government must offer "concrete solutions" and include representatives who can speak for the royal family. He emphasized working with reformists within the Sunni Muslim royal family, particularly Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who is seen as a proponent of accommodation with the Shia majority. Despite opposition from hardliners led by Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, who has been in power since 1971 and opposes the dialogue process, Sheikh Salman insists that now is the time for dialogue and negotiations.

He acknowledged that many young protesters have lost faith in the main opposition parties, feeling that seeking permission to demonstrate or calling for a constitutional monarchy under the current ruling family is ineffective, especially as they accuse the family of ongoing violence. Sheikh Salman recalled that hours before Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) troops were deployed to suppress dissent on 14 March 2011, the crown prince and the opposition had agreed on a seven-point plan to move Bahrain toward a constitutional monarchy. The arrival of GCC troops, however, severed this dialogue.

Regarding international involvement, Sheikh Salman expressed hope that newly appointed U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry would "do more than his predecessor" by exerting clearer and more direct pressure on Bahrain for human rights and democratic practices. He criticized the UK government's approach, urging Prime Minister David Cameron to speak out publicly against violence and human rights abuses rather than relying on private communications, which he says have been ineffective.

Despite a ban on public gatherings in Bahrain, Sheikh Salman reiterated al-Wefaq's commitment to calling for "peaceful demonstrations" as the only way to pressure the government. He also called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists sentenced to long prison terms based on evidence widely accepted as obtained under torture. He stressed that their inclusion in the dialogue is essential for its success, warning that without them, the dialogue will fail.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, has died at his home in Cambridge after an illness lasting several months, according to a statement on his website. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date.

Hogwood worked with many leading orchestras worldwide and was considered one of the most influential exponents of historically informed performance. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for approximately 30 years, bringing the ensemble to six continents. Under his leadership, the AAM made over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. One of his most famous recordings is the 1980 version of Handel's *Messiah* with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, which was named by **BBC Music Magazine** as one of the top 20 recordings of all time.

Educated at Cambridge University, Hogwood studied keyboard with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts, and later with Zuzana Růžičková and Gustav Leonhardt. Early in his career, he served as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of St Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner and was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London.

Hogwood held several prominent positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also an educator, serving as a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell University in the United States.

Colleagues and admirers paid tribute to Hogwood's legacy. Christopher Purvis, honorary president of the AAM, praised his "extraordinary generosity of spirit" and called him "a great ambassador for historically informed music." Richard Egarr, the AAM's music director, expressed deep sadness at his passing and acknowledged the "fantastic legacy" Hogwood provided. Soprano Dame Emma Kirkby highlighted his academic brilliance and his role in mentoring musicians who now lead orchestras worldwide. David Thomas from Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance remembered him as "a very pleasant and lovely man" who believed in letting "the music speak for itself."

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims—comprising murders and culpable homicides—which is five fewer than the previous 12 months. This figure marks the lowest number of recorded homicides for a single 12-month period since 1976 and is half the number reported nine years earlier. As of 31 March 2016, only one homicide case from 2015-16 remained unresolved.

According to the "Homicide in Scotland" report, sharp instruments were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% (29 cases) of homicides in 2015-16. Nearly all of these incidents (26 out of 29) involved a knife. While the alcohol and drug status of the majority of the accused was unknown, 31% (20 individuals) were identified by police as being under the influence of alcohol or both alcohol and drugs at the time of the offense.

Justice Secretary Michael Matheson acknowledged the encouraging decline in homicide cases and the long-term decrease in violent crime. He emphasized the importance of continuing efforts in education and enforcement to prevent violence, stating that "each of the lives lost is one life too many." Matheson highlighted the need for a collaborative approach across public services to support communities at risk of violent crime and to challenge irresponsible attitudes toward alcohol misuse and casual violence. He affirmed the government's commitment to investing in projects aimed at steering young people away from violence and ensuring that law enforcement agencies have the necessary resources.

Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman, Claire Baker, welcomed the overall downward trend but urged caution in interpreting the statistics. She noted that previous "record low" homicide figures were later revised upwards, revealing an actual increase. Baker also pointed out that sexual crime in Scotland is at a 45-year high and that the past year saw a 27% rise in violent crimes such as attempted murder and serious assault. The number of homicide victims for 2014-15 was initially reported as 59 but was later increased to 62 after three cases were reclassified following deaths.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland on Saturday, becoming the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling gave Bournemouth an early lead with their first goal in three games. However, Sunderland responded with goals from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Despite Sunderland playing with ten men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, Bournemouth couldn't find an equaliser. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration over missed opportunities, stating they had enough chances to win three games and emphasized the importance of moving forward.

Mr. Abbott defended Australia's immigration policy of detaining migrants who attempt to reach its shores by boat, stating that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats." This policy involves sending migrants to offshore processing camps for eventual resettlement elsewhere. The New York Times criticized the policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and "of dubious legality," arguing that it contradicts Australia's tradition of welcoming those fleeing persecution and war. In response to the image of Syrian three-year-old Alan Kurdi, who drowned while trying to reach Greece, Mr. Abbott reiterated that stopping the boats prevents such tragedies.

Additionally, Mr. Abbott sparked controversy by stating that the so-called Islamic State (IS) is worse than the Nazis because, unlike the Nazis who "had a sufficient sense of shame to try to hide" their atrocities, IS militants "boast about their evil." Australian Jewish groups, including Robert Goot of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, criticized the comment as "injudicious and unfortunate," emphasizing the fundamental differences between organized terrorism and state-implemented genocide. Mr. Abbott later stood by his remarks but clarified that he was not "ranking evil."

The United States has suspended bilateral talks with Russia regarding the Syrian ceasefire, accusing Russia and the Syrian government of escalating attacks against civilians, particularly in the city of Aleppo. The suspension follows intensified aerial bombardments on Aleppo after a week-long truce collapsed two weeks prior. U.S. State Department spokesman John Kirby stated that Russia failed to uphold its commitments to cease hostilities and was either unwilling or unable to ensure the Syrian regime's adherence to the agreements. He cited the targeting of critical infrastructure, such as hospitals, and obstruction of humanitarian aid, including a deadly attack on an aid convoy on September 19.

In response, Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova expressed regret over the U.S. decision, accusing Washington of not fulfilling its key obligations to improve humanitarian conditions in Aleppo and of shifting blame for the ceasefire's collapse. She also mentioned the U.S. failure to separate jihadist groups from the moderate opposition. Planned U.S.-Russian coordination on airstrikes against jihadist groups has been halted, with American officials instructed to return home. Despite the suspension of talks, both nations will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria to prevent unintended military clashes.

Think tank Policy Exchange has proposed selling high-value social housing when it becomes vacant to raise £4.5 billion annually. This revenue could fund the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes, potentially creating the largest social housing building program since the 1970s and stimulating the economy. The plan, backed by Downing Street, suggests that expensive social housing—properties worth more than the regional average and accounting for 21.8% of the UK's social housing stock—should be sold to reduce the social housing waiting list by about 500,000 people.

Policy Exchange's director, Neil O'Brien, argues that while people have a right to housing, they don't have a right to live in the most expensive areas at public expense. The government supports councils in using their housing stock more efficiently, including selling high-value properties to invest in more social housing.

Critics, including the Labour Party and housing advocates, contend that the proposal would drive low-income families out of affluent areas, break up mixed communities, and lead to segregated neighborhoods. Labour's Shadow Housing Minister, Jack Dromey, opposes forced sales and suggests using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes, thereby boosting the construction industry and employment. Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports the sell-off and notes the government's efforts to "get Britain building" through a £19.5 billion investment in affordable housing programs expected to deliver up to 170,000 homes.

Amid a measles outbreak in Swansea that has reached 942 cases since November and resulted in 83 hospitalizations, 25-year-old Gareth Colfer-Williams was found dead at his home. While laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, it is unclear if the disease was the main cause of his death, and further tests are pending with an inquest to be opened. According to his mother, Angela Colfer, Gareth had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital. After his discharge, he became unwell and developed a rash "from head to foot" but not on his arms. He consulted an out-of-hours GP on 17 April, and the following morning, he was found dead in his flat. The family is uncertain how he contracted measles, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the illness.

Cumbria Police have charged 54-year-old Vincent Hudson, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, with a historical offence against a boy under the age of 16. The alleged attack is reported to have taken place in 2001. Mr. Hudson is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court later.

Gateshead and Guiseley played to a 1-1 draw in a National League match. Before the game, Gateshead were unbeaten in nine matches under manager Neil Aspin, while Adam Lockwood's Guiseley were unbeaten in five. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored into an empty net after receiving a pass from James Hurst following a throw-in. Gateshead's defender Liam Hogan blocked a shot from Jordan Preston, and Guiseley goalkeeper Jonny Maxted made a save from Wesley York just before halftime. In the 62nd minute, Gateshead equalized when Wes York curled a shot into the top-right corner after a slip by Guiseley substitute Derek Asamoah. Both teams made several substitutions, and yellow cards were issued to Simon Walton of Guiseley and Gus Mafuta of Gateshead. The match concluded with the score at 1-1, extending both teams' unbeaten runs.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase stadium capacity. This redevelopment is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed due to a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed at a shareholder meeting that work would begin, following approval from Bristol City Council in November. The club expects to sign the section 106 agreement imminently and, pending a six-week judicial review period with no challenges, intends to start the redevelopment in May to provide certainty to supporters.

Cuadrilla, a shale gas company, has suspended its fracking operations in Lancashire after a second small earthquake, measuring 1.5 in magnitude, occurred near its drilling site. The first tremor, a magnitude 2.3 quake on 1 April, was centered near Poulton-le-Fylde. Both tremors share a similar location and mechanism, according to the British Geological Survey (BGS). The company is now examining data from the BGS and consulting with authorities before deciding whether to resume drilling.

Fracking involves shattering shale rocks underground to release gas using pressurized water or tiny explosions. While the process has been controversial in the U.S. due to environmental concerns—such as potential groundwater contamination and induced earthquakes—the UK's Commons Energy Select Committee has urged support for fracking, suggesting that environmental issues can be managed with tight regulation and good industry practices.

The BGS noted that injecting pressurized fluids into deep rock formations can cause fractures and potentially induce seismic activity. It is monitoring the situation as a precaution. The latest earthquake occurred approximately 2 km deep and within 2 km of the Preese Hall drilling site. Data from temporary instruments installed after the April quake indicate that both events have similar waveforms, suggesting a shared location and mechanism.

**Summary:**

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign (HJC) banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015. He was acquitted of two other fraud charges by a jury at Liverpool Crown Court. Prosecutors argued that Carpenter gave the impression he was collecting donations for the HJC. In his defense, Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and that the banner was a tribute to the victims of the Hillsborough disaster, not an attempt to deceive anyone. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the HJC, testified that while he had permitted Carpenter to design and display a banner featuring the eternal flame and the word "justice," he had explicitly instructed him not to use it to collect funds for the charity. Carpenter, known as a busker around Anfield on match days, will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 in their Championship match. Grant Ward opened the scoring for Ipswich with a scuffed shot. The second goal came from Luke Varney, who capitalized on a miscue by QPR goalkeeper Alex Smithies to roll the ball into an empty net. Tom Lawrence secured the victory with a calm finish into the corner after collecting a long-range shot from Cole Skuse. QPR struggled offensively but nearly scored when substitute Sandro headed Tjarron Chery's corner against the post late in the game.

The win marked a turnaround for Ipswich, who had struggled to score in previous matches. Manager Mick McCarthy praised the team's performance, highlighting Varney and Jonathan Douglas for their contributions. The victory moved Ipswich up to 14th place in the standings, above QPR, who dropped to 15th.

QPR manager Ian Holloway expressed disappointment in his team's performance, especially after the second goal, and called for his players to be mentally tougher and more cohesive. Despite Smithies' error leading to the second goal, Holloway defended his goalkeeper, emphasizing that the defenders should have provided better support.

Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, impressed in the T20 Blast last season by scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's promising direction and praised the elite performance environment fostered by the coaches, stating that it motivates the players to be part of it.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher commended players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams for leading the team, highlighting that the front row and front five collectively made over 70 tackles. The team faces seven lower-ranked opponents in their next eight games, as well as the league leaders, Old Elthamians. Despite the victory, Churcher believes there is room for improvement, describing the performance against Chinnor as emotionally strong but not complete, and emphasizing the need to build on this success.

Indian police have arrested Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a 28-year-old alleged Bangladeshi citizen, in connection with the rape of a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent school in Ranaghat town on 14 March. Nazrul was apprehended at a railway station in Kolkata after returning from Bangladesh, where he had fled after being identified from CCTV footage. He is the sixth person arrested out of eight identified suspects, with two still untraced; the other five arrested individuals have named Nazrul as the perpetrator of the rape. During the attack, the assailants stole money and ransacked the building before assaulting the nun, an incident that sparked widespread outrage and led to street protests across India. In May, police arrested Milon Sarkar, described as the leader of the gang, though his exact role in the case remains unclear.

The passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. In the video, Opie outlines key reasons behind changes in consumer purchasing habits, highlighting how the arrival of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and the availability of cheaper imports have influenced the products sold and favored by UK consumers. The interactive elements also explore shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands. For users who cannot access the interactive video, non-interactive content is available, including links to additional resources such as articles on China's global ownership stakes, freezing food tips from BBC Good Food, an annual survey of the top 20 UK consumer brands, and information about the Museum of Brands. The video is recommended to be viewed in full-screen mode for the best experience.

Two women in Scotland have fallen victim to telephone scams by individuals posing as BT technical support. On 15 September, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was deceived by someone claiming to work for BT. Seven days later, a woman in Stranraer lost money after a caller alleged issues with her internet service. The scammers gained remote access to the victims' computers and stole substantial amounts of money. PC Siobhan Pellett warned the public about the ease with which scammers can access personal computers and urged people to be cautious of unsolicited calls requesting remote access or banking details. She emphasized that banks and reputable businesses never ask for such information over the phone.

Duffy, 37, has left Swinton Lions to join Featherstone on a one-year contract. As the Scotland assistant coach, he will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised him as a fantastic coach who did a remarkable job at Swinton in difficult circumstances. Duffy, who played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during a 16-year playing career, has been replaced at Swinton by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

On Sunday at 12:50 GMT, a Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve. A female rider was found lying unconscious on wet sand with head injuries and severe cold. She received treatment before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A United Nations conference in Geneva decided to allocate part of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system to address weaknesses exposed by the 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370. Representatives from over 160 countries at the World Radiocommunication Conference, organized by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU), agreed to set aside a radio frequency for the satellite tracking of planes. This allocation will enable satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft—signals that were previously sent only to other aircraft and ground stations—allowing for real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. ITU Secretary-General Houlin Zhao noted the agency's swift response to global concerns on flight tracking. Additionally, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) set a November 2016 deadline to adopt new tracking guidelines, requiring aircraft to transmit their positions at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in August 2002, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Now 18, Julian was identified after encountering problems while applying for college, which led the FBI to receive a tip on October 30. The FBI collaborated with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. His father, Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on a $250,000 bail. He is charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Authorities had suspected at the time of Julian's disappearance that his father was possibly the culprit. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery.

On 2 March, a fire broke out at a site on Duncan Street, leading to reduced train services and travel delays. Firefighters remained at the location for several days. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, operated by Asset and Land Group, from accepting waste. Despite the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) stating that the site operators were "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws and having visited the premises nine times in the past year, the EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit. The firm has until 7 August to appeal this decision and is required to remove all waste from the site. Prior to the fire, GMFRS had raised concerns in February about potential risks to residents, transport, and the environment, which led to joint inspections with the EA and subsequent enforcement action. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin political party, has introduced two bills directly linked to the situation in Ukraine's Crimea region, where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill proposes altering existing Russian law to allow territories to join Russia without the need for a treaty with the neighboring state, especially in cases where that state is disintegrating. Mikhail Yemelyanov, deputy leader of A Just Russia, stated that Russia should not be restricted from accepting territories whose people clearly wish to join Russia.

The second bill aims to expedite the process for Ukrainians to obtain Russian citizenship. It removes requirements such as paying a state tax, previous residence in Russia, sufficient funds for self-support, and renouncing Ukrainian citizenship. The preamble of this bill mentions support for "the fraternal people of Ukraine, especially the Russian-speaking ones, who are defenceless in the face of the 'brown threat'," referencing World War Two fascists.

These legislative efforts coincide with the fact that many in Crimea, particularly in Sevastopol—the base of the Russian Black Sea Fleet—already hold Russian passports. The initiatives also follow Russia's actions in regions like Abkhazia and South Ossetia after the 2008 war with Georgia, where Russia supported pro-Russian separatists. Additionally, prominent Russian MPs and celebrities, including Irina Rodnina, Valentina Tereshkova, and Nikolai Valuev, have visited Crimea, underscoring Russia's heightened involvement in the region.

McLaren, once a dominant force in Formula 1 with 182 grand prix victories, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, has faced a significant decline in recent years. The team's slump began in 2013 due to struggles with chassis design, despite having the best engine at the time. In subsequent years, although improvements were made to the car's chassis, problems with the Honda power unit hindered performance.

Historically, McLaren's partnership with Honda in the late 1980s led to unparalleled success, including winning 15 out of 16 races in 1988 with legendary drivers Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. They continued to dominate into the early 1990s before experiencing a downturn. A resurgence occurred in 1998-99 with Mika Häkkinen and Mercedes engines, but the team's last constructors' title was in 1998.

The team has also endured scandals, notably in 2007 when they were fined $100 million and excluded from the constructors' championship for possessing confidential Ferrari technical information. Another incident in 2009, dubbed "lie-gate," involved driver Lewis Hamilton and led to internal shake-ups.

Ron Dennis, who has been integral to McLaren since taking control in the early 1980s, returned in 2014 to reverse the team's fortunes. Despite having world champions like Fernando Alonso, arguably one of the best drivers on the grid, McLaren has struggled to regain its former glory. Dennis remains confident that success is imminent and believes McLaren will be the next team to break Mercedes' dominance in the sport.

The team's current predicament raises questions about whether they are in a state of terminal decline or poised for a comeback. McLaren's leadership asserts that with continued development and improvements to both the car and the Honda power unit, they will once again achieve championship success. The future of the team, as well as the legacy of its star drivers, hinges on their ability to translate this belief into on-track results.

Thomas "Tommy" Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was found severely injured at Stanley Meat Market in the Old Swan area of Liverpool on 27 January. He had been shot in the head and chest after leaving the Phoenix Gym at the market and getting into his car. Mr. Baker later died in the hospital. 

Three Liverpool men—two aged 29 and one aged 32—have been arrested and remain in police custody for questioning regarding the incident. Detectives believe the assailants had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour before the shooting. 

Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that was seen leaving the scene at high speed, traveling along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Detective Chief Inspector Bev Hyland has noted that several individuals captured on CCTV near the meat market have not yet come forward. She urges them to contact the police, as they may possess information crucial to the investigation.

The passage outlines five innovative ways to experience a more spiritual Christmas online without abandoning modern gadgets:

1. **Everyday Church Online**: Launched in the UK in September, this virtual church hosts online services every Sunday, streaming recorded sermons while congregants from 61 countries chat live. For Christmas, they're presenting Star Wars-themed sermons titled "The Hope Awakens," drawing parallels between the franchise and the message of hope in Christianity.

2. **Guardians of Ancora**: A free fantasy game developed by the Scripture Union for children aged 8 to 11, available on Android, iPhone, and Kindle. Players become guardians in a world where light has been stolen, embarking on quests to rediscover lost Bible stories, including special Christmas content about the birth of Jesus, to bring light back to the world.

3. **Modern Nativity Videos**: Creative retellings of the nativity story are gaining traction online. Notably, Viral.de's 2010 video "The Digital Story of Nativity" narrates the birth of Jesus through modern social media updates and has amassed nearly six million views. Similarly, the Churches Advertising Network produced "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle," showing a couple transitioning through eras to become Mary and Joseph, emphasizing that the essence of Christmas remains unchanged.

4. **Manga Messiah by Next Manga**: After significant success with printed manga-style Bible stories, Next Manga released digital versions of their works, including "Manga Messiah," which portrays the nativity story. Available in 33 languages, they've distributed thousands of copies globally, including 25,000 in Arabic to Syrian and Libyan refugees, aiming to share a message of hope and peace.

5. **Social Media Engagement**: Churches and Christian organizations are increasingly using platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with communities during the festive season. By sharing inspirational thoughts and encouraging people to reflect on spiritual matters, they adapt to contemporary communication methods. Some leaders suggest that if Jesus were here today, he'd utilize social media to spread his message due to his role as a great communicator.

These approaches demonstrate how technology and digital platforms can enrich the spiritual experience of Christmas, making it accessible and engaging for a modern audience while preserving its traditional messages.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a request to take over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land for development. The project's backers, including the Blaenau Gwent council, have proposed offering 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. Experts have presented conflicting opinions on whether building on the common land would harm habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales stated it is "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land holds equal value but is not opposing the overall development. An ecology report from the developers claims there will be a "net gain" in biodiversity due to plans to enhance nearby habitats, a point contested by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers ultimately deciding whether the plans can proceed.

On April 1, Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 men suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three reported deaths. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed these allegations, stating that detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a facility near Argun, and is assisting victims in fleeing the region. Chechen authorities, including leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesperson, denied the claims, asserting that there are no gay people in Chechnya.

In response to the report, Chechen Muslim clerics held a meeting on April 3, condemning the newspaper's allegations as an insult to their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. They issued a resolution stating that "retribution will catch up with the true instigators, wherever and whoever they are," which Novaya Gazeta interpreted as a call for reprisals against its journalists. The newspaper urged Russian authorities to prevent incitement of hatred towards journalists fulfilling their professional duties.

Novaya Gazeta's editor-in-chief, Dmitry Muratov, affirmed the paper's commitment to investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya and emphasized that they had no intention of insulting the Chechen people, calling for dialogue. The situation is underscored by past unresolved murders of Novaya Gazeta reporters Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova, who had investigated crimes in Chechnya, as well as the killing of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. The Russian LGBT Network warned that if Russian authorities fail to prosecute those responsible for the abuses, it intends to bring the case to the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

Investing Solutions is a London-based letting agency that has received substantial housing benefit payments over the past two years by providing accommodation for single homeless men over the age of 35. The charity Fresh Start Housing, founded by the same individual, Samir Patel, refers clients from London homeless charities to Investing Solutions. Although both organizations operate legally, homeless groups have criticized their relationship, labeling it "a new low."

Investing Solutions profits by placing several unrelated tenants in a single property and claiming housing benefit for each individual, rather than for the property as a whole. This approach results in total benefit payouts that exceed the rent paid to landlords. For example, in one case, the agency claimed £2,114 per month in housing benefits for two tenants while paying the property's owner £1,150 per month, yielding an annual gross profit of £11,568 on that property.

The agency operates across seven London boroughs and has become one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK. Tenants like Nigel McCann have reported substandard living conditions, including lack of heating, infestations, and dampness. McCann criticized Investing Solutions for prioritizing profit over tenant welfare.

Wandsworth Council, among others, has paid significant sums to Investing Solutions—over £2.1 million in the past two years. While Samir Patel asserts that Fresh Start Housing is an independent charity with its own board of trustees and that most rents are passed to private landlords, concerns persist. Homelessness charity Crisis expressed alarm over the practice of linking a charity to profit-driven activities. The Department for Communities and Local Government emphasized that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money and ensuring the private rented sector remains safe and affordable.

Great Britain's men's basketball team was defeated by the Netherlands in their final warm-up match before the Eurobasket qualifying campaign. Despite leading for most of the first three quarters—highlighted by Andrew Lawrence's 14 points and Ben Gordon's 13 points, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter—they were overtaken in the last 10 minutes. The Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, started the fourth quarter with a 10-point run to lead 71-60 and held on to win despite GB's late comeback. Coach Joe Prunty noted that the team lost some of their fire during the game but was pleased with Gordon's performance. GB will begin their Eurobasket qualifiers with a game in Hungary in midweek.

Conor McGregor has submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves for his upcoming 154-pound boxing match against Floyd Mayweather. This move is unusual for the weight class, as NAC rules typically require 10oz gloves for fights at this weight to ensure fighter safety. The NAC will debate the request on 16 August, considering that lighter gloves can lead to more punishing punches due to less cushioning.

Floyd Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for this bout, had previously expressed his willingness to wear 8oz gloves via an Instagram post but had not submitted the necessary paperwork until now. Both fighters seem to prefer the lighter gloves, with McGregor, accustomed to 4oz gloves in his UFC career, eagerly accepting the proposal.

Despite criticism from notable boxing figures like Oscar De La Hoya and Gennady Golovkin regarding the legitimacy of the matchup, NAC Executive Director Bob Bennett approved the fight. Bennett cited several factors: McGregor's impressive performance against Nate Diaz—who is highly regarded as a boxer by trainer Virgil Hunter—his age advantage (being 12 years younger than Mayweather), and his physical attributes such as height and reach. He also noted Mayweather's lack of recent knockouts, with his last true knockout occurring in 2007 against Ricky Hatton.

To prepare for the transition from MMA to boxing, McGregor's team hired Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez to help them understand boxing rules and etiquette. During training, an intense sparring session between McGregor and former two-weight world champion Paulie Malignaggi, overseen by Cortez, led to controversy. Images surfaced showing Malignaggi on the canvas, which he claimed were misleading, prompting him to leave McGregor's camp.

The fight is poised to be one of the richest in history, marking McGregor's professional boxing debut and adding to Mayweather's storied career. The NAC's upcoming decision on the glove size could impact the dynamics of the match, emphasizing the ongoing negotiations and preparations leading up to the highly anticipated event.

The passage discusses the closure of the Sunday Post's London office on Fleet Street, marking the end of journalism's physical presence on the street historically synonymous with British newspapers. Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked there for decades, reflect on Fleet Street's rich history and its transformation over time. They share anecdotes about the vibrant journalism culture, including bustling newsrooms filled with typewriter clatter, smoke-filled rooms, and socializing in iconic pubs like El Vino. Ex-Sunday Express editor Robin Esser highlights Fleet Street's significance as the primary source of public information before television and social media. Journalist Liz Hodgkinson recounts her experiences as one of the few women in a male-dominated industry during the 1970s and 80s, emphasizing the pervasive drinking culture. The decline of Fleet Street began when media mogul Rupert Murdoch moved his newspapers to Wapping in 1986, leading other publishers to relocate and signaling a shift to new technologies. The buildings left behind have since been repurposed, symbolizing the end of an era in British journalism.

J.K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter series, addressed both supportive and abusive comments on Twitter regarding her political views. After donating £1 million to the campaign against Scottish independence in 2014 and the same amount to the Labour Party in 2008, she faced significant criticism, including being called a "traitor" by some Scottish National Party (SNP) supporters. Rowling expressed that her "personal line had been crossed" by abusive remarks and emphasized the importance of standing up to bullies. Despite the negativity, she acknowledged kind interactions with respectful SNP supporters and noted shared political beliefs with many of them. When a user suggested her books should be burned, she humorously replied that she would "bring marshmallows." The SNP had recently secured 56 of the 59 Scottish seats in the UK's general election, becoming the third-largest party in the country.

A study conducted by the University of Edinburgh, tracking 4,300 young people since 1998, has found that poverty significantly increases the likelihood of youth offending and encounters with the police in Scotland. Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and about five times more likely to be placed under statutory supervision compared to their more affluent peers committing the same offenses. Poverty also exacerbates the risk of violence among both boys and girls. While boys are generally three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, girls from poorer households are twice as likely to be involved in violent crime as those from wealthier backgrounds, even when accounting for factors like truancy, substance abuse, and poor parental supervision.

The research indicates that a history of trouble with the police is the strongest predictor of a young person being not in education, employment, or training (NEET) by age 18. It suggests that involvement with the juvenile justice system may inadvertently reinforce the conditions that perpetuate violence. Another study by the Applied Quantitative Methods Network (AQMeN) reveals that despite overall crime rates in Scotland reaching a 41-year low, the most deprived communities have not benefited from this decline. Crime remains highly concentrated among poor individuals and neighborhoods, which also suffer from high levels of chronic health problems and unemployment.

These findings raise concerns about whether the Scottish government is effectively addressing inequality. In response, a government spokesman emphasized that Scotland has become safer, with significant reductions in recorded crime and homicide rates, and highlighted a £296 million investment aimed at mitigating poverty and inequality to protect the most vulnerable in society.

A 25-year-old man named Mr. Haugh was fatally stabbed in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh, from Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody until August 14. Two other men arrested in connection with the incident were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

At Ennis District Court, Detective Sergeant Padraig Frawley stated that it is alleged Mr. Walsh was one of three individuals who entered the Marian Estate in Kilkee shortly after 1:00 AM on Sunday, seeking Mr. Haugh. An altercation ensued when they encountered Mr. Haugh and another man, involving weapons such as knives and golf clubs. Additional individuals reportedly joined the fight during which Mr. Haugh sustained a stab wound to his back.

Emergency services arrived at the scene, recovering knives and golf clubs, as well as a knife handle and a blood-stained blade. Mr. Haugh was transported to Limerick University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 6:00 AM. The court noted that tensions have risen in the Kilkee area following the incident, leading to Mr. Walsh's remand in custody.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan of Sinn Féin tweeted after Tom Elliott, now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, appeared on a BBC radio programme with Steven Nolan. In the tweet, Flanagan suggested that Elliott had harassed and shot people during his service in the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) between 1982 and 1992. The tweet was deleted within an hour after Elliott, who has a clear Ministry of Defence record, was alerted to it by victims' campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster.

Legal action ensued, and Flanagan is required to post an apology on Twitter acknowledging that his statement about Elliott was "untrue and wholly without foundation." Mr Justice Stevens has reserved judgment on the amount of compensation to be awarded. Additionally, the insurance firm that indemnifies MLAs at Stormont has refused to cover Flanagan's compensation and legal costs, a decision he is challenging in a separate court action.

In a statement, Tom Elliott expressed satisfaction with the outcome, stating he felt "totally vindicated" but was disappointed it took so long to resolve. He remarked that the issue could have been settled 19 months earlier but was pleased with the result despite the delay.

Hawick Knitwear, a company established in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has increased its weekly sweater production from approximately 7,500 to 9,500 to meet rising demand. The surge is attributed to better-than-expected sales of its newly launched Hawick Knitwear-branded range in January and growth in its long-standing private label business, supplying garments to customers who sell them under their own brands. Acquired by Managing Director Benny Hartop in November of the previous year, the company distributes its products across various European countries—including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain—as well as to markets outside Europe such as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Mr. Hartop expressed optimism about the company's future, highlighting the dedicated staff's contribution to its success and anticipating continued growth driven by increased orders domestically and internationally.

In December, 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Brian Wright, 55, admitted in Luton Crown Court to hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. At the time of the incident, Mrs. Blackburn was on duty assisting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road after the traffic lights turned red. Prosecutors stated that while traffic in the opposite direction had stopped, Mr. Wright's vehicle failed to stop at the red light and struck her. Mr. Wright expressed deep remorse in court, acknowledging the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing, and Mrs. Blackburn is currently receiving care in a residential facility.

In response to increased Russian submarine activity in European waters, NATO is conducting a significant anti-submarine warfare exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose" in the North Atlantic. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and the Royal Navy's HMS Portland, working collaboratively to locate and track the German submarine U33, which is simulating an adversary. U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf with a crew of 28, operates stealthily beneath the waves, posing a formidable challenge to the surface ships and highlighting the difficulty of detecting modern submarines—often compared to finding a needle in a haystack.

The exercise underscores growing concerns about Russia's expanding and technologically advanced submarine fleet, now numbering around 60 vessels, including both nuclear-powered and diesel-electric submarines capable of operating in shallow waters. Russia has recently launched what it claims to be the "quietest submarine in the world," further intensifying NATO's focus on submarine detection capabilities. Experts like Peter Roberts from the Royal United Services Institute (RUSI) recognize that Russian submarines are among the most advanced and elusive globally, with highly skilled crews capable of remaining undetected for extended periods while gathering intelligence on other nations' naval activities.

"Dynamic Mongoose" also brings attention to the critical gaps in the United Kingdom's maritime defenses. Since the retirement of its Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft, the UK lacks dedicated long-range aircraft capable of anti-submarine surveillance, forcing reliance on NATO allies for aerial support when Russian submarines are suspected near British waters. This absence represents a key vulnerability, especially concerning the protection of the UK's nuclear deterrent as it departs from Faslane naval base in Scotland. The forthcoming government defense and security review is expected to address this shortfall. Overall, the exercise emphasizes the importance of international collaboration in enhancing anti-submarine warfare readiness, acknowledging that detecting modern Russian submarines is a complex challenge that demands advanced technology and coordinated efforts.

The United Nations warns that South Sudan faces the potential of genocide and ethnic cleansing amid escalating violence. Since July, when fighting erupted in the capital, Juba, and spread to the previously peaceful southern Equatoria states, around 340,000 South Sudanese have fled to neighboring Uganda—surpassing the number of refugees from any other country this year, including Syria. An average of 2,500 refugees cross into Uganda daily, recounting harrowing experiences of killings, sexual violence, and ethnically targeted attacks.

The conflict, initially a power struggle between President Salva Kiir of the Dinka ethnic group and former Vice-President Riek Machar of the Nuer group, has evolved into widespread ethnic violence. Equatorians, who were not primary targets earlier, have been increasingly attacked since July. Refugees like Nelson Ladu Thomas describe atrocities committed against civilians, including murder and assault, particularly against men and boys, while women and girls face rape and other abuses.

Uganda has responded by providing land and resources to the influx of refugees. Families receive plots of land and materials to build shelters and cultivate crops within 36 hours of arrival. The Bidi Bidi settlement, once a village, has become one of the world's largest refugee camps, housing over a quarter of a million people across 250 square kilometers. Despite Uganda's generous efforts, the sheer number of refugees—now nearing a million—strains resources, with challenges in providing essential services like water and education.

Humanitarian agencies emphasize the urgency of international intervention to halt the violence in South Sudan. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees highlights the dire situation, calling for global attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop what is described as a massacre of civilians on all sides. The refugees' stories underscore the severe humanitarian crisis and the deep trauma affecting countless individuals, especially children, who make up a significant portion of the displaced population.

McKenzie, 38, is scheduled to fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. Formerly associated with Norwich and Peterborough football clubs, he switched to professional boxing in 2013 after leaving football in 2011. McKenzie has a boxing record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a former three-time world champion.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is slated for redevelopment as part of the coalition government's £330 million investment in new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will cost £33 million, with funding contributions from NHS Somerset and the Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust covering the remaining balance not provided by the government. Planned features include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners.

The existing hospital, built in 1813, has become cramped and outdated. Matron Sue Taylor expressed that the building's poor conditions impact patient recovery, emphasizing the need for a modern facility. Over the past five years, three out of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and construction has begun on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton.

Dr. Donal Hynes, a Bridgwater GP and medical director at Somerset Primary Care Trust, highlighted that the new hospital will significantly enhance patient care by providing a comprehensive range of services in a "one-stop shop" setting. Somerset PCT intends to build the hospital on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with the goal of completing the project by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot near Sheffield's city centre on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe. He was either inside or close to a black Mercedes he had been driving when the incident occurred around 13:35 GMT. Officers found him with a gunshot wound to the chest; despite being taken to Northern General Hospital, he died from his injuries. Local residents noted that the man was part of a family living nearby and that relatives had gathered for a celebration when the attack happened. Many family members rushed out to assist after hearing the shot. This tragedy follows a series of shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, though previous incidents occurred in the northern parts of the city, not near Upperthorpe.

The passage highlights the significant role of hacker groups in the cyber warfare accompanying the Ukraine conflict. Key among these are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, the pro-Russian Cyber Berkut, and the Russian activist group Anonymous International.

**Ukrainian Cyber Troops**: Led by Kiev-based programmer Yevhen Dokukin, this pro-Ukrainian hacker group targets Russian interests. They claim to have hacked Russian interior ministry servers and police emails, allegedly uncovering evidence of Russian military involvement in Ukraine. Utilizing distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, they disable rebel websites and disrupt separatist funding by targeting electronic payment systems like PayPal and WebMoney. They also monitor troop movements by hacking into public CCTV systems in rebel-held eastern Ukraine and have hijacked network printers to disseminate pro-Ukrainian messages and messages insulting Russian President Vladimir Putin. Ukrainian officials deny using information from hackers for military operations.

**Cyber Berkut**: A pro-Russian group named after the former Ukrainian riot police, Cyber Berkut opposes Ukraine's government and Western influence. Their activities aim to thwart Ukrainian military plans, which they describe as "genocide" instigated by the West. During U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden's visit to Kiev, they hacked Ukrainian government websites, displaying messages accusing him of supporting fascists. They claim to have obtained confidential U.S. documents detailing military assistance to Ukraine by hacking a mobile device from Biden's team. Cyber Berkut has also hijacked electronic billboards in Kiev to display graphic anti-government content, disrupted electronic vote-counting systems before parliamentary elections, leaked alleged defense ministry data on losses and desertions, and claimed responsibility for blocking President Petro Poroshenko's website. They assert possession of hacked communications suggesting Ukrainian forces downed Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, though this remains unverified.

**Anonymous International (b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay)**: This Russian activist group is known for leaking Kremlin documents. It is unclear whether they obtain materials through hacking or from insiders. While focusing on Russia's domestic affairs, they have released content related to Ukraine, including a letter from a Russian fighter indicating a lack of local support for separatist forces and leaked emails involving Igor Girkin (also known as Strelkov), a former Russian FSB colonel and key rebel commander in eastern Ukraine. Their website is currently blocked in Russia.

The passage underscores the extent to which cyber warfare has become a tool for both sides in the Ukraine conflict, used to influence public opinion, gather intelligence, and disrupt adversary activities. These cyber activities are reported and analyzed by BBC Monitoring, which aggregates news from various global media sources.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran MSPs Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie delivered their farewell speeches ahead of the Scottish Parliament election on 5 May. Former First Minister Alex Salmond reiterated his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," highlighting a consensus on the need for the parliament to assume greater governance responsibilities. While welcoming new powers under the Scotland Bill, he argued that they did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. Salmond added humor by referencing the Chancellor's UK budget speech and the Cheltenham races, concluding with, "It's goodbye from me... for now." Marwick praised his service to the parliament and Scotland.

Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, serving since the parliament's establishment in 1999, moved Marwick to tears with his powerful speech. He urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster, particularly in enhancing accountability and scrutiny through its committee system, warning that failure to do so would have consequences. Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bade farewell, joking she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney's "huge outbursts of faux indignation."

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care provided to older people in residential care homes across Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their families, and friends to share their experiences, with the aim of using this evidence to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, highlighting both good practices and the impact of poor care.

While Rochira has observed positive effects of high-quality care during her visits across Wales, she also notes unacceptable variations in care quality. Her team plans to engage not only with residents and their families but also with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the situation.

Mario Kreft, Chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the overall goals of the review but expresses disappointment that the advisory panel lacks representation from provider experts—individuals who have lived in, worked in, managed, or owned care homes. He believes that their absence is a missed opportunity for partnership and full engagement with the sector.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company specializing in manufacturing and supplying animal feeds for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors, reported an increase in pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million. The company experienced growth in international sales in Europe and new markets further afield. Harbro also operates 19 Country Store branded shops across Scotland, catering to farming and rural communities with products like fireside supplies, country clothing, and footwear. In accounts filed with Companies House, Harbro noted the unpredictability of the agricultural outlook and acknowledged challenging times over the past 12–18 months but expressed confidence in the robustness of the industry and its preparedness for potential business challenges arising from Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. Another man in his 80s was taken to the hospital, according to a police spokeswoman. Detectives are treating the death as a murder and are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker. The public is warned not to approach him. Detective Chief Inspector Martin Brunning from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, and Hertfordshire major crime unit stated that the investigation is in its early stages but emphasized the urgency in locating McLoughlin. McLoughlin is described as a white male, approximately 6 feet (1.8 meters) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and an average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter-length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Authorities urge anyone with information to contact the police or Crimestoppers. Additional police patrols are being conducted in the area to reassure residents.

David Lipton, the second-in-command at the IMF, warned of a weakening global economic outlook during a speech to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington. Citing the IMF's latest readings, he stated that the global economy shows a "weakening baseline" and is "clearly at a delicate juncture." His remarks followed disappointing trade figures from China, where exports plunged by 25% compared to the previous year. As a result, the IMF is likely to downgrade its current global growth forecast of 3.4% in its upcoming April predictions. This grim scenario has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that have relied on China's growth.
