Symptoms often include red, scaly skin that can be itchy, sensitive, or raw. There is no cure, but symptoms can improve over time with proper skin care management. Valerie hopes that increased awareness of the condition will reduce stigma and misconceptions, allowing RJ to lead a more accepted and inclusive life. RJ's siblings are supportive, helping him and standing up against bullies, and Valerie remains devoted to caring for her son despite the hardships.

Campaigners are celebrating the removal of Protein World's controversial "Are you beach body ready?" advertisements from the London Underground. The ads featured 24-year-old model Renee Somerfield in a bikini and prompted backlash from feminists and body image activists who argued that the posters promoted unhealthy body images and sexism. A Change.org petition demanding the removal of the ads collected over 50,000 signatures, and the Advertising Standards Authority received more than 200 complaints.

Transport for London (TfL) confirmed that the ads are being taken down as the three-week advertising period has ended. TfL stated they would consider public reactions for future advertising approvals. The posters had been defaced by activists, and a protest is planned in Hyde Park on May 2.

Protein World defended their campaign vigorously on social media, responding sharply to critics. Richard Staveley, the company's Head of Global Marketing, appeared on "Good Morning Britain" where presenter Susanna Reid described the ads as "anxiety-inducing." Staveley defended the campaign's intent to encourage fitness and health but revealed that the company had received violent threats, including a bomb threat now under police investigation.

Public figures are divided on the issue: while critics continue to voice concerns over body image and the advertisement's messaging, personalities like Katie Hopkins and writer Samantha Brick have expressed support for the campaign, with Brick stating the ad motivated her personally.

Rail companies are planning significant fare increases of up to 87% starting May 17, just ten days after the general election, despite pledges from major political party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has personally intervened by writing to First Great Western (FGW), requesting an urgent review of its decision to nearly double certain fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds—an area that includes his Witney constituency.

Currently, passengers traveling from Charlbury, the station nearest to Cameron's constituency home, can purchase an off-peak return ticket to London for £33.30. This ticket allows them to depart after the morning peak and return during the evening peak period. However, from May 17, the cost for those wishing to return on evening peak trains will rise to £62.40, marking an 87% increase. FGW states that the fare changes are intended to align the North Cotswolds route with its other services and notes that some customers may find cheaper options with advanced single tickets.

Other notable fare increases include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton on London Midlands rising from £30 to £37, and the cost of an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin increasing from £26.50 to £33—a 24.5% hike. Virgin has mentioned that the majority of its price increases affect "Virgin Trains-only fares," which remain at least 20% cheaper than tickets offered by rival firms.

Train companies have three opportunities each year to raise "unregulated" fares, which comprise about half of their total revenue and include off-peak leisure and advance-purchase tickets. These planned increases have drawn criticism from passengers and politicians alike, particularly in light of promises from leaders like Cameron and the Labour Party to freeze or cap fare prices in real terms for the upcoming parliamentary term.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in his left eye after vandals hurled bricks at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. On April 18, while John and his new wife Elaine, 54, were writing thank-you cards for their recent wedding gifts, thugs began throwing stones at their front window. When a brick smashed the glass, John opened the front door to confront them and was struck in the eye by another brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors couldn't save his eyesight in that eye. Feeling unsafe, the couple plans to move away. Police are investigating the unprovoked attack, suspecting it might be a case of reckless vandalism, and are appealing for any information.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully returning from injury. Poynton, 25, missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident last April in which his father, Keith, died. After undergoing an ankle operation, he made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season. He is now committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing confidence that the new contract will boost his performance this summer.

Five-year-old **Harley Renshaw** from Stretford has been declared cancer-free after a year-long battle with **neuroblastoma**, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting specialized nerve cells. Diagnosed when he complained of stomach pain, doctors found cancer in his **kidney, neck, lungs, and bones**. 

To help him feel brave during his treatment, Harley decorated his protective radiotherapy mask to resemble a **Ninja Turtle**, his favorite superhero. This act of courage captured the hearts of hospital staff and garnered international attention. The children's TV channel **Nickelodeon** sent him a box of Ninja Turtle gifts for Christmas in support.

Harley's intensive treatment journey included **80 days of chemotherapy**, surgery to remove the kidney tumor, a **stem cell transplant**, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. Despite complications, he returned home in time for his fifth birthday.

His bravery earned him one of Cancer Research UK's **Little Star Awards**, and he became the face of the charity's **Kids and Teens campaign**, aiming to raise funds for research into childhood cancers. His parents, Oliver and Stacey, expressed immense joy and are looking forward to his return to school and a healthy future. Harley will continue to have regular check-ups to ensure he remains cancer-free.

**Neuroblastoma** affects fewer than 100 children annually in the UK, mostly under five years old, and is the second most common solid tumor in childhood. It originates in specialized nerve cells involved in the development of the nervous system, commonly starting in the adrenal glands or alongside the spinal cord. Symptoms vary based on the tumor's location and can include tiredness, loss of appetite, bone pain, and swelling in the abdomen or neck.

Treatment depends on the child's age, tumor size and position, and disease spread. Options include **surgery**, **chemotherapy**, **radiotherapy**, and **antibody treatments**. Early detection is challenging due to vague initial symptoms, highlighting the importance of awareness and research supported by campaigns like Cancer Research UK's Kids & Teens.

Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood has urged 19-year-old midfielder Jack Grealish to focus on his club career rather than his international future. Grealish impressed during Villa's 2-1 FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, which has intensified interest from both the Republic of Ireland and England national teams. Sherwood emphasized that the choice of which country to represent is entirely up to Grealish and advised him to follow his heart when making the decision. Drawing a parallel with former Tottenham player Nabil Bentaleb's choice between France and Algeria, Sherwood stressed the importance of personal identity in such decisions. Grealish's father, Kevin, agreed with Sherwood, stating that Jack should concentrate on his performances for Aston Villa and that international opportunities will follow. Although Grealish has represented Ireland at youth levels, he remains undecided and is expected to make his choice at the end of the season.

Private jet landing fees vary widely across airports, with some unexpected locations charging the highest rates. The most expensive airports for landing a private jet, based on fees for a Boeing 767-400 aircraft, are predominantly in Japan. Tokyo's Haneda Airport tops the list at £4,559 ($6,850), followed by Narita International Airport at £3,728 ($5,600) and Osaka's Kansai International Airport at £3,594 ($5,400). Other airports in the top ten include Toronto Pearson International Airport (£3,461), Darwin International Airport in Australia (£3,059), Bristol Airport in England (£2,929), Chūbu Centrair International Airport in Nagoya, Japan (£2,863), Dublin Airport in Ireland (£2,729), LaGuardia Airport in New York (£2,630), and Salzburg Airport in Austria (£2,530).

The high landing fees highlight the growing trend of private jet travel among the wealthy, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US and 705,000 in Europe in 2013. The private jet market is substantial, valued at $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. Major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix are peak times for private jet travel, resulting in higher costs and busier schedules for private jet companies. Popular routes include short trips such as Los Angeles to Las Vegas, costing around £2,890 ($4,340), and Milan to Rome in Europe, costing about $5,880 one way.

Surprisingly, some smaller or less expected airports like Bristol in the UK and Salzburg in Austria feature among the most expensive for landing fees. These high charges provide insight into the popularity of certain transport hubs among the rich and famous, reflecting the exclusive nature and significant expenses associated with private jet travel.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her two dogs, Cooper the Labrador and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy, the smaller female pup, takes delicate licks of her cone, Cooper devours his in one bite. A video of this outing has been viewed over seven million times. Despite some viewers criticizing Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, she defends the treat, noting that Cooper is healthy and active, and that her previous dog lived to 19 years old enjoying similar treats. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, often ensures Daisy eats first due to Cooper's quick eating habits. In another video, the duo visits Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," a cup of whipped cream without coffee, which Cooper also consumes rapidly.

Gary Locke, the former Hearts manager, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after signing a three-year deal. Initially joining the club last summer as assistant to Allan Johnston, Locke took over as interim manager when Johnston resigned at the start of February. The 41-year-old has led the team to lose just once in seven games since taking charge at Rugby Park. Locke will speak at a press conference on Friday morning and was seen shaking hands with chairman Jim Mann after signing his contract.

Jessica Kemp, a 32-year-old mother from Eustis, Florida, claims that Seminole County Elementary School threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because he wears DoTerra essential oils to help manage his condition. The teachers stated that the oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, smell and distract other students. Kemp applies the oils to Logan's head and neck to keep him calm and focused and says he has been using them all year until a teacher's aide complained. She received a letter from the school board stating the oils had created a "problem" for staff and students. Despite the threat, Kemp intends to continue using the oils, asserting their positive impact on her son. The Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, referring to it as a "health issue."

A beach-side apartment complex, the Sandpiper complex in Westhampton Beach, was destroyed by a massive fire on Wednesday at 3 p.m. The blaze spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed, melting paint off nearby structures due to its intensity. Twelve fire teams were deployed but were unable to enter the summer homes to control the flames. The cause of the fire is unknown, but authorities are investigating reports that it started near a car parked by the complex. Residents, including apartment owner Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, expressed shock and grief over the loss of their homes and belongings. Witnesses reported seeing flames from three miles away. The Sandpiper complex, used as a holiday home between May and November, is now completely obliterated.

Despite approaching her 89th birthday, Queen Elizabeth II, 88, was seen enjoying a ride in the spring sunshine on her faithful black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Accompanied by a groom on another Fell pony, the Queen opted to wear a silk headscarf instead of a riding helmet, a practice she has maintained throughout her life. She has been encouraged to wear safety hats but is reportedly reluctant due to her hair, once remarking to her racing trainer Ian Balding, "I never have and you don't have to have your hair done like I do."

Her Majesty's love of horses began at age four when she was given a Shetland pony named Peggy. Over the years, the royal stables have housed many of her beloved mounts, including Betsy and Surprise. Although a knee injury has led her to ride less in recent years, the Queen remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and continues to breed several breeds of horses and ponies. She breeds Fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud and Highland ponies at Balmoral, with some being ridden by her grandchildren, Lady Louise and James, Viscount Severn.

Fell ponies, like Carltonlima Emma, are one of the oldest equine breeds, having roamed the moors of Cumbria since the Neolithic period. Docile, hardy, and typically black, grey, or bay, they stand between 13 and 14 hands high. Historically prized by the Carvetii tribe, they were later used by Romans, Vikings, and Normans as pack animals and played a significant role in British trade until the 18th century. In the 1950s, their gentle nature and appealing looks made them popular riding ponies for families—a tradition that continues today, with the Queen among their admirers and breeders.

A dispute between two neighbors in North Brisbane over noise levels resulted in tragedy when 55-year-old Leon Yeaman was allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old shift worker and father of three, Phillip Pama. Around 9 p.m. on Thursday night, Yeaman was reportedly making excessive noise in his yard on Muller Road, disturbing Pama, who was sleeping before his early morning shift. Confronting Yeaman, the situation escalated, and Pama struck him. Despite efforts from paramedics, Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 p.m. Pama, who has no history of violence and was described as "beside himself" with grief, was charged with manslaughter. Granted conditional bail, he surrendered his passport, is under a curfew, and must report to the police twice a week. Neighbors remembered Yeaman as kind and generous, while a friend noted he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed playing loud music. The case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old student and former lover, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship for a classmate. Offering 100,000 rubles (£1,400), she specified to the undercover officer—posing as the hitman—that she wanted Vanya to suffer unbearable pain, with broken arms and legs and damaged kidneys to cause him to bleed to death, before she would "finish him" herself. The police conducted a sting operation, secretly recording the exchange. After she handed over expense money, Simonova was arrested, searched, and charged with attempted murder, now facing up to 15 years in prison. Vanya expressed relief at her arrest, hoping authorities would "throw away the key."

José Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, revealed that he talks to God every day about his personal life but never about football, and he does not discuss the game with his wife. Emphasizing his strong faith, Mourinho prays daily and attends church when he feels the need, especially when in Portugal. He strives to keep his professional and family life separate, claiming to be a good family person and friend who supports others, even those he doesn't know. Despite his intense and sometimes arrogant demeanor on the sidelines, he insists he is a good person who acknowledges making mistakes in the competitive and emotional world of professional football. His family is aware of poverty, and they have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. At the time of the interview, Chelsea was top of the league and preparing to play Queens Park Rangers. Earlier in the season, Mourinho was fined £25,000 by football authorities for alleging a "campaign" against Chelsea after a player was booked for diving.

Bob Barker, the legendary former host of "The Price is Right," returned to the show for the first time in eight years on the April 1 episode. At 91 years old, Barker appeared energetic as he hosted the first price-guessing game, the classic "Lucky Seven." He then handed the hosting duties back to Drew Carey, who completed the rest of the show. Despite his long absence, Barker didn't seem to miss a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent named Arthur Baldwin was arrested early Friday morning in Washington, D.C., after allegedly attempting to break into a house around midnight. He was taken into custody by the Metropolitan Police on charges of attempted burglary, a felony, and destruction of property. Following his arrest, the Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the agency's Foreign Missions Branch, which collaborates with the State Department on U.S. diplomatic activities. His arrest comes shortly after another high-ranking supervisor in the agency was placed on leave amid allegations of misconduct, which are being investigated by the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general. These incidents are part of a series of challenges faced by the Secret Service, including an ongoing investigation into a separate March 4 incident involving two senior officials accused of driving into a secure area at the White House after a night of drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture close-up images of a hungry male lion at Lahore's safari park. Spotting the lion in the distance, Saeed exited his car and approached to within 10 feet, lying on the ground armed only with his camera. The clicking sound of the shutter alerted the lion, which began to treat Saeed as prey and aggressively charged toward him. Saeed managed to scramble back into his car just in time. Reflecting on the close encounter, he admitted that while he laughed at the time, he wouldn't attempt such a risky endeavor again.

New York City police are seeking help to identify a deceased woman found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend area of Brooklyn. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, had no identification but bore a distinctive tattoo on her right leg: the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. The NYPD has released images of the faded tattoo and a rendering of its original appearance to aid in identification. Authorities are awaiting the medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death. Anyone with information is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

After returning to New Zealand from the UK in 2009, Hannah and Alex needed a home but couldn't afford to buy property. They purchased a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent a year and a half transforming it into a solar-powered, two-bedroom house made of wood and steel. Located on a lot they bought in Nelson, New Zealand, their $25,000 home features cypress wood interiors, a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is surrounded by nature with majestic trees and a babbling brook nearby. The couple lives nearly self-sufficiently, with most of their electricity coming from solar panels and water sourced from a nearby spring. They are pleased with their cozy home and even plan to build another similar one in the future.

Researchers have found that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests than those who use iPads individually or do not use them at all. Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University conducted a study with 352 kindergarten students in a Midwestern suburban school district. The results showed that students who shared iPads scored around 30 points higher than their peers. Blackwell suggests that the collaborative learning experience around the technology enhances literacy outcomes. She recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are utilized, especially in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness. Blackwell is scheduled to present her findings at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without its hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front legs. Owned by farmer Ms. Duan, the piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," has mastered balancing on its front trotters. A heartwarming video featured on People's Daily Online shows the piglet taking unsteady steps, wobbling as it forages for food with its snout to the ground. Despite appearing close to tipping over at times, it always regains its balance and happily interacts with its fully limbed siblings. Villagers have flocked to see the unusual animal since its birth. This piglet's story follows other inspiring tales, such as a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo in Guangxi Province that has become a star attraction by hopping on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when driver Francesco Dracone's car struck him. Dracone had come in for tires and fuel on lap 25 but spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips's leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg at the infield care center and was released. Rain prior to the race caused traction issues for many cars. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd, and also spun out on turn one during the event.

In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano brutally murdered his wife, 29-year-old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, just four days after their wedding. CCTV footage captured Severiano assaulting her in their garden, where he physically attacked her and ultimately shot her multiple times. The motive was his jealousy over the attention she received from other men due to her involvement with the dance troupe Jaula das Gostozuedas. After the incident, Severiano fled in a stolen car but was apprehended by police after crashing the vehicle. Authorities found several firearms and a bulletproof vest in his possession. Severiano confessed to the crime and now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of the best-selling book *I Quit Sugar*, opened up about her personal battle with mental illness in a candid interview. She revealed that her anxiety had brought her to a point where she couldn't see the point of continuing and came close to taking her own life. Wilson explained that a combination of mounting stress, anxiety, her thyroid disease, and distant family contributed to her feelings of isolation and hopelessness. She felt alone as she hadn't found a husband nor had children, watching others "get on with their lives."

Wilson mentioned that while she struggled in her younger years, she has recently found some peace with her situation and now accepts that she is an "anxious person." She believes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection is essential to address the increasing rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. Highlighting that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," she referred to Beyond Blue's report that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime. Despite being different conditions, depression and anxiety can often lead to one another.

For those needing assistance, Beyond Blue can be contacted at 1300 224 636, and Lifeline is available at 13 11 14.

In November 2014, Oregon resident Elena Curtin, who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. Curtin came home to find the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom. When the woman refused to leave, Curtin used physical force, which is permissible under Oregon law against intruders who won't exit a residence. Prosecutors later dropped the charges, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents. The boyfriend, who has a history of heroin use and shares a five-year-old child with his ex-girlfriend, is not involved in his new child's life.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed at home being fed treats when her owner tried to trick her by adding a broccoli spear to the mix. Upon biting into the vegetable, Gemma showed immediate disgust and spat it out on the floor. The incident highlights her dislike for greens, and it's hoped that the two children she lives with won't follow her lead. Aside from her aversion to vegetables, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has issued an apology after a link on its official website inadvertently directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, intended for the bank's Young Entrepreneur Awards page, led to explicit content because the awards were discontinued in 2011 and the URL registration on hsbc.com.hk expired. A pornographic site subsequently took over the address. Upon discovering the error, HSBC promptly removed the hyperlink from its website. The bank stated it has no affiliation with the external site and assured the public that its own website remains secure. HSBC expressed regret for any inconvenience caused.

On Sunday morning in Clinton, Maryland, 13-year-old Marcus called 911 when his family's home caught fire, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom. Remaining calm during the 11-minute call, Marcus provided precise directions to firefighters and soothed his panicking sister by reminding her to stay low and breathe. Firefighters from Prince George's County entered the home, broke into their room through a window, and rescued the siblings. Lieutenant Kenny Ward handed Marcus out the window to another rescuer and gave his own gas mask to Aaliyah after she tugged on his leg. Assistant Fire Chief Alan Doubleday praised Ward's actions as heroic. Marcus and Aaliyah were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while their mother, stepfather, and older brother escaped on their own and were transported to MedStar Hospital.

Amazing photographs have captured blue fluorescent algae illuminating Australia's east coast at Jervis Bay, New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The phenomenon is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in the spring and autumn, usually due to natural causes. According to Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, this carnivorous organism preys on another type of algae called diatoms and emits a luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar display was observed at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, where experts assured the public there was no need for concern about the algae.

New genetic tests like EndoPredict are helping breast cancer patients determine the aggressiveness of their tumors by pinpointing genetic markers. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening, and within days, women can learn their risk of the disease returning. For some, the tests reveal a recurrence risk as low as 5% over ten years, which is comparable to the odds after undergoing chemotherapy.

Traditionally, most women receive chemotherapy following tumor removal to prevent recurrence, despite the treatment's severe side effects—such as hair loss, nausea, and extreme fatigue—that can be more daunting than surgery itself. Experts like surgeons Hemant Singhal and Professor Kefah Mokbel advocate for these tests, believing they empower patients to make informed choices and could reduce unnecessary chemotherapy treatments.

Currently available privately at about £2,500, there is hope these tests will soon be accessible through the NHS. Patient Becca Cornford, a 49-year-old mother of three, benefited from EndoPredict after discovering cancer in her second breast. With a low-risk score, she opted out of chemotherapy, preferring regular monitoring. She acknowledges that while no treatment guarantees zero risk, early detection through vigilant follow-up offers a chance to address any recurrence promptly.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five sailors from HMS Ocean over the past nine years and at least one from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty" before its decommissioning. Data obtained revealed that 18 other ships, such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations for pregnant personnel. The Ministry of Defence enforces a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting these pregnancies likely occurred before deployment or during leave.

These incidents align with the return of Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, who was flown back to the UK amid allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member, leading to a military investigation. The Ministry of Defence did not confirm the reasons for her departure or any subsequent actions.

Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990 and made up about 9% of personnel in 2014. In a historic milestone, three women became the first female submariners in the Royal Navy last May. 

Similarly, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between January 2006 and December 2013 after discovering they were pregnant, with 16 in 2013 and 18 in 2011. An additional 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Strict military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones. While troops are reminded by senior officers to ensure they are not pregnant before deployment, they are not required to undergo pregnancy tests. Most pregnancies were likely conceived before leaving the UK, though some may have occurred during deployment. According to a Ministry of Defence spokesman, "The small numbers of personnel who discover that they are pregnant on operations are returned at the first convenient opportunity."

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo on Wednesday, prompting concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone, equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material, was found by a staff member. While the amount of cesium was not immediately harmful to humans, its presence raised alarms.

The incident occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved the government's plan to restart two nuclear reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant in Kagoshima Prefecture, a move that faces public opposition due to safety concerns following the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who was attending the Asian-African Conference in Indonesia at the time, has been advocating for the reactors' restart despite widespread apprehension about nuclear energy.

Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed heightened concerns about the threat of terrorism, especially with upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 Summit. He emphasized the need to review regulations on small unmanned vehicles to prevent future incidents. Currently, Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but imposes no such restrictions over most of Tokyo, including critical government buildings like the Prime Minister's residence.

A security guard named Lu Xincai from Zhejiang province in eastern China takes dedicated care of his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. Concerned that she might get lost if left alone—especially after she had previously wandered off while collecting firewood—Lu began bringing her to work with him every day after his father's passing left no one else to look after her. Each morning at 5 a.m., he helps her get ready and secures her to the back of his motorbike with a sash tied around both their waists to ensure she doesn't fall off. They travel four kilometers to his workplace, a journey that takes an hour as he rides slowly to make her feel safe and so they can chat along the way. His employer, a bank, has provided a room for his mother, and Lu frequently checks on her throughout the day to ensure she hasn't wandered off. Lu expresses deep devotion to his mother, saying, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple," acknowledging his duty to care for her just as she cared for him when he was young.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the *American Journal of Public Health*, found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, primarily due to rising rates among women. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) defines heavy drinking as consuming more than one drink per day for women and more than two for men over the past month; binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion at least once in the past month.

The increase is largely driven by changing social norms affecting women's drinking habits. Nationwide, the rate of binge drinking among women rose more than seven times the rate among men over the decade. For example, in Santa Clara County, California, women's binge drinking rates increased nearly 36% between 2002 and 2012, compared to a 23% increase among men.

In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers, and 18% were binge drinkers, while the overall percentage of people who drink alcohol remained relatively unchanged. The study, the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, highlighted regional variations: Madison County, Idaho, had the lowest rate of binge drinking at 6%, whereas Menominee, Wisconsin, had the highest at 36%; Hancock County, Tennessee, had the fewest heavy drinkers at 2%, and Esmeralda County, Nevada, had the most at 22%.

Several factors contribute to the rise in excessive drinking, including increased alcohol advertising expenditures (about $3.45 billion in 2011), alcohol becoming cheaper due to taxes not keeping pace with inflation, weakened alcohol control policies, and the influence of affluent professionals in urban areas who may engage in hard-partying lifestyles. Young people and wealthier individuals are more likely to binge drink, and changing social norms have made it more acceptable for women to drink heavily.

Alcohol-related issues have significant societal costs, with approximately 88,600 deaths attributed to alcohol in 2010 and an estimated annual cost of excessive drinking exceeding $220 billion. While more individuals are seeking treatment for alcoholism, many do not seek help unless faced with serious consequences like job loss or legal issues.

The findings are based on data from about 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older, collected through the CDC's Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System, an ongoing telephone survey of health behaviors.

UN officials from the World Health Organization (WHO) warn that doctors are jeopardizing the health of women and their babies by performing caesarean sections too frequently. They stress that caesareans should only be conducted when medically necessary due to the risks of infections, significant complications, disabilities, and even death associated with the procedure. In England, over 25% of women now give birth via caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. This rise includes an increasing number of women opting for planned caesareans due to severe anxiety about natural childbirth, a condition known as tokophobia.

The WHO advocates for an optimal caesarean rate between 10% and 15%, considering the health dangers and financial costs involved. Their stance contrasts sharply with current NHS guidelines, which allow women to choose caesareans even without medical justification. The procedure's higher cost—averaging £2,369 for a planned caesarean compared to £1,665 for a natural birth—also diverts funds from other healthcare needs. Additionally, prior research indicates that up to one in ten caesareans result in infections.

The WHO urges doctors to reduce unnecessary caesarean sections and to be more cognizant of the associated risks and costs, emphasizing that overuse of the procedure can have adverse short- and long-term health effects on women and their babies.

A 44-year-old woman named Michelle Filkins from West Wareham was arrested after she allegedly broke into an $800,000 home on Martha's Vineyard, lived there for at least a week, and sold the homeowners' belongings in a yard sale. Homeowner Mark Conklin discovered Filkins sitting in his living room on April 17. When confronted, she claimed ownership of the house and fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck as Conklin called the police. Officers found a broken window covered by a blanket, indicating a break-in. Filkins was arrested hours later when she attempted to re-enter the home, thinking Conklin had left. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, and is scheduled to appear in court on May 14. Missing items include furniture, lamps, a grill, household items, and a painting by the owner. Police are asking anyone who received items from Filkins to return them to the Edgartown Police Department, assuring that those who purchased items are also victims and will be assisted in seeking restitution.

A lost iPhone belonging to Melbourne resident Bella Crooke was reunited with her after Albury police officers used her unlocked phone to post humorous messages and photos on her Facebook page. Bella misplaced her phone at a friend's birthday party, and it was handed in to the Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border by a security guard. Realizing the phone was unlocked, officers posted selfies and playful updates such as "You should probably put a password on your phone" and photos of the phone in a holding "cell," complete with puns like "It is a great 'cell' phone" and assurances that it would be "fully 'charged'" upon her arrival. The posts garnered amused reactions from Bella's friends. When she went to retrieve her phone, officers recognized her from her Facebook profile without needing her name. Bella appreciated the officers' sense of humor and has since added a password to her phone, thanking them for returning it and their lighthearted approach.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was hurled into the air and dragged along the water by one of the males during the tussle, while its mother watched in horror. The mother had previously kept her calf away from sub-adult and younger hippos, fearing they might be too rough. During the fight, she stayed with her herd, possibly believing it was safer. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the incident and recounted how the mother tried to rescue her calf but was unable to prevent the tragedy. The baby hippo succumbed to its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on sale for £575,000, a fraction of the typical price in this expensive area. The low cost is due to the property having only three years left on its lease. Extending the lease could cost between £3.35 million and £4.5 million, potentially increasing the property's value to over £6 million. The unmodernized maisonette in Egerton Place offers 1,990 square feet of space but requires renovation. It is one of two similar properties with short leases being sold by Russell Simpson. Estate agents report high interest because such opportunities are rare, but experts warn about the significant premiums associated with lease extensions and advise potential buyers to be cautious.

On Friday evening, a computer outage disrupted registers at 8,000 Starbucks stores across the U.S. and Canada, leading baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods or close stores early. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented staff from processing sales, especially credit card transactions. Excited customers shared their experiences on social media, posting photos of their free beverages. While some stores remained open accepting cash, others closed to avoid giving away free products. Starbucks announced late Friday that the issue was resolved and stores would open as usual on Saturday. The incident occurred just one day after the company reported record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

According to Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Individuals involved engage in seemingly ordinary community activities but have ulterior motives related to radicalization. Jones emphasized that terrorism is not confined to large cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence in identifying such threats.

The passage references historical incidents of Islamic extremist activities in Wales dating back to 1998, including claims that hate preacher Abu Hamza sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, a military training area known for its rugged terrain. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers, Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer, were photographed white water rafting at the National Whitewater Centre in Bala, North Wales. In 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff—Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai, and Abdul Miah—were arrested as part of an al-Qaeda-inspired group plotting attacks after holding secret meetings in a Welsh country park.

Additionally, Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is understood to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, which was reportedly established by Iraqi clerics. Detective Constable Jones highlighted these connections to underscore that such radicalization activities do occur in rural Welsh communities and called for vigilance and intelligence sharing from the public.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, a species once feared extinct and rarely seen, was found washed up on a remote beach near Exmouth in Western Australia after tropical cyclone Olwyn. Measuring 5.68 meters, the whale initially puzzled Department of Parks and Wildlife staff until DNA profiling confirmed its identity. This marks the first sighting of an Omura's whale in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the discovery "highly significant" due to the limited knowledge about the species, which was first described in scientific journals in 2003 and is typically found in tropical and subtropical waters like Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The carcass has been buried with plans to recover the skeleton for future scientific research and possible museum display. Omura's whales are noted for their sleek bodies and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. This find is expected to enhance understanding of the whale's distribution and aid in improving identification guides.

The article addresses statements made by Cheryl Rios, a Texas businesswoman who asserted that Hillary Clinton should not become president because women's hormones could make them irrational leaders prone to starting unnecessary wars. The author challenges this perspective by highlighting that male leaders have historically made impulsive decisions influenced by hormones, referencing unnecessary wars and scandals involving politicians like George W. Bush, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Mark Sanford, and John Edwards.

The discussion expands to the broader issue of gender bias in leadership and the workplace. Despite women outnumbering men in higher education and the workforce, persistent biases limit their potential. Examples include the underrepresentation of women on corporate boards—where men named John, Robert, William, or James outnumber all women combined—and the tendency for students to describe male professors as "geniuses" while labeling female professors as "nice." The article cites insights from Wharton professor Adam Grant and Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg on the benefits of eradicating gender stereotypes.

The author points out that Hillary Clinton's path to the White House is steepened not by her capabilities but by ingrained gender biases. Emphasizing that equality benefits everyone, the article notes that organizations with more women in leadership perform better financially, and that shared responsibilities strengthen families and marriages. The piece concludes by remarking on the irony of Rios's threat to move to Canada if Clinton is elected, given that Canada had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, aged 89, is auctioning over 200 items from his extensive collection of antiques, valued at £100,000, as he downsizes his home in the Cotswolds. Known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and for portraying Winston Churchill, Hardy is selling items that reflect his keen interest in military history and classic literature. Notable pieces include a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt commissioned in the 1960s, a yew longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of himself holding the bow. The auction also features paintings, furniture by Gillows of Lancaster, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating back to the 17th century. A total of 238 lots will be sold by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire on Saturday. Despite his sadness at parting with his collection, Hardy wishes the new owners as much joy as he had. Educated by J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford, he has published two books on the history of the longbow and was consulted during the raising of the Tudor shipwreck the Mary Rose. Hardy continues to work in television and is recognized by younger audiences for his role as Cornelius Fudge in the "Harry Potter" films.

A Florida man, **Michael Scott Shemansky**, is wanted by police as a suspect in the murder of his mother, **Sandra Shemansky**, 57. He has been on the run since Saturday after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son—the same day his mother's body was found at their shared home in Winter Garden following a well-being check requested by a family member. Initial investigations indicate foul play, and authorities have recovered the murder weapon but have not disclosed details about how she was killed.

Shemansky has a history of bipolar mental illness, was previously involuntarily committed after a suicide attempt, and is on parole for battery on law enforcement. He is undergoing divorce proceedings, and his estranged wife had filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years prior. Neighbors suggest that stress from the divorce and potential interference from his mother regarding the visit with his son may have contributed to the situation.

He was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication and was reportedly spotted shortly after the murder asking for a glass of water at the trailer park's office. Authorities urge anyone with information on his whereabouts to contact them at **407-656-3636**. His estranged wife is taking precautions in case he attempts to contact her.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) council decided to bypass the usual bidding process due to what it saw as a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the championships in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. A recent presentation to the IAAF convinced the governing body of Eugene's capability to stage the event. IAAF President Lamine Diack expressed delight over the decision, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. He acknowledged that while the decision departs from usual procedures, it serves the global development of the sport. Notably, the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

An aspiring model named Leonie Granger, 25, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for her role in the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger targeted Hassan after noticing him flashing cash at a London casino. She befriended him and, on the night of the crime, went to his flat and left the door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, 28, and his accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, 29. The two men entered, tied up Hassan, and killed him while ransacking his home for his winnings. They were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." All three were also convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan. After the crime, they were seen celebrating with the stolen money. Hassan's family expressed deep grief over his death.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a significant dip in form during the second half of the season, continuing a pattern noted since his time at Barcelona. He struggled in Spain's 2-0 defeat to the Netherlands, receiving a low rating from the Spanish press. After a brilliant start to the season with Chelsea—where he amassed 15 Premier League assists by mid-January—his contributions have dwindled, with only one assist in his last five league games. This decline puts him at risk of falling short of Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists in a Premier League season. Chelsea manager José Mourinho is concerned about Fabregas's fatigue and is hoping the midfielder can regain his form to aid in the club's title run-in. With nine league games remaining against teams he has previously excelled against, there is optimism that Fabregas can overcome his late-season slump and help secure the Premier League title for Chelsea.

West Ham United are in discussions to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, considered one of the most promising talents emerging from the Caribbean and linked with several European clubs, also has offers from teams in Belgium. In addition, West Ham have announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium for the 2016-17 season will start at £289, implementing the Premier League's most affordable pricing strategy to help fill the stadium's 54,000-seat capacity.

Police have dropped an investigation into an assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, just three months after the incident, despite substantial evidence pointing to a suspected attacker. Lane was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars attached to ropes during a hunt in Everleigh, near Amesbury. The hunt involved 30 riders and hounds chasing an artificial scent rather than a fox.

During the confrontation, Lane, who is joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was punched, kicked in the head, and knocked unconscious, resulting in concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling, and subsequent memory loss. A video capturing the face of the assailant and a dossier containing names and car registration numbers of suspected saboteurs were provided to Wiltshire Police.

Despite this evidence, the police have halted their investigation due to insufficient evidence to proceed, a decision that has left Lane and hunt supporters feeling let down and dismayed. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to help identify and bring criminals to justice. Wiltshire Police stated that the case has been recorded as undetected but will be reopened if further evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American known as "Azzam the American," was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, as announced by the White House. Gadahn was a prominent member of Al Qaeda and served as its chief English-language propagandist. Born Adam Pearlman in 1978 in rural California, he converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998. He appeared in numerous Al Qaeda videos, threatening attacks against Western targets, criticizing U.S. presidents, and encouraging lone-wolf actions within the United States. In 2006, he was indicted for treason and providing material support to Al Qaeda and was placed on the FBI's "Most Wanted Terrorists" list.

The operation that killed Gadahn also resulted in the death of Ahmed Farouq, another American Al Qaeda operative, though neither was specifically targeted. In a related attack that killed Farouq, two hostages—American Warren Weinstein and Italian Giovanni Lo Porto—also died. Gadahn was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child. His final video appearance was in September 2014, where he called for the overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan.

A viral video circulating in China showcases five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, a budding basketball prodigy who has been playing since he was two and a half. The footage captures Mai effortlessly scoring multiple hoops and skillfully dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without missing a beat, feats that surpass those of many professional players. His exceptional talent has garnered him a large fanbase across basketball-enthusiastic China, with netizens expressing astonishment and admiration. Comments range from disbelief—suggesting his skills are special effects—to self-reflection on personal achievements. Mai's rising stardom highlights China's passion for nurturing young prodigies, adding to the legacy of notable athletes like Yao Ming, the country's most prominent basketball figure to date.

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE)—an organization that campaigned in the 1970s and 80s to legalize child sex—has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. On February 25, O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament, chaired by comedian John Cleese, to lobby Members of Parliament for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns against what it perceives as the "biased and unfair" Independent Press Standards Organisation and advocates for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The revelation of O'Carroll's support is considered an embarrassment to Hacked Off. Previously, O'Carroll was involved with PIE's alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), where he served on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee. The NCCL had lobbied Parliament to reduce the age of sexual consent to ten, provided the child "understood the nature of the act" and apparently consented, and sought to legalize incest. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals" and confirmed his attendance at the rally in a blog post. A spokesperson for Hacked Off stated that the meeting was "open to and free for all members of the public to attend."

On Thursday, the iconic Icebergs Club pool at Bondi Beach was drained to create a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces fashion presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Regular lap swimmers were displaced as models showcased the brand's monochrome, unisex collection designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for both day and night. Ten Pieces, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, featured minimalist and androgynous designs. Models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. Guests enjoyed refreshments from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria under sunny skies on an unseasonably warm 28-degree Celsius day, while beachgoers and passers-by watched the show from nearby vantage points.

Boxer Amir Khan, born in Bolton, spent a day with his family at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari park in Northern California. He fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions alongside his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter, Lamysa. Earlier in the week, Khan announced that he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation over his next opponent. Khan had been under pressure to face British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June but revealed he was already deep in negotiations for the bout with Algieri. He had also been linked to potential fights against Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian teenager who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis, had his name added to an Israeli memorial at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, honoring fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. However, his family objected to his inclusion, stating they were not consulted and did not want his name listed among Israeli soldiers. Hussein Abu Khdeir, his father, firmly rejected his son's association with "soldiers of the occupation." Additionally, Almagor, an Israeli organization representing victims of terror, opposed his inclusion, arguing his death was a rogue attack rather than terrorism. Following protests from both the family and Almagor, the National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial, agreed to remove Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial wall and its website.

A video by California-based YouTube user Lionel Hutz features his young son trying to use the family cat's belly as a pillow. The footage shows the boy chasing the cat around the garden, repeatedly lying on top of the feline as it licks its fur. Each time, the cat gets up and moves to a new spot, but the boy persistently follows and tries again. After several attempts, the cat decides it's had enough and goes indoors. In a later video, they reconcile as the boy gently feeds the cat handfuls of treats.

Robert Kushner, a 32-year-old varsity basketball coach at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy in Bryn Mawr, lost his coaching job after testifying in a Philadelphia police corruption trial. During his testimony, he revealed his past as a marijuana dealer and alleged that undercover officers stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. This information was news to the school officials, as Kushner had passed a background check when hired in 2010. He acknowledged that the 2007 charges were expunged after a probationary sentence and admitted to a 2008 DUI and a 2011 arrest that led to four years of probation. Despite his past, Kushner expressed remorse and a commitment to coaching, with colleagues praising his work with kids. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, but their lawyers contend the case is based on testimonies from unreliable witnesses.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, injured six people and ignited a massive fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in making polyester films and fabrics. The blast occurred Monday night at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spills have been reported. Five of the injured were hurt by broken glass and have been hospitalized. Over 600 firefighters were deployed to control the blaze, which is now under control. Residents nearby reported hearing the explosion and feeling slight tremors. This plant experienced a previous explosion in July 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. The construction of PX plants has sparked illegal protests in China over pollution concerns, leading to occasional violence. Originally slated for the densely populated city of Xiamen, public backlash in 2007 prompted authorities to relocate the plant to its current, more remote location.

Jack Grealish, a teenage midfielder for Aston Villa and a Republic of Ireland under-21 international, insists he will continue wearing his socks low despite referees urging him to pull them up. Renowned for keeping his stockings just above his children's-sized shin pads due to superstition, Grealish states, "It's a superstition that I've done all my life and I'm going to keep it that way." He made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR on Tuesday night. Pleased with his debut, Grealish appreciates the manager's faith in him and hopes to secure more starts before the end of the season, saying, "He said I deserve my start which is nice to hear and it really gives me a bit of a boost."

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. While she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. Despite this, her father, Bobby Brown, recently announced that she is awake and watching him, suggesting some improvement. An attorney for the Brown family confirmed that her condition has improved but emphasized that the quality of her life remains uncertain and that her rehabilitation process will be lengthy and challenging. Family members express both hope and sorrow, acknowledging the difficult road ahead and the possibility that she may live in this condition indefinitely.

Russia is leading Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup semifinal after victories by Svetlana Kuznetsova and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova. Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets in the opening match. Pavlyuchenkova overcame Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, saving a match point in the second set. Both players struggled with their serves; Pavlyuchenkova had 13 double faults, while Lisicki committed 63 unforced errors. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and aim for their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week, potentially from Thursday through Saturday. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low—the same weather system that caused last week's severe weather—could impact the region again, bringing heavy rain, especially to the far northern parts of the state.

The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that additional storms will hamper ongoing clean-up efforts from the previous event. Out of over 24,000 requests for assistance received last week, more than 4,400 jobs remain unfinished. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills expressed particular concern for the Hunter region, which was heavily affected by flooding and high winds. She urged residents to prepare themselves, their homes, and their families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Meteorologist Kim Westcott noted that while another east coast low may form, it is expected to be less severe and affect different areas compared to the last storm, with heavy rain unlikely over Sydney. The Bureau of Meteorology stated it's too early to determine the storm's severity but warned that catchments already impacted by flooding could experience further rainfall.

SES personnel are working to complete as many tasks as possible before the potential storm arrives. Over 1,000 personnel are in the field across NSW, including 200 from other states such as Queensland, Victoria, the ACT, and South Australia.

Nina Moric, 38, the Croatian-born model known for appearing in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, has denied reports that she attempted to take her own life. Despite Italian media claims that she was found by her mother in her Milan apartment after a suicide attempt—and her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso reportedly confirming these allegations—Moric stated that she collapsed due to low blood pressure. She took to Instagram, where she has over 40,000 followers, to share photos of her injuries and explain that she suffered a domestic accident after fainting. Expressing shock over the suicide reports, she assured her fans that she is recovering at home and only needs rest. Moric was previously married to photographer Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria, born in 2002. Corona was later jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

As Kate and William anticipate the arrival of their second child, a YouGov poll for the Sunday Times reveals that "Diana" is the favorite name among the British public if the baby is a girl, with 12% support, honoring William's late mother. "Alice" and "Charlotte" are close contenders, each receiving 9% of the vote—"Alice" after the Queen's aunt and "Charlotte" as a nod to William's father, Charles. If it's a boy, "James" leads with 13% preference, followed by "Alexander."

The poll indicates a strong desire for a baby girl, with a quarter of the 2,200 respondents hoping for a daughter, while only 3% prefer a son. Social media users echo this sentiment, expressing enthusiasm for the name "Diana." Additionally, 68% of those surveyed support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, according to provincial police chief Faizullah Ghairat. The protesters, including Member of Parliament Humayoon Humayoon, were en route to join a larger rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time, eyewitness Zahir Jan reported. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility so far.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has enjoyed seven successful years at the club, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies. Unable to agree on a new deal, Alves will depart the Nou Camp. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that negotiations have ended after Alves declined a three-year contract extension that required him to participate in 60% of the matches. Santana expressed disappointment that Barcelona waited until April to address his contract renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old footballer currently playing for Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. Having become an instant hit at Boca by scoring three goals in six games, Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti's playing style possesses a South American flair that would make them perfect fits for the team. In an interview with *Corriere dello Sport*, he expressed that the fans at La Bombonera would be ecstatic to see such talented players. Despite having played with many great players throughout his career, Osvaldo specifically highlighted Pirlo and Totti as the two he would most like to see join him, confident they would be as loved in Argentina as they are in Italy.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson returned to work at Paul Nicholls's yard, bearing only a cut on his nose after a spectacular fall that made him an internet sensation. His double somersault fall from the favorite, Merrion Square, during the 4:20 pm race at Wincanton has been watched hundreds of thousands of times online. Despite the ordeal, Ferguson is undeterred and continues to ride. He described the incident as "just a blur" and only understood what happened after watching the replay with fellow jockeys, who looked away in horror. Grateful for his luck, he joked about pursuing a gymnastics career after racing, having gained some notoriety and a few hundred new Twitter followers from the incident.

England flanker and London Wasps captain James Haskell embraced the excitement surrounding the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron" by posting a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram. The movie premiered at Westfield London shopping centre, drawing fans eager to see stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell shared his photo with the message: "Avengers movie is out so thought I would release the inner Iron Man."

Haskell began his rugby career with Wasps in 2002, earning his first England cap five years later. In 2009, he moved to Stade Français in France, followed by stints with the Ricoh Black Rams in Japan and the Highlanders in New Zealand. After returning to Wasps in 2012, he surpassed 100 appearances for the club and became a key player for England, accumulating 57 caps to date.

The wide-leg trouser is emerging as a leading trend for Spring/Summer 2015, offering a refreshing alternative to the enduring skinny jeans. This versatile style—ranging from denim and cropped to printed and striped variations—exudes an effortless appeal. Fashion figures like Louise Redknapp suggest that while the wide-leg can be daunting, especially for shorter individuals, the key to mastering the look lies in styling. Pairing these trousers with high heels, particularly those that expose the top of the foot, can elongate the legs. Keeping the top half of the outfit simple—using a knit, shirt, or tee—maintains proportion and prevents the ensemble from looking costume-like. High-waisted and long-length options add extra leg length. Designers such as Gucci, Céline, and Stella McCartney have embraced the trend in their collections, with Gucci revisiting 1970s-inspired flared jeans. High-street brands like Topshop have also introduced styles like the 1970s-inspired "Miller" jean. This trend is practical for various weather conditions, making it a stylish and functional addition to any wardrobe.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a planned screening of "American Sniper" after over 200 students petitioned against it, asserting the film negatively depicted the Middle East and its people. Given the Detroit area's significant Arab-American population, the concerns resonated locally. However, following a backlash and a counter-petition urging the university to reconsider, Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper admitted that canceling the screening was a mistake inconsistent with the institution's commitment to freedom of expression. The university reinstated the movie for the UMix event and offered "Paddington" as an alternative for those who preferred not to attend "American Sniper." The reversal drew praise from Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

Two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24 and residing in Cockburn Central, allegedly used an aerosol spray and a lighter to produce a large flame that made contact with a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived the incident but was singed by the flame. Detectives visited the island on Saturday, questioned the men, and seized video evidence of the act. Both men were evicted from the island, charged with animal cruelty, and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, the size of a domestic cat, are native to small islands off the West Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

At 102 years old, former dancer Alice Barker was delighted to finally see footage of herself performing in the 1930s and 1940s. Barker had been a dancer in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and the Cafe Zanzibar, entertaining alongside notables such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Despite motion pictures being made of her, she had never seen them, and her personal photographs and memorabilia were lost over the years. With the help of Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and some volunteers, a compilation of early music videos called "soundies" was shown to her at the nursing home where she lives. Reacting to the footage, she exclaimed, "It's just fabulous."

A recent survey by vehicle leasing firm OSV indicates that the tradition of Britons washing their own cars is diminishing. The study of 1,100 adults found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do performing the task regularly. Among women, three-quarters reported never washing their own vehicles, opting instead for local car wash services. Contributing factors to this decline include the rise of Sunday shopping, increased live football on TV, the availability of affordable hand car washes, and larger vehicle sizes like 4x4s that are more challenging to clean. Furthermore, only 5% of respondents have asked their children to wash the car for extra pocket money. During holidays such as Easter, there's a surge in car washing by owners—an estimated 15 million cars—though a quarter admit doing it merely to get out of the house. The practice of self-washing is most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least common in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Owners of Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are more likely to wash their own cars, while those with Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are less inclined. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley commented that while car washing was once a national Sunday tradition, modern lifestyles, larger cars, disinterest from children, and convenient alternatives have led to its decline.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard for his significant impact since Skrtel joined Liverpool in 2008, noting Gerrard's assistance in helping him settle at the club. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool, acknowledging that the team will be different without him. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, which would be his final match before moving to LA Galaxy. Despite the challenge of replacing Gerrard, Skrtel believes Liverpool has players capable of filling the void with the team's support. Both Skrtel and Gerrard are expected to return to the lineup after serving three-match bans for violent conduct in a previous match against Manchester United.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus delighted fans by scoring a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus watched his ball sail past the flag before spinning back into the hole, marking his first ace at Augusta. The day saw a total of five hole-in-ones, tying the record set in 2002. Camilo Villegas made two aces on the fourth and eighth holes but narrowly lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, who became the youngest to wear the green jacket in 1963 and secured his sixth Masters win in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career Grand Slam—an achievement Rory McIlroy aims to match with a victory at the upcoming major.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens blared in Kansas as storms brought reports of tornadoes. A tornado was spotted about six miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. CNN's severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that storms would continue throughout the night and emphasized that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous.

Additional tornado sightings were reported near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. Kansas wasn't the only state affected; the National Weather Service indicated that a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. Reports from CNN affiliate KMOV mentioned wind damage and flooding in the town. Social media users shared images of fallen trees, damaged roofs, flooded streets, unusual dark clouds, and baseball-sized hail.

The Weather Service forecasted more storms on Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and areas near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve sheriff's deputy in Tulsa County, Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates claims he intended to subdue Harris with a Taser but mistakenly used his firearm instead. During his hearing, the judge granted Bates permission to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, a decision that prompted criticism from Harris's family, who viewed it as a sign of apathy toward the shooting and their loss.

Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. His lawyers expressed eagerness to address the facts in court rather than in the media. Meanwhile, Harris's family alleges that Bates was unqualified for his role and received preferential treatment due to donations he made to the sheriff's office and his friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz. The *Tulsa World* newspaper reported claims that some supervisors were instructed to falsify Bates's training records and were reassigned when they refused; the sheriff's office denies these allegations.

In response to scrutiny over his qualifications, one of Bates's lawyers released most of his training documents, asserting they demonstrate proper law enforcement training. Additionally, two deputies involved in Harris's arrest have been reassigned because of threats made against them and their families. Both Bates and Sheriff Glanz have apologized to the Harris family for the incident.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the encounter, McGregor unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, adding to his existing chest tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart. He shared the new ink on Instagram with the caption, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor claims that Aldo lacks the same motivation and highlighted their tense relationship, which included grabbing Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin. Aldo will be defending his title for the eighth time, while McGregor aims to claim it in front of his supporters.
